description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

Brace yourself for an evening dripping with glamour, sparkle, and a whole lot of cheek as you soak in the skyline of Wellington's most unique rooftop hideaway

TRIGGER WARNINGS: This is an R18 event! Expect strong language, good vibes, and thotty danger and legs so smooth they'll sweep you off your feet!—100% guaranteed! xx

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
(door sales will be available)
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

description:
Practices of Compassion, Explore the practices of the Sisters of Compassion then and now, through the lens of the historic crèche and the ongoing mahi of the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Learn about the historic crèche established by Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert and the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, now known as the Pukeahu Education Centre. Hear the stories of the practices of compassion led by the Sisters in early 20th century Wellington.

Then, walk over to the Compassion Soup Kitchen on Tory Street where the Sisters of Compassion and their co-workers are still supporting people with kai, aroha and much more.

This programme offers a unique look at the past and present practices of compassion emanating from these two influential and historic Wellington sites. Please bring along a cash koha for the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Session times:
Wednesday 22 October 12pm — 1:30pm
Thursday 23 October 12pm — 1:30pm

Booking is required.

The Compassion Soup Kitchen is a two-minute walk from the Pukeahu Education Centre.
Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Week: Tragedies Tour, Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Tales from the Vaults Tour, Tales from the Vaults.
Find out who is in and who is out of some of Karori cemetery’s most substantial dwellings. Note: tours do not enter vaults or try them out for size. 
The tour duration is 1 hour 45mins.
This tour is suitable for people with moderate fitness. The route mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness. Surefootedness is required. This tour involves approximately 2km of walking, with some slow paced but uphill stints

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes long
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - Gallows Tour (Dec 2025), Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.
While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: National Monuments (Dec 2025), The two main stops on the tour are the Cemeteries’ two national Monuments – the Tangiwai disaster and Prime Minister Peter Fraser.  We will review what happened at Tangiwai and especially the bravery of the trains crew and in addition, what the court of inquiry found about the safety of the bridge. 
Peter Fraser is generally regarded as one of NZ’s best Prime Ministers of the 20th century, and we explore his initiatives in public health and education and also his leadership during WW2.
These are just two of the several stops we will make.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you 1 hour before the tour start time by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
He Kura Toi Tangata: Gold Card Tour, Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum invites our golden folk to experience an intimate, guided tour of photography exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The tour will continue throughout the museum, weaving through Wellington stories and taonga currently on display.
After the tour, we’ll sit down for a chat and a warm cuppa in the old Harbour Board room, with a little sweet something to finish off the afternoon.
This tour is part of the Takurua Hauora: Winter Wellness event series developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
Tickets are limited. Booking is essential.
Note: International visitor admissions are not included.

Sunday 24 August | 10:30am–12pm
$5 for SuperGold Card holders

Book online or over the phone on: 04 472 8904
Image: Ngāi Te Rangi kuia in attending the hearing of the urgent claim concerning the use of te reo Māori in the public service. 2024. Wellington. Image credit: Tessa Chrisp.

description:
CHAPPELL vs CHARLI: A Drag Fundraiser Smackdown, Friday 27 September | 9.30pm @ Ivy Bar, Pōneke
Tickets: $20 (excluding ticket fees) | Generosity options available!
All proceeds to Wellington Pride Festival!

Kia ora! brats and popstars! Get your heads out the passenger seat and get ready, cause your about to be bumpin’ that with some of wellington drags finest!
Royalty is stepping into the ring (well, the stage) for CHAPPELL vs CHARLI : a high-camp, high-stakes, drag smackdown showdown, where our fabulous local drag artists channel the icons of Charli XCX and Chappell Roan to battle it out for title of 'Queen of the Chartsverse'… all in the name of charity xx

Three lip sync rounds. Four drag titans. One glitter-drenched champion.
Each round sees performers pull a mystery song each from their assigned diva’s discography and fight for the crown based on lip sync accuracy and undeniable star quality. Think charity boxing... but queerer. Like, much queerer. Only you! The audience! And our incredible judge Rachel Winter Hase, can determine our number #1 pop icon!

Featuring:
- Homer Neurotic (multi-award-winning drag king)
- Slay West (the biggest mouth in the biz)
- Petra Fyde (now your petrified)
- Ms. Leading (Your big bros lil secret)
(and Olivia Dreams on door)

Hosted by the ever-glamorous Selina Simone, and judged by local performance legend Rachel Winter Hase, who will deliver her pop verdicts with love and lashes *whipcrack.mp3

A high-speed crash of glitter, vocals, and vengeance! Expect drag, drama, and come ready to holler, hoot, bump and help decide who is our ultimate XCX BRAT or CHAPPELL POPSTAR!

Tickets: Just $20 + fees, with donation options for those feeling generous – every cent raised goes to support Wellington Pride Festival, helping make 2025 the queerest yet!

Accessibility: Ivy Bar is located downstairs but alternative access is possible with prior planning. Please email theselinasimone@gmail.com so we can accommodate you. If you wish to attend and donate, but cost is an issue for you, please reach to me as well xx

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival)
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 2 November 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
Contra Dance 18 October 2025, Contra Dance Wellington - October Dance 2025
When: Saturday, 18 October 2025
Where: St Michael’s Community Hall
81 Upland Road, Kelburn,
Wellington
Dance Time: 7:00-10:30pm. Be ready to dance at 7:00 when the band kicks off.
Entry: $15.00 waged, $10.00 unwaged $5.00 children $30.00 family (CASH ONLY)
Please bring something to share for supper around 9:15. Tea and coffee are provided.
About Contra: Contra Dance is for all ages. It's called and danced in long opposite lines. You swap partners progressively and dance with everyone in the opposite line. Footwork is easy and at a walking pace. No special dance ability required. You meet everyone and it’s massive fun!!
The Band:
Jonathan Berkahn – accordian, piano
Emily Griffiths – fiddle, banjo
Monika Wells - accordian
Lydia Warren – recorder, whistle
Bernard Wells – keyboard, flute, fiddle
Mark Howell – hammered dulcimer and mandolin
Remember!
Please come only if you're feeling well.
Bring family, friends, tell people it’s on.
Like Contra Dance Wellington on Facebook to stay in the loop about upcoming dances.
See you on the dance floor!

description:
Helpful tools for searching NZ historical records, Helpful tools for searching NZ historical records
The Wellington Branch of the NZ Society of Genealogists hosts a demonstration of online tools that make searching for your New Zealand families easier.

Luke Howison will demonstrate some of the features of Ancestor Search Helper (ASH), a free NZ genealogy search site, and also its sister-sites Archway-style Collections Search, an unofficial alternative to searching Archives NZ, and also give a tour of the Intentions to Marry Project, which features 40+ years of digitised and transcribed registers of Intentions to Marry from Archives NZ.


Cost: Free
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/helpful-tools-for-searching-nz-historical-records/


Health & Safety:
Health and Safety instructions will be given at the beginning of the talk. In an emergency evacuation, there are two assembly points in the carpark and between the two greens. The exit to be used in the event of an emergency will be the upstairs door leading directly onto the upper carpark. The bowling club hall and buildings are smoke and vape free. The venue maintains health and safety manuals.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Innovations in Stroke Care - World Stroke Day 2025 Public Lecture, Please join Stroke Aotearoa New Zealand and the University of Otago, Pōneke Wellington Campus on World Stroke Day 2025 for this public lecture from Professor Anna Ranta, a world leading authority on stroke research, care, and policy. Her lecture will briefly cover current stroke trends in New Zealand and globally followed by an in-depth discussion on prevention and treatment strategies. This will explore the latest scientific advances and future directions including the promise and pitfalls of AI technologies.

To RSVP your attendance to this free event, please complete the online form below:
https://forms.office.com/r/rKC7igpqM5?origin=lprLink

description:
JKaiWa, Japanese Conversation Evening
(October), こんにちは皆さん！
Come along and flex your Japanese language skills at JKaiWa
JETAA Wellington’s monthly Japanese conversation evening. JKaiWa welcomes language learners and native speakers to come and enjoy casual conversation in Japanese with like-minded people!
This month JKaiWa will be held on Thursday 9th October from 5:30pm - 7:00pm, at the usual place, the Japan Information and Cultural Centre, Level 18, Majestic Centre, 100 Willis Street Wellington CBD.
For health and safety reasons we have been asked to limit the number of attendees to a total of 30 people. We still absolutely encourage anyone interested in attending to sign up, as we often do not reach this 30 people limit, however signing up is now mandatory, so please follow the link below if you wish to attend:
https://forms.gle/fernCvWAwM9hhG3M7
If all 30 places are taken you will receive an email letting you know of your spot on the waiting list. Likewise, if you have signed up and can no longer attend, you can email jkaiwawlg@gmail.com and let us know.
Sign-ups close the morning of the event.
This is a free event open to anyone with Japanese conversational ability from beginner to advanced and native speakers, so feel free to share this event with all your Japanese-speaking friends!
Some packaged snacks may be provided.
We hope to see you there!
よろしくおねがいします!

description:
Aviation Industry Association Conference 2025, Aviation Industry Association Conference 2025
Mark your calendars for the pre-eminent commercial operator aviation event of the year, held annually in New Zealand.

This AIANZ Conference promises to be an immersive experience, offering invaluable insights, networking opportunities, and expert-led discussions that shape the future of aviation.

Tākina Wellington Convention and Exhibition Centre, Sunday 14 to Tuesday 16 September 2025.

Harness Collective Wisdom: At AIANZ, we believe in the power of collective wisdom. By participating in our conference, you’ll have access to a wealth of industry expertise and insights. Together, we can navigate challenges and seize opportunities for the greater good of the aviation community. Don’t miss out on this unparalleled opportunity to connect, learn, and shape the future of aviation.

Calling on Exhibitors and Sponsors - we are seeking interest from sponsors and exhibitors for our Conference. Please see the prospectus here: https://aianz.org.nz/wp-content/uploads/AIANZ-Conference-Prospectus-2025-v1.pdf

description:
All That Heaven Allows, Details
Directed by Douglas Sirk
Starring Rock Hudson, Jane Wyman
70th Anniversary

--- Cary Scott is a well-to-do widow gradually re-entering a social life amongst her mostly dull country club peers. Her only apparent enjoyment in life comes from weekend visits from her college-age children. Cary then meets a handsome younger man, Ron, who owns a small landscaping business. A follower of Henry David Thoreau's Walden, Ron enjoys a life focused on nature and is deliberately uninterested in the gossipy opinions of others. Their romance causes clashes and tensions between Cary, her children, and the country club. ---

This is a TEA TIME TALKIE screening where a delicious Devonshire Tea* awaits for upgraded tickets holders (a cup of tea and traditional homemade scones with cream and jam). This is served upstairs in the Grand Lobby during the intermission.

Admit only tickets are available for $15 or you can upgrade to include a Devonshire Tea for $24.

*No dietaries catered for.

Schedule:
2:35pm – Cinema doors open
2:45pm – Feature starts
3:15pm – Intermission, Devonshire Tea available for collection upstairs in the Grand Lobby
3:30pm – Feature resumes
label: Film & Media

description: Aikido classes, Learn aikido in a supportive environment, friendly club and superb dojo with certified teachers. We hold adults and teens classes 6:30pm every Monday and Wednesday, and kids classes 5:30pm Mondays during school terms. We welcome beginners and aikidoka with aikido experience to join in. Aikido is a very effective martial art with a fascinating philosophy of peaceful conflict resolution, and has to be seen and experienced: first three classes free, so try something life-improving. Conrad, 4th degree black belt, 021 843 467

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Family event: Explore Omnibirding with Giselle Clarkson, We are thrilled and delighted to announce we are going to be hosting a fabulous school holiday event with the multi-award winning Giselle Clarkson to celebrate the release of her latest book Omnibird: An Avian Investigator’s Handbook, a guide to the art and science of omnibirding.
Giselle Clarkson, the author of The Observologist, will be in Tawa for this very special event to explore the inner workings of the book and delights and wonders of the avian world.
Some birds are so commonplace it’s easy to forget how extraordinary they are. These creatures have a secret eyelid, hollow bones and a two-part brain. They dress in feathers. Omnibird, explores what’s remarkable about the birds all around us and the clues we can all use to become avian investigators.
Giselle is an author, illustrator and cartoonist based in Greytown, known for her work on conservation and environmental topics. She has illustrated award-winning picture books and nonfiction and is a 2023 Arts Foundation Laureate, receiving the prestigious Mallinson Rendel Illustrators Award.
This promises to be an unmissable event for bird and nature lovers of any age.
Books for sale thanks to the Children's Bookshop.
We wish to extend our thanks to Gecko Press for helping make this event happen.
This is a free event.
We expect this event to be very popular so to secure your seat early arrival is suggested.
label: Family Friendly

description:
It’s Vall Walk time again (nearly)!!, It’s Vall Walk time again (nearly)!!
HALLO FOLKS!!

Yep, that's right!! It's Vall Walk Time again (... well, not for a wee while yet ...)

This time I'm giving plenty of notice, because there's a chance my doggy-dad, Jack, might be able to come along (and Aria, and his peoples!) ... I HOPE!!

And because I LIKE it here, AND because it's gonna be a BEEYUTIFUL day (I just KNOW it!!), AND because the Tide is going to be LOW (or so calculates Buddy Dad, so we'll see if THAT turns out to be true), let’s go to the Beach at Queen Elizabeth Park!!

AND let's have a BBQ PICNIC too, cos it's SPRING time, and it's BOUND to be fine and warm!! YUMAY!!

Let's meet in the car park just inside the Mackay Crossing entrance to the Park. We'll head down to the beach from there! Bring your picnic and BBQ thingies too!! Buddy dad will bring our small portable BBQ and will cook things for you too. And don't forget about the small fee I charge to be your Official Taster!! (Snicker!!)

So, we’ll see you there!! WOOHOO!! I can hardly wait!!

And let's aim for a record turn out, because I KNOW there's lots of you Vall's out there, including a few newbies, just hanging out for some F-U-N, and blowing off some winter cob-webs!!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kareoke & Disco Fundraiser, Ultimate Kareoke Disco Fundraiser Night! Let’s send me to Australia in style!
Malo families & friends, as you all know I got picked for the Wellington Samoa cricket tour to Australia — but I need your help to cover my ticket, kit, and subs. This is my FINAL DANCE to fund this dream, and I’m counting on you to bring the vibes, the laughs, and the support!
Date, place & vibes:
Saturday 6th Sep
Cutlers Entertainment, The Hutt
6:00 PM – Midnight
Let’s light up the floor and keep the good energy rolling all night long!
What’s happening:
Kareoke & Disco Party Night — you bring the voice, we bring the glory!
Cash prizes: Winner takes home $500
, 2nd, 3rd and 4th places take home a NSW or Maroon hoodie (your pick)

Sing solo or in a crew — 10 lucky peeps get to perform the beat between 9:30pm to 11pm
Entry to perform: only $50 per seat (book fast — only 10 spots!)
Tickets to watch and dance: Online $20 | Door $25
How to join the fun:
Want to sing? Message me NOW to grab your seat!

Kareoke entry deadline: 30th Aug — don’t miss out!
Song submission for the night: 1st Sep — we’ll be ready to roll!
Tickets to dance & watch: inbox me — I’ll send your number once you book and pay

Payment - Te Mana
03-0531-0113530-001 (Please ref your FB name)
Support the dream:
Can’t perform? Come cheer, dance, and enjoy with great food & drink deals!

VIPs & judges will be on hand to spice up the night and crown our karaoke king/queen

Share this post, invite your crew, and flood the dance floor with love — the more, the merrier!
DJ & vibes:
DJ Mana spinning a vibrant mix of Pacific tunes for all ages
Epic lighting, dance circles, and island-flare vibes that’ll have you smiling all night
Why I’m asking for your help:
October tour in Australia is my first cricket adventure abroad — I want to represent our Tokelau family with pride.
Every dollar brings me closer to my dream and to stepping onto that pitch with heart!
Let’s make this night legendary. Your support means the world to me — bring family, friends, neighbours, and your best dance moves!
Special prizes for our male/ female best dressed outfit on the night

(Island Club Theme)
Hope to see you there!

description:
International Day of the Girl - 2025, You are Invited to our inaugural International Day of the Girl Fundraising to celebrate the work of Heartprint Cambodia.

The AquaPura Project is raising funds for a new Safe Water installation, and an Emergency Rapid Response Kit for Heartprint in Cambodia.
Heartprint is wholly aligned with AquaPura's mission to educate and provide technical training for girls to be safe water system installers and maintenance leads, so they are provided an opportunity to succeed in a male-dominated industry of essential water provision services.

The theme of International Day of the Girl Child 2025 is:
"The Girl I Am, the Change I Lead: Girls on the Frontline of Crisis". 

This theme was developed in consultation with girls' organisations, UN partners, and girls themselves.

This theme emphasise the leadership potential of girls and their role in driving positive change, particularly in the face of crisis. 

The International Day of the Girl, observed annually on 11th October, aims to highlight the challenges girls face globally, and promote their rights and empowerment. 

The 2025 theme specifically acknowledges the unique experiences and contributions of girls during times of crisis, recognising them as agents of change. 

This fundraiser will be led by Girls, who deeply understand the importance of delivering Safe Water for Every Child.
Heartprint is a not for profit organisation committed to improving living standards of underprivileged families in Cambodia. Heartprint takes a holistic approach to charity by building the Heartprint Community Centre. They are able to provide the support that looks at the whole family structure, not just the basic living needs, but also addressing their overall physical, emotional, social, and spiritual wellbeing.

SCHEDULE: Sat 4 October InPerson Venue
10-12pm: Room 2
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)
1 - 3 pm: Room 1
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table:
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Film screening: GAGA
Join us for a special screening of the 2022 Taiwanese comedy-drama film GAGA, featuring a Q&A with the award-winning Director, Laha Mebow

About this Event

Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.

Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.


Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

https://cdn-az.allevents.in/events10/banners/8cd1bb10-7456-11f0-994e-1dce379af11a-rimg-w570-h740-dc090807-gmir.jpg

description:
Live & Work in Japan! Q&A Evening with JET Programme Alumni, Have you ever wanted to live and work in Japan?
Come talk
to some people who've done it!
Every year, a diverse range of New Zealanders representing a variety of backgrounds, ages, interests, and cultures start a life-changing adventure in Japan-and next year that could include you!
With applications for the New Zealand JET Programme around the corner, you may have questions about what it's actually like to be sent off to live and teach in Japan for a year or more!
The JET Alumni Association of Wellington, in coordination with The Embassy of Japan, have organised a casual evening event for prospective applicants to ask those questions, and hear some stories to help you make a better decision about if the JET Programme is right for you.
Q&A event details
Date: 6th October 2025
Time: 17:30 - 19:30
Location: Yoshi Sushi & Bento (Press Hall, Willis Street)
Doors open from 5:30, with Q&A starting from 6:00.
Enjoy free
courtesy of Yoshi Sushi & Bento.
(Drinks, including Japanese
will also be available for purchase).
Admission to the event is FREE!
So come along and bring your friends
to this great opportunity to meet a handful of the thousands of Kiwis who've taken part in this programme over the past 40 years
Anyone interested in applying is welcome to attend!

What is the Japan Exchange Teaching (JET) Programme, you ask?
The JET Programme is an overseas employment opportunity to live and work in Japan for a year or more! You could soon head abroad on the adventure of a lifetime, and get paid for it!
Programme criteria includes the following-are you:
A New Zealand citizen?
Already graduated?
Or will have your Bachelor's Degree/Teaching Diploma conferred by early July 2026?
Interested in international activities?
Interested in teaching English to young people and living in Japan?

Positions available:
Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
ALTs help the Japanese foreign language teachers in class and help prepare teaching materials and class activities. They may assist in English language clubs and other extra-curricular activities. Knowledge of Japanese is not required to be an ALT.
Coordinator for International Relations (CIR)
CIRs work in local government offices and are involved in international activities, which might include editing publications, translation work, advising on the planning and implementation of exchange programmes, and interpreting at international events. A functional knowledge of written and spoken Japanese is required to be a CIR.
For more information about the New Zealand JET Programme, visit:
https://www.nz.emb-japan.go.jp/itpr_en/jet.html
https://www.facebook.com/JETProgrammeNZ/
We hope to see you there!

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
MMC Evening Connection, We’re excited to share with you this brand new event:
MMC Evening Connection! #2
Created in response to requests for more after-hours activities, these evenings gathering is all about community, storytelling, and belonging.
Whether you're new to Marlborough or a long-time local, join us for a relaxed Friday evening of conversation and connection in a welcoming space. This is your chance to meet others, share experiences, and celebrate the diverse cultures that make up our region.
Special Highlight
We are proud to welcome Puku Rangi Tea, a cultural performing group from Rapa Nui (Easter Island). They will share with us their rich journey through history, legends, and the vibrant traditions of the island.
Come along for Kōrero, laughter, and meaningful connection.
Bring a friend or make a few new ones!
Limited Capacity | RSVP Only |
label: Community & Culture

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.

description:
September Mini Golf @ Pirate's Cove, It's been forever since our last scheduled Mini Golf meet-up!
Apologies for the late notice, but we couldn't bear going three months without a game.
This month is at Pirate's Cove in Porirua. Tee-off is 10am.
We'll lock in a bit more routine for the next few months and there will be some practice sessions for November's NZ Open, once again at Golf Warehouse in Lower Hutt.
Make sure you RSVP via Humanitix or Facebook as we'll tee-off around 10am or when everyone who has registered is present.
A bit of rain or wind doesn't bother us, but if it's too rough, we'll change our plans (keep an eye on Facebook or Humanitix)

NAWIC 2025 Annual General Meeting, Join us for NAWIC’s 2025 AGM on Wednesday, 15 October.
The AGM is your opportunity to:
Hear about NAWIC’s progress and plans for the year ahead
Have your say on key decisions shaping our organisation
Connect with fellow members and industry peers
Celebrate 30 years of NAWIC and the collective impact we’ve made
Whether you’re a long-time member or new to NAWIC, your voice matters. Together, we’re shaping an equitable construction sector where women are empowered to thrive.
We look forward to seeing you there.
If you are unable to attend in person, please register your apology here:
NAWIC AGM 2025 Apology
Start time: 5.30pm arrival for a 6.00pm AGM kick-off.
Venue: Aoraki Construction, L1, 74 Cambridge Terrace, Wellington
 Come as you are - snacks will be provided
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organization, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015. Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
National Library 60th Birthday Open Home, Here’s to 60 years! Your National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa is turning 60 and we’re opening our doors in Wellington to invite you, your whānau and communities to celebrate with us.
Come along to view our collections up close, take part in activities and join guided tours of the He Tohu exhibition and our collection stores.
Our curators, librarians, archivists and conservators will share some of their favourite collection items and take visitors behind the scenes of the Library. There will be tours of He Tohu, a chance to help build a replica waka and a kids’ corner to keep the whānau entertained. At 2pm, we’ll be celebrating with cake.
Our friends at City Gallery Wellington will be open from 1pm to 4pm.
Experience your taonga
View a display of our collections from the National Library and the Alexander Turnbull Library, featuring taonga from books, comics, manuscripts, photos and more.
Learn about what we collect, how we collect and how you can make the Library your whare through making the most of our services and connecting with our collections. Drop in to chat with Library staff, learn more about our work and get up close with the collections.
Build a waka with friends
Help build the replica voyaging waka Whakaura and learn how Māori and Pacific peoples used their knowledge and navigational expertise to sail their amazing waka across one-third of the earth’s surface.
***Join a guided tour***
Explore our back of house — Take a special guided tour of our collection repositories and learn more about how we preserve the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand. Don’t miss out on this very rare opportunity to take a peek behind the scenes and see some exciting taonga in our collection stores.
Tours are 45 minutes and booking is essential as spaces are limited. Please email us to reserve your place — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz.
***Take a tour of He Tohu***
No booking required. Join our friendly kaiārahi for a guided tour of our exhibition He Tohu and view the three iconic constitutional documents that are shaping Aotearoa New Zealand:
*1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
*1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
*1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
History of the National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa: The National Library was formed in 1965 when the General Assembly Library, the Alexander Turnbull Library and the National Library Service (comprising the Country Library Service and the School Library Service) were brought together by the National Library Act 1965. For the past 60 years, we’ve continued to grow and evolve our collections and services.

description:
The Effective Speaker, Wellington, 18th & 19th November, 2025, 1 or 2 Day Presentation Skills Workshop
Limited tickets available. Get in now so you don't miss out!
When effective presenters speak, they do more than inform - they influence, persuade, and inspire. That isn’t magic; it’s method. With the right tools, anyone can build genuine connection and move a room.
This workshop is for leaders, emerging leaders, technical specialists, and professionals who want practical tools and techniques for speaking in both formal and informal settings.
Short on time? Attend 1 Day (Foundations) for all the core skills. Ready for a bigger shift? Choose 2 Days (Advanced) for one on one coaching and deeper transformation. Pick what’s right for you.
You’ll leave with the tools to present more clearly, confidently, and with the influence your role demands. This is not just for the stage. You will use these skills everyday.
The workshop format
Small group format for maximum practice and feedback (no massive groups).
Learning is adapted and personalised for maximum value (no cookie-cutter approach).
Hands on, practical learning, with easy to apply tools and techniques (no sitting around listening to theory).
The Effective Speaker - One Day Workshop (Foundations):
A hands-on day where you’ll learn our step-by-step SpeakerMap™ system to plan valuable presentations quickly and with ease.
You’ll learn the principles behind useful visuals, how to manage nerves, and three delivery techniques you can use immediately.
Foundations is best for technical experts who know their stuff but struggle to get it across, and nervous presenters who want a safe, practical reset.
What you’ll learn
Plan engaging content (fast)
Use the SpeakerMap™ to develop a clear Key Message and structure that keeps audiences attentive without overload.
Plan faster, make better decisions about what to include (and what to ditch).
 Design useful slides (not wallpaper)
A simple but revolutionary way to design slides that support — not sabotage — your message.
Practical guidance on using AI to fast-track draft slides and create supporting documents.
How to use PowerPoint to keep you on track without putting your audience to sleep.
 Keep nerves under control
A proven psychological approach to calm the mental chatter that causes waffling, speed talking, and blank moments.
Build a personal plan to shift focus from “me” to the audience and the outcome you want.
 Deliver in a natural, engaging way
Three delivery techniques that help you look credible, be engaging and feel confident.
How to vary pace and emphasis so your key points actually land.
How to cut the filler - the “ums” and “ahs” - and keep your flow.
 Plenty of practice
You’ll practise each technique in pairs or threes — supportive, safe, and highly practical.
Includes
A full day of training
All food and drinks during the workshop
The Effective Speaker workbook
30minute one on one follow up session
Investment: $1,200 + GST (Early Bird Pricing $995+GST)
 
What past participants say:
"By far the best course i have attended in any organisation, either here in NZ or abroad. The format of the course was engaging and there was a great balance between listening, engaging and participating. I look forward to using the skills used presenting at our next Team Hui!"
Matthew Townsley, Medical Council of New Zealand


"Really great course, no pressure environment with a good mix of interactive and book work. Have walked away feeling more confident in how I am going to put my presentations together."

Jessica Stokes, Emergency Management Team, New Plymouth District Council
"It was good, practical and useful tools "not rules" for business comms and pressos. Good to learn some of the other things you don't often learn in traditional presentation skills training. Really good engagement and interaction - the team were impressed we were all engaged right until the end! Easily one of the best courses I have been on in this line of work. Keep up the good work! "
Brad Stansell, Channel Account Manager, Pax 8
The Effective Speaker - Two Day Workshop (Advanced)
Gain all the skills from Day One - and then take them further. If presenting is central to your career growth, this is the coaching workshop you need.
Over two full days, you’ll create a significant shift in your communication skills.
Day One gives you the foundations to make presenting easier and more effective.
Day Two consolidates and extends these skills. You’ll go deeper into content planning, adapt the tools to your real work presentations, and get personalised coaching to develop your own authentic style.
You’ll also learn strategies for handling even the toughest audiences. The workshop is practical, hands-on, and focused on learning by doing - presenting, receiving coaching, and observing your peers.
If you’re ready for lasting, transformative change in your communication skills, the two-day option is the best choice.
What you’ll learn
Everything from Day 1 (Foundations) PLUS
Go deeper with planning
Apply the SpeakerMap to plan an actual presentation that you can give. 
Dive deeper into crafting valuable messages that you can use in the future. 
Rehearse in a way that actually works
A practical way to prepare when time is tight — so you own your words.
Shift from competent to compelling
One-on-one coaching targeted to your specific needs.
Video feedback plus our inside-out coaching methodology to reconnect you with the techniques you use naturally in conversation.
How to use silence, pace, notes, and the remote without looking stiff or artificial.
How to speak with energy and authenticity, not speed and panic.
Eliminate “ums” and “ahs”, look confident (even when you’re not), and create a sense of commitment that audiences feel.
An understanding of your personal communication strengths and the areas you need to focus on for growth.

Handle audiences like a pro
Strategies for side chats, interruptions, distractions, disagreement, and the odd angry voice - while staying calm and in control.

Includes
Everything in Day 1, plus:
A second full day of training
All food and drinks during the workshop
Videos of your presenting and coaching sessions
The Effective Speaker workbook
60minute one on one follow up session
Investment: $2,500 + GST (Early Bird Pricing $2.200+GST)
What past participants say:

"The overall experience of the course far surpassed my expectations. I came in hoping to gain some valuable insights and tips for better public speaking, but what I received was so much more. I developed a newfound confidence in my ability to communicate effectively, learned how to captivate an audience, and discovered strategies for managing nerves and overcoming stage fright. I would recommend this effective speaking course to anyone looking to enhance their communication abilities. It's not just another course; it's a transformative experience that will empower you to become a more confident and persuasive speaker" Alex Goryachev, New Zealand Green Building Council
“This course not only met my expectations, but it completely exceeded them. This has been one of the most transformative courses I’ve attended. Jane totally revolutionised the way I now approach presentations. Having felt fear in the past each time I have to present to large groups, for the first time I now feel like I have the tools, understanding and ability to approach presentations and conquer my fear. I can’t thank Jane enough.” Nadia Marsh, Head of Bids, Tonkin & Taylor
"I have never been in such a well-run course (I've done a lot) Jane was amazing she held our attention from start to finish each day. I feel we all learnt so much and I will definitely be taking her advice on how I can improve myself. This course was well above what I expected, Jane had a great way of communicating. Typically, people tune out or lose interest by the end of the day. This was not the case for us. I honestly thing it’s the best course I’ve been on in my 4 years with WCC." Joshua Harding, Team Leader Consents, Wellington City Council

“The course is awesome. The balance between talk time, practical learning and feedback is perfect. The trainer really made the course for me - she is sensitive and responsive to people’s needs and is genuine in her approach to give the learners as much out of the time as possible. A very polished and well-planned course.” Huia Grey, Department of Conservation

description:
October Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

Embody Your Flow - Reconnect to the wisdom of your menstrual cycle, Embody Your Flow - Reconnect to the wisdom of your menstrual cycle
Explore how to recognise your body’s rhythms, needs and strengths throughout your menstrual cycle, and discover supportive practices grounded in somatic and embodied awareness.

Attuning to the wisdom of the menstrual cycle offers a meaningful way to honour your natural rhythms, nurturing ease, creativity, and deeper connection.

This course is trauma-informed and inclusive. No prior somatics experience is necessary, and all who menstruate are welcome.

****************
Bookings:
https://www.trybooking.com/nz/events/landing/16754?embed

Or email

Ticket prices range from $50-$75. If finance is a barrier please reach out.

****************
Amy Richards is a yoga teacher based in Pōneke, with a Certificate in MindBody Therapy. She is drawn to the ways intentional movement and embodied awareness can shape our inner experience and relationships. Grounded in a trauma-informed approach, her work invites exploration of connection with sensation and emotion through the body.

Her practice is influenced by Tantric Shaivism, contact improvisation, Open Floor dance, Hakomi somatic psychotherapy, Somatic Experiencing, Authentic Relating, and Nonviolent Communication.

description:
This Wasn't The Plan: A Musical Theatre Cabaret, This Wasn't The Plan: A Musical Theatre Cabaret
This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse. Please take your seats in this cabaret classroom as lecturer, acclaimed musical theatre performer Glenn Horsfall, takes you through the twists and turns of a life imagined versus a reality lived. Glenn lays bare his journey of self-discovery, from the highs of childhood fame to the lows of bullying and self-doubt. With beautiful songs and hilarious, heartfelt, humbling stories, this show looks at what it means when the script of life gets rewritten. This Wasn’t The Plan picked up the Auckland Fringe Tour Ready Award and Outstanding Solo Performance Award at NZ Fringe 2025. It’s a must-see for anyone navigating change or questioning societal expectations.

“Masterclass in storytelling” - The Post

Tickets from https://www.tahifestivalnz.com/this-wasnt-the-plan

Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women’s lives in early Wellington.

Booking info here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/our-fair-ladies-tour/


Health & Safety:
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.

While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.

Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
Pacific Peoples and the Underclass of Aotearoa New Zealand: Repositioning the Narrative, In 2018, over 380,000 people in Aotearoa New Zealand identified with at least one Pacific ethnicity. Despite being a youthful and growing community, Pacific peoples are statistically entrenched in a cycle of disadvantage that cannot be ignored.
In almost every measure—health, education, income, home ownership, and justice—Pacific people are overrepresented in poor outcomes.
We are not just facing a Pacific problem; we are looking at the face of New Zealand’s underclass—systemic, intergenerational, and largely invisible in mainstream policy conversations. Despite progress for some groups, the Pacific population remains on the wrong side of the statistical ledger.
Pacific peoples experience:
• The highest rates of avoidable hospitalisations and chronic conditions.
• Worst material deprivation across nearly every indicator.
• Persistently low home ownership rates.
• A widening education achievement gap, often masked by ethnic averages.
• Underrepresentation in decision-making, leadership, and governance roles.
While initiatives for Māori advancement are critical and must continue, Pacific peoples require their own distinct policy lens. A “one-size-fits-all” approach under a pan-ethnic umbrella risks making the Pacific experience invisible.

Te Kāhui Tika Tangata Human Rights Commission is proud to host this discussion for International Day of Older Persons in partnership with Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa (formerly LAGANZ).

Panelists from the Wellington rainbow community - 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗶 𝗠𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗹, 𝗞𝗲𝘃𝗶𝗻 𝗛𝗮𝘂𝗻𝘂𝗶 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗟𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘆 𝗖𝗼𝘄𝗮𝗻 - will join Chief Commissioner Dr Stephen Rainbow for the discussion and a brief Q and A session. 🌈🎙️💫

Prudence Walker, Disability Rights Commissioner and Rainbow rights spokesperson will host the panel.

𝗣𝗿𝗲-𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗱𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴. Pre-register here: https://events.humanitix.com/rainbow-elders-our-aspirations-our-well-being-our-rights-a-panel-discussion 🎟️🎟️🎟️

The discussion runs from 10.30am to 11.30am.

NZSL will be available. The venue is accessible.

Light refreshments will be available.

A recording of the discussion may be made available afterwards via the Commission's website.
❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🩷

description:
George Fenn is: Sexy Ghost Boy, Sexy Ghost Boy is a wordless interactive comedy that came from the challenge to make work exploring consent without using words. Thematically this show is a celebration of the micro-neurosis and little rituals we have around sex and appearing sexy. It is an uplifting and exciting show, which is satirical in its burlesque and invigorating through its clown. It is very, very funny.
The performer’s approach to interaction and participation is gentle, with a focus on ensuring the audience is enthusiastic consenting to each action. George Fenn is an interactive theatre comedian with decade of experience. This is not an experimental show. This is a weird show. A very good, weird show.

Official and unofficial praise Sexy Ghost Boy:
Organised Chaos Award at Auckland Fringe / 2024
Bizarre and Charming Award / Hasting Fringe Festival 2024
Nominated for Outstanding Performer / Dunedin Fringe 2025
“A theatrical alchemist, Fenn has the rare talent to create something utterly ridiculous yet very clever…he worms his way into our brains making it crazy, yet safe. There’s an element of consent in the interaction that is miles away from the experience of sitting in the front row of some stand-ups.” - Rosheen Fitzgerald, Theatreview
"but we both feel so… I don’t even know how to describe it. I feel like I’m floating while simultaneously feeling grounded, I’m ecstatic while also very chill. Maybe it’s the full moon, or maybe I’m just a little bit possessed by the Sexy Ghost Boy." - Laura Ferguson, Art Murmurs
"... Like Mr. Bean, but Sexy." - Audience member
"What the **** that was incredible." - Audience member
The show is strictly R18. It contains sexual themes and nudity up to underwear.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
