description:
Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms, Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms
Our native riparian plantings from 2023 have really started to thrive this winter, visible as you drive past the farm, or walking the local farm trail loop.

These native seedlings planted alongside the river, act like living sponges, slowing any farm runoff, filtering nutrients, anchoring soil and shading the water so that beneficial invertebrates & life forms can thrive. Creating cleaner water, richer habitat and less flooding downstream.

Keen to get involved? We have a few tree planting events coming up this season:

🌳 TREE PLANTING DAYS
- Sat 16th Aug 10am - 3pm
- Sat 6th Sep 10am - 3pm with @forestandbirdwellington

EVENT DETAILS
- Meet at 10am, 298 Whitemans Valley Road, Upper Hutt.
- We will walk 5-10mins to our planting site near te Awa o Mangaroa / the Mangaroa river.
- Come for a short time, or a long time, and join us for a kai and refreshments at 2pm after the mahi is complete.

BRING WITH YOU
- A Jacket and warm clothes - be prepared for a range of weather
- Boots or stout shoes
- Gloves - if you have them
- A spade if you have one
- Water bottle

Register at https://store.mangaroa.org/collections/events

#treeplanting #mangaroafarms #riparianplanting #nativetrees #volunteer #alwaysbeplanting

description:
Renaissance Gold - in celebration with Manawatū Sinfonia featuring Bach's Magnificat, Renaissance Gold - in celebration with Manawatū Sinfonia featuring Bach's Magnificat
On Saturday 13 September, at 7.00 pm in the Cathedral of the Holy Spirit on Broadway, PN, the choir under Christine Archer-Lockwood is to be joined by the Manawatu Sinfonia and soloists, Caroline Hickman, Jennifer Little and Lindsay Yeo with choristers Nigel Tongs and Bronté Hodgetts also singing solo in Bach's Magnificat. The Magnificat is a world favourite, arguably Bach's best choral piece that has transcended the ages, celebrating Luke's description of Mary's pregnancy.

In addition, the choir and orchestra perform Ritchie's Then I Understood. When a child of seven to nine, Laura Rangers sketched eight poems centred on summers at Otaki Beach, Ritchie seized the opportunity to add the musical dimension and the result are dual choirs - the Renaissance Singers split - accompanied by the Sinfonia to set off Rangers' delightful insights, so elegantly displayed. The magic that can be childhood.

The concert has a celebratory theme, it being the 50th anniversary of the choir. Thus the inclusion of Forrest's Three Nocturnes that express the wonderment involved when examining the heavens and the universe full of stars. Throughout this piece the percussionists alone from the Sinfonia provide whimsical accompaniment with a celeste providing the heavenly tones - a hit when played on the last occasion the choir sang the piece.

Opening the concert will be Carl Orff's O Fortuna from his popular Carmina Burana. While O Fortuna laments the role of fate it is set in the larger piece that celebrates life with gusto.

With the performers in great form (two choristers just back from singing with the world's best choir) this concert will no doubt build the sense of celebration - full of life and wonderment.

General Admission $25, Concession $20, Secondary School $15,
Under 13 Free.

description:
Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!

description:
Wellington Walk the Waterfront, Wellington Walk the Waterfront
Top Up Together

As part of Mental Health Awareness Week’s Be Active day, the Aotearoa Mental Health Collective invites you to join us for an evening of movement, connection and community.
We’ll gather at The Lounge at St John's Bar, Wellington from 5.30 pm for a warm welcome and a chance to connect. Then at 6 pm we'll take a walk along the beautiful Wellington waterfront, returning to The Lounge at St John's around 6.45 pm.
After the walk, you’ll have the opportunity to share a meal or snacks of your choice, deepen connections, and continue the conversation in a relaxed setting. As this is a free event, you’ll order and pay for any food and drinks yourself and can choose from the wide range on offer at St John's Bar.
Walking alongside others and taking the time to connect can boost our wellbeing, reduce stress, lift our mood and strengthen our sense of belonging.
Spaces are limited, so secure your spot today.
We look forward to connecting, walking and topping up our wellbeing together this Mental Health Awareness week.

With thanks to St John's Bar, who have generously provided the venue for this free event.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Portrait Play: Natural Light Photography Workshop with Sony Scene, Practice and learn how to pose and photograph people
Learn, practice and play with portrait photography!
Curious about portraits but not sure where to start? This welcoming workshop is designed especially for beginners who want to build confidence behind the camera in a relaxed, supportive setting.
With Wellington portrait photographer Rebecca McMillan as your guide, you’ll explore how to capture people using just the light around you. No flash or fancy lighting required. Our slightly spooky late-October theme adds a fun twist, and with a professional model to work with, you’ll get plenty of chances to practice both taking photos and gently directing your subject.
Over two and a half hours, Rebecca will share how she approaches a scene, engages with her subject, and makes the most of natural light in an outdoor city location. You'll then have plenty of time to practice photography and directing our model. You’ll leave with new skills, a boost of confidence, and portraits you’ll be proud of.
The workshop is an outdoor session in a central Wellington location. Location details will be communicated to registered attendees.
Register at Sony Scene: all camera brands welcome!

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .

description:
Teaching Well - Supportive schools for a well staff - Wellington (TWS2025/04), With the growing emphasis on staff wellbeing there is a plethora of workplace mental wellbeing programmes on offer. However what is meant by staff wellbeing is not often clearly defined, with many programmes focusing on work related 'stressors' for staff or using staff wellness approach.  
As part of a well school, it is just essential to have a well staff as it is to a well student body. Take the opportunity to learn the underlying principles of wellbeing that inform a sustainable and impactful staff wellbeing plan.  
Designed specifically for the school context, the workshop examines the theory and the practice of promoting wellbeing through the lens of of being part of a school staff in 2025.
From Remedial to Sustainable Action
Equipping individual staff members skills or resources to cope more effectively with the stressful or distressing aspects of their jobs or providing an employee assistance programme is only one aspect of a comprehensive staff wellbeing plan. It is common for schools to start their development of their plan at the remedial end of the wellbeing continuum. Consequently the plan developed is more a welfare / wellness plan. Learn the difference between welfare, wellness and wellbeing approaches and the strengths and weaknesses of each approach. 

Meta-evaluations of workplace mental wellbeing programmes indicate that there is little evidence around the efficacy of many workplace wellbeing programmes because they do not address the organisational and systemic factors that act as either enablers of or obstacles to wellbeing. Just as it is recognised that supportive environments are foundational to wellbeing of students, so is it also for a well staff. An effective staff wellbeing programmes responds to the needs of the staff and reflects the cultural make-up of the staff, the values and character of the school. 
Drawing on collective impact and transformational change theory and Te Whare Tapa Whā, a conceptual model will be introduced that outlines the eight pou on which a staff wellbeing plan should be based. The strength of this model is that it settings or occupation specific. It requires a depth analysis of the nature, dynamics and demands of the work and the inter-relationships that occur in the work
Building of the learnings from previous workshops and feedback from participants, the workshop now offers a template to guide the development of a staff wellbeing plan
If you are wanting a workshop that will give you a pre-packaged wellbeing programme, then this workshop is not for you. Countless evaluations have shown the limited efficacy of wellbeing programmes that are "inserted" into a school. A staff wellbeing plan must grounded in and responsive to the learnings made out of the reflective analysis and staff consultation stages. In fact, the staff consultation is, in itself, is a wellbeing activity.
Take the opportunity to hear from an award winning wellbeing specialist about:
the wellbeing continuum and the difference between mental illness prevention and wellbeing approaches
the key determinants that impact on staff wellbeing
effective strategies to respond to fatigue, burnout, depression and trauma
why one size doesn't fit all and how to scope and design a staff wellbeing programme responsive to the specific needs of your school
developing a staff wellbeing programme based on proven wellbeing outcomes
making informed decisions on your school’s staff wellbeing policy and activities
Workshop Format:
The content will be delivered over two workshops.
In-Person 1 day workshop in Wellington
Friday 31 October 9am to 4pm
On-Line Workshop
Wednesday 3 December 1 - 3.30pm

Topics covered in this practical workshop:
what is meant by wellbeing and its role in addressing stress and mental distress in staff;
the difference between a welfare and a wellbeing approach;
staff wellbeing as an industrial relations / conditions of employment issue
resilience, coping, thriving? - identifying desired wellbeing outcomes
the interface between personal and professional stressors and distressors
the impact on staff wellbeing from exposure to trauma and poor mental wellbeing within the student body
the key determinants that facilitate wellbeing in the teaching environment
what does and what doesn’t contribute to a supportive environment where staff thrive
the key components that should be in a staff wellbeing programme
designing, implementing and evaluating a staff wellbeing programme
School Group Participation
Schools are encouraged to have more than one staff member participate in the online workshops. Past workshops has shown that having more than one staff member has maximised the benefit of the workshop activities which can then been continued post-workshop. To promote school group participation, there is a 30% discount off the total registration fee when three or more participants per school are registered.
Who should attend: 
Senior leadership team members (especially those with responsibility of staff wellbeing)
OHS representatives or union delegates
Heads of Departments
Boards of Trustees representatives
School Counsellors / EAP providers
In-House Delivery:
This workshop can also be delivered in-house, school clusters, or organisations such as prinicpal assocations or unions. Post workshop consulting services such as mentoring the development of or reviewing a staff wellbeing plan can also be provided.
Post Workshop Consult:
Schools and Kuras have the option of a 90 minute consult with Barry in 2026 to review their staff wellbeing plan.
Barry has worked in mental wellbeing promotion and suicide prevention/postvention for 36 years at the local, national and international levels.  His extensive experience includes sitting on state and national government advisory committees; designing, implementing and evaluating suicide prevention programs; writing suicide prevention guidelines, training packages and community resources; providing technical advice to community based and national mental wellbeing and suicide prevention programs. 
He has led multiple ‘firsts’ in mental wellbeing both in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.  In recognition of his outstanding contribution to mental wellbeing and suicide prevention, he was awarded in 2016 the NSW Mental Health Commissioner's Community Champion Award.  He currently sits on the Health and Disability Ethics Committee.
Barry has lectured on wellbeing both nationally and internationally and been appointed to numerous government advisory committees on mental wellbeing and suicide prevention.  He brings to this workshop extensive experience in advising communities and government on post-disaster recovery in terms of both mental wellbeing promotion / community resiliency and suicide prevention. He wrote the first national guidelines for suicide prevention in Australian schools and undertook a review of the NZ guidelines.
As a Health Sociologist and Public Health practitioner, Barry has a long-term interest in the social and cultural determinants of wellbeing, especially the role of gender and he brings a wealth of knowledge and passion for promoting wellbeing in men. He has examined the impact of discrimination, internalised stigma, social exclusion or inclusion on mental wellbeing along with the role of human rights as an enabler of wellbeing.
He embraces a holistic understanding of wellbeing and has an interest in the role spirituality and ecology contributes to a person's wellbeing. He uses a population health and systems change approach, drawing on transformational change theory and collective impact.
After a number of years overseas, Barry is living back in New Zealand and is passionate about building the knowledge base, competence and capability within our country to promote well whānau, workplaces and communities and for the incorporation of wellbeing principles in public policy and social outcomes such as education, training and employment.
WORKSHOP DETAILS
WORKSHOP PLACES ARE LIMITED. REGISTER EARLY TO AVOID DISAPPOINTMENT
Places in the workshop are limited. If the workshop is full please register your name on the waitlist
Group Booking Discount: Book 3 or more participants in one booking and receive 30% discount off each registration
School & Kura Discount: Enter SCHOOLKURA20 to the Discount Code box at the beginning of the registration process for a further 20% discount off the registration fee.
Payment: Payment is by either:
Credit Card (Visa or Mastercard) or 
Instalment payment (ZIP and Afterpay)
Invoice - Schools and kura have the option to pay by invoice. At payment method click on Invoice,
Terms for Payment By Invoice
By selecting to pay by invoice the organisation agrees to the following conditions:
1.  Your place in the workshop is not confirmed until payment has been received. Payment of the invoice must be made within seven days of registering to avoid having your registration cancelled. Late payment fees apply.
2.  A Tax Invoice from TaylorMade Training and Consulting will be sent to you separately which will contain bank details for payment.  
3.  By registering for the workshop, you agree to the cancellation and policy. (refer below).  Organisations who cancel within seven days of the workshop and have not paid the invoice for the outstanding registration fee are still obligated to pay the outstanding debt.

Cancellation and Refund Policy
Workshops can fill quickly. If you are no longer able to attend the workshop please cancel your registration as soon as possible. The following refund policy is strictly adhered to.
Cancellation up to seven days prior to the commencement of the workshop:  Full Refund less $35+GST admin fee
Cancellation within seven days prior to the commencement of the workshop: No refund but registration can be transferred to another person. To transfer your registration log on to your registration and update the name and contact details to the new person attending.
Non attendance:   No refund
Disclaimer: The information and professional advice delivered in the workshop and the associated printed material is provided solely on the basis that before relying on this material, participants should obtain appropriate advice relevant to their particular circumstance to evaluate its accuracy, currency, completeness and relevance for their purposes. TaylorMade Training and Consulting will not be liable for any damages of any kind to any person or entity arising from the use of this information. Your attendance at this workshop reflects your acceptance of this statement.

description:
Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days, Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days
This workshop is ideal for advanced students who have already learned how to set cabochon stones. Over two three-hour sessions, 20 and 27 September, 10am-1pm, you will be given an understanding of the technique of setting faceted stones using a setting burr, hammers, punches and burnishing tools. This is the first step in learning to flush set facet cut stones so they sit below the surface of the metal.

Session 1 will cover the technique, demonstrations and the basics of preparing and cutting the setting. Students will be shown how to set their stones, and may begin to do this in class, but will then go on to repeat and practice the technique in their own time.
They can do this at home, or for a small extra cost, can stay on at the studio to practice setting for the afternoon.

Session 2 will pick up on the setting techniques, reminding and refining essential steps in the process. Troubleshooting can be covered in this class, as well as learning to clean up the settings. The principles of this setting technique will be covered in a few different scenarios, as some students may wish to take this skill into different styles or directions.

The option for students to have a half-day bench hire after class will also apply to this session.

What is provided: class fees cover your practice metal (copper) and stones (CZ) and detailed handouts that are useful for you to take away to refer to when practising and honing your skills.

Correctly sized drills and setting burrs will be provided in class, but students must purchase their own burrs for practice after class and any future bench hires. These are available for purchase in the studio.

What to bring: Advanced students can bring projects to set stones into, but please note the metal must be at least 2mm thick and we do not allow brass to be used as a project or practice for beginners. The metal must be copper or sterling silver.

Students should bring either a craft magnifier or magnifying lenses/glasses. If you have your own flex shaft tool you plan to use at home for drilling and setting, please also bring this along so that your tutor can advise on the best way to use it. We have two drilling machines in the studio, and these must be shared between the students, so if you have a machine, do bring it.

Practice bench hire after class $20 per person (till 4pm) must be booked in advance.

Workshop fee $195, Early bird $175 till 24 August.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures, Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures
📅 Wednesday, 1 October 2025
🕔 5:00–7:30 PM (Networking from 5:00 PM | Panels 5:30–7:30 PM)
📍 Te Aro Campus, Faculty of Architecture and Design Innovation, Victoria University of Wellington (139 Vivian Street)
The built environment is at the heart of Aotearoa’s response to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs). The way we plan, design, and construct our cities influences how we live — and how we tackle challenges such as climate change (SDG 13), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), affordable housing and equity (SDG 10),
responsible consumption and production (SDG 12), and partnerships for action (SDG 17).
This event is part of SDG Action Month 2025, a global campaign that highlights how communities, institutions, and industries are accelerating progress toward the 2030 Agenda.
For Aotearoa, the conversation is urgent: how can planning, design, and construction shape a sustainable, equitable, and climate-resilient future?
The evening will open with a keynote address that sets the stage with global perspectives on sustainability and the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs.
Two panels will then explore critical themes:
• Planning + Place + People — equity, housing futures, cultural identity, indigenous leadership, and policy alignment.
• Materials + Methods + Innovation—construction technology, green standards, digital tools, and carbon-conscious practice.
Alongside the discussions, attendees can view a Student Showcase from the School of Architecture and the School of Design Innovation, and contribute to a Blueprint Wall by writing their own pledges on SDG Commitment Cards, ensuring the event concludes with collective action as well as ideas.
📌 Free to attend | Open to all | RSVP required

description:
Wellington Maritime Sail Heritage Exhibition, Wellington Maritime Sail Heritage Exhibition
Petone's seaside art & gift gallery will host an art exhibition of Wellington’s rich maritime sail history including Pamir, Bolton, Huia, Echo & settler ships

The exhibition will feature oil paintings and prints by guest artist, Paul Deacon from Nelson.

Paul is a world renown marine artist particularly well known for his skill and knowledge of sailing ships and has especially painted some magnificent new paintings for this exhibition. Included will be paintings of some of Wellington’s favourite sailing ships as well as a selection of first settler ships and later immigrant ships.

Gallery owner, Alfred Memelink, will also exhibit a selection of watercolours and prints alongside Paul's masterpieces.


Gallery Opening Hours during the festival are Tuesday to Sunday 10.30am - 4pm
Cost: Free
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/wellington-maritime-sail-heritage-exhibition/


Health & Safety:
Please contact the event host for health & safety information.

description:
Family event: Explore Omnibirding with Giselle Clarkson, We are thrilled and delighted to announce we are going to be hosting a fabulous school holiday event with the multi-award winning Giselle Clarkson to celebrate the release of her latest book Omnibird: An Avian Investigator’s Handbook, a guide to the art and science of omnibirding.
Giselle Clarkson, the author of The Observologist, will be in Tawa for this very special event to explore the inner workings of the book and delights and wonders of the avian world.
Some birds are so commonplace it’s easy to forget how extraordinary they are. These creatures have a secret eyelid, hollow bones and a two-part brain. They dress in feathers. Omnibird, explores what’s remarkable about the birds all around us and the clues we can all use to become avian investigators.
Giselle is an author, illustrator and cartoonist based in Greytown, known for her work on conservation and environmental topics. She has illustrated award-winning picture books and nonfiction and is a 2023 Arts Foundation Laureate, receiving the prestigious Mallinson Rendel Illustrators Award.
This promises to be an unmissable event for bird and nature lovers of any age.
Books for sale thanks to the Children's Bookshop.
We wish to extend our thanks to Gecko Press for helping make this event happen.
This is a free event.
We expect this event to be very popular so to secure your seat early arrival is suggested.
label: Family Friendly

description:
The Check-in Men's Group Tuesday 23 Sept, To join this community, and book your Tuesdays - please sign up here first, and we will email you the event access code. (our venue address will be emailed with your ticket).

This is a space for men to talk honestly, listen deeply, and figure some things out together. It’s not about having it all sorted. You don’t need to be a certain type of guy. Just show up as you are, with no pressure to speak or share.
Open group: new faces are welcome
Flexible: book to come when it suits you. Each Tuesday is a new event. Most will try for fortnightly.
Small groups: 8 men + 2 experienced hosts
Inclusive: all ages, backgrounds and identities (18+)
It's about connection and showing up, instead of going it alone. It makes time for meeting our various challenges, while learning and growing us into better friends, partners, dads, sons and humans. 
It isn’t a boys or bros club, therapy or a self-help seminar, religious or new-age. No fixing, preaching, or pressure. It’s not a crisis service or a substitute for professional care. The sign-up form explains this in more detail.
You can expect to:
Practice listening and learn communication skills for life
Discover greater integrity and self-accountability
Be supported in building your emotional intelligence
Become a part of a hearty and diverse community
Have a good time - it’s often uplifting and inspiring.
Joseph and your team of hosts have all been in regular men's groups for many years. The group sometimes offers simple proven inquiries that draw on NVC, MBSR, active listening, gratitude and more.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Intro to 2D Traditional Animation - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, This is a beginners course in 2D animation where tweens & teens will learn the time-honoured principles of hand-drawn animation and how to apply them to your own animation project. You may work on a project incorporating your own ideas, or if you'd rather, an assigned a project from your tutor.

You can use any device, ipad or laptop you already own (except a mobile – it's really not big enough to do good animation on). The school does not provide any digital equipment.

Your tutor, Ross Payne, is a 30 year veteran of traditional 2D animation, and loves to share his knowledge about it for you to love it as much as he does.

In each lesson there will be examples and demonstrations of the animation principles with follow up exercises to put your new skills into practice. You'll work on your project both during class and at home, applying the animation principles to your individualised project.

You can choose to draw your animation on paper then scan/capture into your device, or choose to draw your animation digitally, directly into an animation programme. which ever you choose, instructions in class will be provided to give you the skills needed for this step.

Bring a water bottle and snack for morning tea.

This workshop is for ages 10 and above. Tuesday - Friday, 30 September - 3 October, 10 am - 1 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, pottery and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Hatch Showcase, Fresh voices, bold stories. HATCH puts emerging talent in the spotlight!

TAHI Festival’s student showcase, HATCH, champions our next generation of solo performers. In partnership with Te Auaha, Toi Whakaari: NZ Drama School, and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, HATCH supports students through workshops, mentorship, and creative development, culminating in a high-energy showcase at BATS Theatre. Show info below.

Cursed Child: The return of Mr Haki
Written and performed by Leia Edmonds
Mr Haki is Leia’s childhood imaginary friend. He returns from the grave to confront her about his death. Cursed Child: The return of Mr Haki is a funny, slightly creepy, and nostalgic tale about the mind of a strange little girl. Contains mental health themes, and depictions of injury or medical distress.

HĀNGĪ PANTS
Written and performed by Waikamania Seve
It's 9:04pm, a Saturday like any other. Scandaleyes smeared on, soju burning sweet, cherry pomegranate nicotine clouding the air. K Road’s about to come alive, but Hāngī Pants is already unpacking the mess. Her lovers, her losses, her lust. Contains flashing lights, course language, themes of sexual assault, substance abuse, and eating disorders; and depictions of sex and semi-nudity.

Warm Night At Normal School
Written and performed by Gabriel Murphy
Gabriel missions across the sticky floors and strobe lights of the school disco to ask the girl he likes to dance with him. But it’s not as easy as it sounds. Recommended for audiences aged 13+. Contains flashing lights and some coarse language.

Enter: Child
Written and performed by Aroha Morrison
Wide-eyed, happy to be there, and - well - utterly clueless. Child leads with curiosity - will you follow?

Lost Memory
Written and performed by George Long
A man is trying to tell the story of meeting someone really important. But unfortunately life changes over time.

Show title to come
Written and performed by Charlie Roigard.
Show info to come.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Karori Christmas Merry Pop-ins, Falalalala!
Christmas is on the way and we like to get our festive on nice and early at Pop-ins so we can fit in all of our little elves and snowmen.
Merry Pop-in events are online now and booking up quick!
We specialise in merry, bright and beautiful NATURAL SMILES

Capture your child's joy in the Pop-ins chair, just like Monthly’s only Christmassy. Our iconic backdrop returns every year so you can collect portraits of your child growing from Christmas to Christmas.

Every registered participant who attends the photo walk goes into the Scene Festival draw to win a trip to Rome!

Paekākāriki Pride Parade, Dress in your brightest colours, bring musical instruments, your dog, your friends and whanau and make some noise for the world-famous-in-Paekākāriki Pride Parade!
Assemble at 2.30pm on the sports field at Campbell Park on The Parade.

The Parade leaves Campbell Park at 3pm sharp. We'll finish up at the usual destination of St Peter's Village Hall where we'll cut the ribbon, walk across the crossing and declare it the World's Shortest Pride Parade, and celebrate eight years of Pride in the friendliest little village in the world.

Show your pride, solidarity, respect and love for and with your rainbow whanau.

This 1.5-hour experience is full of sparkly fun, gentle storytelling and a sprinkle of mischief — with fizzy surprises, sweet smells, and lots of giggles.

description:
Meet the Characters: Kiwi's Big Hararei, These school holidays Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne will become the playground of a host of incredible critters from the upcoming Circa Theatre children's show Kiwi's Big Hararei!

Brought to you by award-winning company Horse With No Name, this free "Meet the Characters" event features an amazing array of manu including kiwi, tūī, kārearea and tītīpounamu.

The cast of Kiwi's Big Hararei will wow tamariki with a sneak peek of their show, featuring original waiata by New Zealand singer songwriter Benny Tipene. They will also kōrero about the unique adaptations of these manu, and how we can all be kaitiaki of them.

Bring your tamariki along to engage with these colourful creatures, with stunning costume design by GRIDLEY by Victoria. Musical performance, native biodiversity and interactive theatre combine on the Heritage Lawn for an afternoon of spring fun in the sun! The team of talented children’s entertainers from Horse With No Name are so excited to share a snippet of their show Kiwi's Big Hararei with you.

Kiwi's Big Hararei will be playing at Circa Theatre over the school holidays. For more information about the show, visit www.circa.co.nz

General admission fees to the sanctuary apply, free entry for members. Should the weather turn, this event will be held the foyer of the Visitor Centre on the ground floor. Overflow carparking is available at Birdwood Street during the busy school holiday period.

description:
Artistic Potential: Marine Reserves - A presentation/talk, A presentation and talk facilitated by Katy Cottrell, Matteo Collina and Alice Rogers.
Marine Reserves have obvious benefits to the environment, protecting species and providing underwater appeal to snorkelers and divers but a little realised benefit is what they can offer to artists of all mediums. Join artist Katy Cottrell as she chats with academic researcher Matteo Collina and director of the Victoria University Coastal Ecology Lab – Alice Rogers. Alice and Matteo will talk about their work with marine reserves from a scientific perspective and how this has inspired the artworks by Katy Cottrell and Rick Allender for their exhibition Taputeranga: Above and Below.

description:
Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop, Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop
Do you know a child who loves craft and making a splash? Join us for a fun family papermaking session!

We’ll be getting our hands wet as we explore the creative world of handmade paper using native harakeke (NZ flax) pulp. You will start off learning the simple skills of how to form a sheet of paper from wet pulp, then develop these skills by making different shapes and sizes, such as sheets, cards, envelopes, and ornaments. Express your own flair by experimenting with bits and pieces to add different colours and textures to your creations.

This workshop is designed for kids and accompanying adults to enjoy together. Adults are expected to assist hands-on and join the fun. Ages 5 and up.

description:
Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!, Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!
Wednesday 24 September 2025, 10am – 2pm
Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free
These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.
Activities include:
• Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
• Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
• Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
• Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.
Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!
We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!
label: Family Friendly

description:
Irish Cultural Festival, Irish Cultural Festival
Join the Fun at the Community Cultural Festival! 🍀

The Hutt Valley Irish Society invites you to a lively Community Cultural Festival filled with the heart and soul of Irish tradition—and plenty of fun for everyone.

🎶 Live Irish Music to get your toes tapping
💃 Traditional Irish Dance performances that will amaze and inspire
🏐 Irish Sports Demos—give Gaelic games a go!
🍞 Soda Bread Making—watch, learn, and taste! Have a go for koha!
🧒 Children's Activities—face painting, crafts, and games galore

Whether you've got Irish roots or just a love for good craic, there's something for all ages at this community celebration. Entry is free—bring your friends, family, and your dancing shoes!

Don't miss out—let's make it a day to remember!

description:
NO CIGAR - Under The Surface Tour | Wellington, NO CIGAR - Under The Surface Tour | Wellington
Eccles Entertainment Presents:

NO CIGAR - Under The Surface Tour

Fri 7 Nov | Meow Nui, Wellington
Sat 8 Nov | Ngaio Marsh Theatre, Christchurch
Fri 14 Nov | Powerstation, Auckland

Ticketing Presales: 12pm, Thu 19 June
General Public On Sale: 12pm, Mon 23 June

Tickets - www.nocigar.co.nz/pages/shows

-------------

Breakout Aotearoa five-piece NO CIGAR have announced a three-date tour across New Zealand this November, in celebration of their highly anticipated third studio album Under the Surface, due for release July 30th.

Since forming in 2019, NO CIGAR have built a fiercely loyal fanbase across Aotearoa and beyond, carving out a unique niche that blends elements of indie, surf, and alternative rock. Their upcoming album is crafted for the stage — shaped by the band’s dynamic chemistry and a deep connection with their audience.

NO CIGAR’s 2023 sophomore album The Great Escape spent more than 74 consecutive weeks on the NZ Top 20 Albums Chart and featured the breakout hit “Concubine,” voted the 10th best rock song of 2024 by listeners of The Rock FM.

Their past tours across NZ, Australia and the UK have consistently sold out, driven by a word-of-mouth buzz and a reputation for electric, unforgettable performances. This tour will host their biggest headline shows on home soil to date and are not to be missed!
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!, Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!
Wednesday 24 September 2025, 10am – 2pm
Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free
These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.
Activities include:
• Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
• Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
• Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
• Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.
Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!
We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!

description:
WOW Train VIP Experience ex Christchurch : SOLD OUT, Transcend the ordinary on a journey like no other, to a show like no other. This extraordinary experience brings you the Greatest Stages on Earth.

Departing Friday 26 September, 2025

Beginning in Christchurch or Kaikoura, you'll witness the unique landscapes of the pacific coastline aboard the Coastal Pacific WOW Train and Interislander Ferry. A very special service, full of all things WOW, you'll be treated to a VIP welcome, special WOW garment appearances with an accompanying commentary, a WOW goodie bag and full catering during your journey. In Wellington, you will continue your journey into extraordinary with a Gold ticket to see the 2025 World of WearableArt (WOW) Show. This is a WOW experience like no other!

You'll love this break
If you are looking for the ultimate WOW Show experience, then this is the ticket!

Indulge your senses with a unique WOW Train experience, journeying along the coastline and over the strait past marine habitats aboard the Coastal Pacific and Interislander. In Wellington, you will continue your journey into the extraordinary with the Gold ticket to see the World of WearableArt Show.

This magical 3-day experience is set to be one of the greatest journeys of all time!

Inclusions
A 'Gold' ticket for the WOW Show performance on Saturday 27 September and a WOW Show Programme
Exclusive WOW Train aboard the Coastal Pacific (where everyone on board will be going to WOW in Wellington!) and VIP Ferry journey on the Interislander on 26 September
Onboard WOW entertainment and a goodie bag
Morning tea, lunch, and afternoon tea aboard the train
2-nights accommodation including breakfast
Hotel transfer
Return flight with Air New Zealand

Read to Kurī, Join us and our doggy guests from Canine Friends Pet Therapy for Read to Kurī at the library. You can book a 15-minute session to sit with one of our friendly dogs and read your favourite book, or one you've found at the library.
Read to Kurī aims to help children improve their literacy, self-confidence, and self-esteem in a relaxed, non-judgemental environment. This programme is perfect for tamariki aged 5+ who would like to practice their reading skills while making a new canine friend at the library.
To book your session, please call the library on 04 477 6151, or email johnsonville.library@wcc.govt.nz with your preferred date and time.
Bookings are for 15 minutes only. After you have booked, library staff will be in contact informing you what time to arrive for your session.

‘Radicals’ film screening, Join us at the Library to watch the documentary ‘Radicals’ that tracks the evolution of modern Māori political activism — from young members of Ngā Tamatoa in the 1970s to the actions of Te Kawariki at Waitangi Treaty Grounds in 1995. The screening will be introduced by the Director of ActionStation, Kassie Hartendorp.

Photo ‘Scenes at Waitangi during the Waitangi Day protests’, 1982, by Ans Westra. Courtesy of Suite Tirohanga. Ref: PA-Group-00941 Alexander Turnbull Library.

description:
Due Isole, Join Chef Giulio Ricatti for an extraordinary evening celebrating the bond between two islands — Sardinia and New Zealand. Through a carefully curated nine-course dinner, this event offers a personal and heartfelt exploration of identity, place, and the connection between land and sea.

Raised in Sardinia and now at home in New Zealand, Chef Ricatti shares his story through a menu that bridges the wild, untouched landscapes of both countries. Each course is crafted exclusively with New Zealand ingredients, reflecting the rich bounty of our land and sea, yet inspired by the timeless traditions and bold flavours of Sardinian cuisine.

Accompanying the meal is an expertly selected pairing of wines from Sardinia and New Zealand, highlighting the unique characteristics of each region while celebrating their shared essence. The thoughtful combination of food and drink creates a dialogue between the two islands, offering diners a chance to taste the harmony of contrasts.

More than just a meal, this is an evening of storytelling. Chef Ricatti invites you to journey with him as he reflects on the places that have shaped his life and the meaning of finding a home across oceans. His philosophy of embracing the present moment is woven into every dish, making this event a sensory and emotional experience.

Whether you’re a lover of fine dining, an admirer of Sardinian culture, or simply curious about the connections between food and identity, this dinner promises a night of discovery. Step into the heart of two islands and savour their soul in one unforgettable evening.

description:
Science Bites School Holidays Science Workshops, Get hands-on with some tasty, edible science these school holidays! Science Bites is an edible science workshop for tamariki aged 8-12 years old.

Learn about rainbow diffraction chocolate, make your own gummy worms, explore some glow-in-the-dark jelly, and more! All the projects in this workshop are safe to eat, meaning kids can taste their creations as they learn.

Tamariki will be excited to come home and share their new understanding of how science can be found in our everyday lives, even our kitchens!

Workshops include a complimentary planetarium show.

Tamariki can be dropped-off in the morning and picked-up afterwards; caregivers are not required to stay for the duration of the workshop. Tamariki should bring a packed lunch.

This workshop will involve handling and consuming some known allergens and substances your child may be sensitive to. Please refer to the list on the Space Place website.

Best suited for children aged 8-12. $65 per tamariki - 9am-1pm.

description:
The Pantoloons Present: Cinderella, The Pantoloons Present: Cinderella
Glass slippers, royal balls, and a Fairy Godmother who’s still on her learner’s licence, what could possibly go wrong?

Prince Percy is hopelessly charming (emphasis on hopeless), the Queen is busy approving new royal wave techniques (it’s very hard work being a Queen!), the step-sisters are causing chaos in couture, and Buttons has big dreams!

Will true friendship win over fairy-tale romance? Will Buttons dreams come true? And who is behind the kingdom’s mysterious gossip vlog? Packed with music, mischief, and magical mayhem, this is Cinderella with a twist, a tune, and a whole lot of sparkle! Step into a spellbinding world of wonder where dreams shimmer, magic floats on the breeze, and anything is possible… but only until the clock strikes twelve!

description:
Lost Wax Casting - 6 Weeks Course, A fantastic class full of fun and inspiration! It starts on Wed 1 October and runs until Wed 5 November, 5.30pm-8pm.

Level one: Students learn carving in hard wax, texture forming in soft wax, and how to clean up and finish your metal pieces. Course costs include basic materials for the process, but do not include the eventual metal costs for the pieces you choose to cast. As this is subject to each students' choice of size and type of metal, we leave this up to you to decide.

Castings may cost between $5 and $40 depending on whether you cast in Silver or Bronze. Casting in Bronze or Brass will be much cheaper.

Level two: expand your range of designs and skills with the wax you prefer using. Learn to set stones into your designs and either: Cast them IN the metal (exciting and organic) or, more advanced students can learn to set them in a fabrication class.

Classes fill fast so please book now to reserve your place!

description:
The Pantoloons: Cinderella, Glass slippers, royal balls, and a Fairy Godmother who’s still on her learner’s licence, what could possibly go wrong?

Prince Percy is hopelessly charming (emphasis on hopeless), the Queen is busy approving new royal wave techniques (it’s very hard work being a Queen!), the step-sisters are causing chaos in couture, and Buttons has big dreams!

Will true friendship win over fairy-tale romance? Will Buttons dreams come true? And who is behind the kingdom’s mysterious gossip vlog? Packed with music, mischief, and magical mayhem, this is Cinderella with a twist, a tune, and a whole lot of sparkle! Step into a spellbinding world of wonder where dreams shimmer, magic floats on the breeze, and anything is possible… but only until the clock strikes twelve!

REVIEWS FOR RED RIDING HOOD

“You guys were amazing, thank you so much. Me and the kids had an amazing time. We can’t wait for the next holidays t come see you again.”

“My kids had a blast! My little man was in hysterics at Mr Moa.”

“Love everything that you do and each time gets better and better.”

description:
BØLZER - Southern Tempest Tour: Wellington - This week, BØLZER [bœlˈtsr] ~ He who strikes like lightning – with sudden, decisive force or implications.
BØLZER - SOUTHERN TEMPEST TOUR
20/08 - Wellington; Valhalla
21/08 - Auckland; Whammy Bar
Tickets on sale from: https://www.undertheradar.co.nz/gig/97050/BLZER.utr
An intuitive art project born from raw passion;
musical ecstasy fueled by impulsive composition
and enactment. Whilst wielding a lyrical and musical
medium largely inspired by – and seeking to
channel – the primeval essence of the human experience,
flashes of illumination will descend the sky
from which there shall be no shelter.
Forged of an intense understanding between drummer
Fabian Wyrsch and guitarist Okoi Jones, the
project first took physical form in 2008. Before
long, the dualistic significance of their musical partnership
outshone any need for a bass player and
has since served to both challenge and empower the
band’s creativity. Following their 2010 live debut in
Zürich, BØLZER soon made a name for themselves
as the remarkable Swiss-Antipodean duo capable of
conjuring up mighty barriers of sound with nothing
but a ten-stringed guitar and an almost ritualistic
percussion style. The pair describe their own stage
experience as a form of spiritual rapture, an atavistic
vortex woven together from the profound union
of spectacle meeting spectator on a deeper plane.

description:
Kids Rock 4 Palestine, Kids Rock For Palestine
One Day. One Stage. One Cause.
This event is organised by kids in Pōneke to raise funds for kids in Palestine.
Join us for a one-day-only music fundraiser where young voices take centre stage to amplify hope and raise money for children in Palestine.
This isn’t just a concert, it’s a movement. Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.
Organiser Eddie 12: "We see children in Palestine who are being bombed and shot and are starving. We kids want to help. So that is what we are doing."
There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.
100% of proceeds go directly to emergency aid and child-focused relief in Palestine - Convoys of Good and Kiwi Trust for Palestinian Childrens Relief.
Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.
Do you want to volunteer to help? Email aotearoa2gaza@gmail.com
ALL UNDER 18s MUST ATTEND WITH A PARENT OR GUARDIAN.

Time: 5:30pm-8:00pm
Cost: $10 per family (immediate, not extended)
Who: children/young adults with special needs and their parents, guardians, family members, carers, siblings.

If you are looking to have a birthday celebration at one of these sessions please txt Paul on 0272787087, or message us in advance. We would also encourage you to make use of a party room to host additional guests (an extra charge would apply to guests)

description:
A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland - Wellington, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland - Wellington
“Jingle Jigs, Reels a Treat.”
Ken Longworth – The Newcastle Herald

Direct from its Off-Broadway season, A Taste of Ireland - The Irish Music & Dance Sensation, presents its holiday spectacular, A Celtic Christmas. Prepare to be enchanted with some of the world’s finest Irish dancers and musicians bringing the spirit of Christmas to life, in a show that will make you laugh, cry, and sing into the night.

After captivating audiences across the USA and around the world, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland returns to New Zealand this festive season following a highly successful 2022 tour. Experience the magic as world-class performers blend melodic folk mash-ups, acapella tap battles, and heartwarming storytelling in one truly unforgettable performance.

Featuring former World Irish dance champions and stars from Lord of the Dance and Riverdance, A Celtic Christmas delivers a holiday spectacular packed with Irish wit, traditional tunes and heartfelt ballads, alongside all your favorite carols. The show’s exciting mix of electrifying rhythms and extraordinary talent promises an evening brimming with Irish charm and enthralling entertainment, all in one powerhouse event.

Immerse yourself in a traditional Celtic landscape and let the magic of an Irish Christmas transport you to a world filled with excitement and wonder, where vibrant music and dance embody the heartbeat of the festive season.

With over one hundred and fifty 5-star Facebook reviews and over 150,000 followers, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland promises 100% live singing and dancing as it bridges the gap between energetic folk music, Irish dance, and modern tap styles.

Don’t miss your chance to see this magical show as it tours New Zealand for a strictly limited season. Get your tickets now before they sell out.

**musical instruments are subject to change from performance to performance

description:
Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival, Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival
Wellington's annual spring cherry blossom festival is back this September 🌸 A must-see event with 350+ cherry blossom trees creating a sea of pink 🌸

⭐ 'After Dark' evening light experience tickets now on sale.

📷 Capture gram-worthy photos and videos under the blossoms, and find our viral style photo spots including a giant living love heart, a swing, a boat (new this year!), a giant frame, and more

🛏️ Book a night in our chalet accomodation and wake up to a sea of pink 🌸

☕ Pre-purchase a delightful high tea alongside your ticket for the full experience (bookings required)☕

Weekends often sell out so make sure you have pre-purchased tickets online to secure your car park as spaces are limited. We hate to have to turn cars away when tickets are sold out so please do pre-purchase your tickets this year for weekends!! 🚗

🌸 New This Year - Flexi Passes
This pass allows you to come on whichever day you like. Not sure about the weather or at what level of blossom the trees are then this is for you. Purchase this ticket and come during the day on whichever day and time you like. (These tickets do NOT cover the After Dark experience).

Shuttles are available from Wellington, Palmerston North, Masterton or (anywhere!) with Capital Shuttles. With bookings available from 1 person, up to a 54 seater bus, they are the ideal way to get to and from Aston Norwood Gardens 🚌

Our in house photographer Lilia will be back again offering affordable professional photography sessions - perfect for family photos, couple photos, solo, friend groups, or even secret engagements! 📷

🌸 Blossom Valley is more than an event—it’s a fleeting moment of beauty, peace, and connection with nature. We can’t wait to share it with you. 🌸

-
In 1994, inspired by visits to Japan, owners Mark and Fiona Rammell planted over 350 Sakura Cherry Blossoms and are now seeing their dream burst into life each Spring.

Blossom Valley is an annual spring celebration sure to put the spring in your step as you explore the 14 acres of garden with New Zealand’s highest number and density of mature cherry blossom trees in the one place. For just a short amount of time each year at Aston Norwood Gardens in Kaitoke, Upper Hutt, hundreds of cherry trees come alive creating a canopy of pink blossom.

The event is carefully scheduled around the natural blossoming of the trees, with data from previous years informing the date selection. While the team at Blossom Valley do their best to ensure the ultimate blossom experience the timing of the bloom is up to mother nature.

description:
Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival, Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival
Wellington's annual spring cherry blossom festival is back this September 🌸 A must-see event with 350+ cherry blossom trees creating a sea of pink 🌸

⭐ 'After Dark' evening light experience tickets now on sale.

📷 Capture gram-worthy photos and videos under the blossoms, and find our viral style photo spots including a giant living love heart, a swing, a boat (new this year!), a giant frame, and more

🛏️ Book a night in our chalet accomodation and wake up to a sea of pink 🌸

☕ Pre-purchase a delightful high tea alongside your ticket for the full experience (bookings required)☕

Weekends often sell out so make sure you have pre-purchased tickets online to secure your car park as spaces are limited. We hate to have to turn cars away when tickets are sold out so please do pre-purchase your tickets this year for weekends!! 🚗

🌸 New This Year - Flexi Passes
This pass allows you to come on whichever day you like. Not sure about the weather or at what level of blossom the trees are then this is for you. Purchase this ticket and come during the day on whichever day and time you like. (These tickets do NOT cover the After Dark experience).

Shuttles are available from Wellington, Palmerston North, Masterton or (anywhere!) with Capital Shuttles. With bookings available from 1 person, up to a 54 seater bus, they are the ideal way to get to and from Aston Norwood Gardens 🚌

Our in house photographer Lilia will be back again offering affordable professional photography sessions - perfect for family photos, couple photos, solo, friend groups, or even secret engagements! 📷

🌸 Blossom Valley is more than an event—it’s a fleeting moment of beauty, peace, and connection with nature. We can’t wait to share it with you. 🌸

-
In 1994, inspired by visits to Japan, owners Mark and Fiona Rammell planted over 350 Sakura Cherry Blossoms and are now seeing their dream burst into life each Spring.

Blossom Valley is an annual spring celebration sure to put the spring in your step as you explore the 14 acres of garden with New Zealand’s highest number and density of mature cherry blossom trees in the one place. For just a short amount of time each year at Aston Norwood Gardens in Kaitoke, Upper Hutt, hundreds of cherry trees come alive creating a canopy of pink blossom.

The event is carefully scheduled around the natural blossoming of the trees, with data from previous years informing the date selection. While the team at Blossom Valley do their best to ensure the ultimate blossom experience the timing of the bloom is up to mother nature.

description:
Bookshop Day 2025, Mark your calendars, Bookshop Day takes place on Saturday 11 October! Bookshop Day is a one-day nationwide celebration of independent bookstores, highlighting the cultural importance of books and bookshops, and the people that bring the two together, our amazing booksellers.
This year marks 10 years of Bookshop Day in Aotearoa – that’s 10 years of dress-up competitions, live music, storytimes, regional bookshop hops, author readings, spot prizes, teddy bear sleepovers, giveaways, arts and crafts, scavenger hunts, delicious baked goods, and many, many more activities and offerings!
Bookshop Day is run by the Booksellers Association of New Zealand to encourage book lovers, like you, to celebrate your local bookshop.
Head to our website to explore our Bookshop Day event calendar and see what your local bookshop has planned this year: https://www.booksellers.co.nz/bookshop-day-2025-events

🚀 You’re invited to the BOWIE BLASTOFF Concert & Afterparty!

description:
OdESSA - Oak Park Avenue 20th Anniversary Show, Oak Park Avenue 20th Anniversary Show Oct 26th 5pm San Fran

Two decades ago, OdESSA kicked in the back door of the New Zealand
mainstream with their explosive debut Oak Park Avenue – a landmark
Indie-Funk record stacked with classics such as Bring The Money
Back, Baby Don’t Go Home, Promises Promises, Sugarpop, and I Could
Beat You In A Fight, the album captured the raw energy and swagger
of a band unafraid to push boundaries.

Now, 20 years later, OdESSA are back to celebrate the album that
started it all. On Labour Weekend, the band will take the stage at
Wellington’s iconic San Fran for a family-friendly early show,
performing Oak Park Avenue in full – plus a few surprises from their
wider catalogue. Expect high-octane grooves, infectious hooks, and the
kind of live energy that made OdESSA one of Aotearoa’s most beloved
live acts.

Joining them for this milestone event are rising stars of New Zealand’s
alt-pop scene Love Party. Known for their electrifying performances,
Love Party are the perfect complement to OdESSA’s funk-fueled legacy
– bringing fresh fire to a night that promises to be unforgettable.

Whether you were there in 2005 or discovering OdESSA for the first
time, this is a celebration of New Zealand music history you won’t
want to miss.

Tickets available now from moshtix.co.nz.

description:
Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025, Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025
The Carterton Daffodil Festival is back for 2025!

Iconic daffodil field | Heritage train | High Street markets | Street performers | WAI ART SHOW | Library crafts + MORE... Here's a snippet of what's in store:

Your Daffodil Flyer experience (that's the train between Carterton to Masterton) has been revamped with new one-way options! Book you seat now: https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-festival-flyer/

Wander through the golden daffodils at Middle Run. Access is by free bus only – no private vehicles permitted. Pick-your-own, bunches are $5 with proceeds going to Plunket and Wellington Free Ambulance.

Enjoy music, dance, and live acts throughout the day. From main stage performances to roving entertainers, there’s something for the whole whānau.

Visit the Wai Art Show at the Events Centre and browse a wide variety of art by talented local artists. A must-see stop for art lovers and collectors.

This year, the Carterton Library will be open with simple crafts for kids, a display from the Wairarapa Herb Society, and a free talk from Aratoi about our collaborative POP-UP museum.

Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori also begins on September 14 - to celebrate we invite you to come in and browse our Māori Collection and pick up a flyer – listing 50 of our resources to help you on your te reo journey.

We can't wait to see you at one of Carterton's biggest and brightest days of the year!

Big thanks to our event sponsors; Carterton District Council, Stuff Wairarapa Times-Age, and TSC Traffic Management.

description:
ChoctoberFest, Porirua is the home of New Zealand’s favourite chocolate — Whittaker's. So it's only fitting it has a festival celebrating all things chocolate. During September and October, the city is serving up a range of tasty treats for ChoctoberFest, all featuring Whittaker’s chocolate.
More than 30 local businesses will be competing in the Whittaker’s Bake Off and Top of the Chocs. Head in to participating spots, and try unique chocolate drinks and amazing baked goods. You can then vote for your favourites.
Indulge your tastebuds and try special drinks such as a whipped white choc biscoff latte, or a coldbrew shot choc maltini. For a sweet snack, how about a molten embrace, kunafa chocolate croissant, or a banoffee flossy pie? There are plenty of options for all chocolate lovers, including vegan and gluten free items.
As well as voting for your favourite items, you can join the fan club, share reviews, and be in to win. Up for grabs are 100 Whittaker’s Peanut Slabs, an exclusive tour of the Whittaker’s factory, and ChoctoberFest vouchers for local cafes and bars.
The festival has been running since 2022, and is a highlight of the local hospitality scene.

It's going to be an unforgettable night with a monster lineup, guest appearances, merch giveaways and a carnival atmosphere all night long.

Soaring horns, driving dancing rhythms and plenty of smiles! 2 International Tours and counting (Brazil coming this November!), parades at Newtown Festivals and Cuba Dupas, Waiheke Jazz Festival, National Jazz Festival, tours across the motu. + Special Guests.

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Daffodil Express 2025
Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!

Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.

Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.

Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.

The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.

Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.

Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!

The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.

Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!

Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free

For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/

description:
Dancesplash 2025, ArtSplash is a week-long festival, held every two years, that celebrates tāmariki and rangatahi experiencing performance on the big stage in dance and choir concerts. This year, we have two separate groups performing – one at ArtSplash and the other at DanceSplash.
Mrs Long and Mr Graff have a hard-working troupe of dancers training to perform on Thursday 28 August at the 5pm show, held at the Opera House.
This is a new venue for the show, what a treat! This group will be heading into town by 8:15am for the dress rehearsal, before returning to school to catch their breath. They’ll head back in together on the bus and will be ready to head home with their spectator parents at the conclusion of the show. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
Tickets are now on sale. You can purchase them via the Ticketmaster website. NOTE: Due to limited seating and a high number of schools involved, there is a limit of TWO tickets per performer. Don’t miss out!
label: Festivals

description:
Day of the Dead Celebration - Dia de los Muertos, Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

Expect:

Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

description:
Diwali Festival of Lights, Diwali Festival of Lights is an exciting cultural celebration with fun activities for the whole whānau . Experience the colours, tastes, and sounds of India and South-East Asia. TSB Arena and Shed 6 will host a variety of performances and plenty of activities to keep you entertained. Take part in henna painting and lantern-making. Feast on delicious regional cuisine, explore Indian fashion and jewellery, and meet local community groups. Most importantly, enjoy this important and joyous festival. 
At the end of the night, enjoy the fireworks show as the event goes out with a bang. The fireworks display will start at approximately 8:50pm on Wellington Harbour (weather dependent). 
Diwali is a significant annual festival that marks the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. It is celebrated by Hindus, Sikhs, and Jains in communities all over the world. It’s marked with candles, lanterns, and fireworks. It is also known as Deepavali and is one of India’s most widely-celebrated holidays.
label: Festivals

Enjoy a lively event filled with music, dance, and cultural performances, plus fun activities for the whole whānau.
Explore Indian fashion and jewellery stalls, try your hand at henna and lantern-making, meet local community groups, and feast on delicious regional cuisine.
The night will wrap up with a fireworks display at approximately 8.50pm!

Join our club trip across to Matiu-Somes Island. Enjoy a pot luck lunch with time to explore the island before conducting an underwater clean up dive by the wharf (conditions permitting).

After a BBQ dinner it is time for a walk before dessert to observe the Little Blue Penguins returning to their nests at sunset and to hunt for Giant Weta and Tuatara.

Sunday morning is a great time to relax, continue exploring the island before the boats arrive and to conduct a beach clean up before catching a ferry home.

This is a great experience for the whole family.

$100pp + Ferry

description:
Eastbourne Garden Show, Step into a world of six acclaimed private gardens each a living canvas of colour, design and inspiration from lush natives to sculpted landscapes. Each garden tells a story and provides a visual image of wonderful creations.
One garden, allegedly with the best vista, has not been opened to the public before. One garden has previously featured in the House and Garden magazine. The tour (self-guided) will begin with lunch and an opportunity to buy potted plants in the tranquil St Alban's church garden, 11 Ngaio St Eastbourne, Lower Hutt, Wellington. The tour will end with hors d'oeuvre, wine and live music in the last garden.
This is a chance not just to visit amazing gardens but support the earthquake strengthening of St Alban's historic church and hall for a rejuvenated community hub.
St Albans church garden
The six private gardens all lie within a less than 100 m walk of the 83 Metlink Marine Parade bus route, but a car or bicycle would be more convenient.
A glimpse of the six separate gardens (a-e).
a
a
b
c
d
e
f
f
The garden show is in support of earthquake strengthening of the de Jersey Clere designed St Alban's church and adjacent hall to remake this a community hub.
For the last hundred years and more, this beautiful church designed by acclaimed architect Frederick de Jersey Clere has been the heart of Anglican parish life for people in the eastern bays of Wellington. People have rejoiced, prayed and wept in it through happy family milestones and sad occasions, through two world wars and countless celebrations and crises. Along with its parish hall and tranquil garden, it has been the base for social and community services and outreach, and its memorial wall houses the ashes of local residents.
But in 2016 the congregation had to suddenly leave the church, which was deemed an earthquake risk.
Since then, the parish has explored alternatives for continuing its life and service to the people of the eastern bays. In that process it has kept its ministry and worship going through borrowed premises in local schools and other churches. Now, however, the parish has decided it needs to go back to its original base and strengthen both St Alban’s Church and the parish hall so it can continue to serve the community from its heart and home in Ngaio Street, for the next hundred years and more.
Detailed plans for strengthening the church and hall to meet acceptable safety standards have been drawn up, and fund-raising is under way. The parish is a registered charity (CC22188) and tax-deductible receipts will be issued for all donations.
Postponement by 1 day to 30 Nov if weather were to dictate and would be announced on this web site.

In collaboration with Treacle Lane and House of Puck, we invite you to a super fun evening of creative chaos—in the best possible way.
This workshop? We're building bold, beautiful mixed media artwork with woodblocks, nails, thread, and collage. It’s part art, part alchemy—all materials included, no stress required.

description:
Greg Crayford's Jazz Night for 20th August - Erna Ferry, Kia ora jazz lover,
This coming week at Wellington’s longest-running jazz residency Greg is thrilled to bring one of Aotearoa’s top vocalists to the stage – the one and only Erna Ferry.
About Erna
Erna, associated primarily with the mighty Rodger Fox Big Band, is a Jazz’n’Blues afficionado from Manawatū.
Erna started her career in amateur musical theatre, discovering, alas, that a thespian she was not - but that she loved to sing! She has performed at all the leading NZ jazz clubs and festivals throughout the country and includes as highlights her ‘tribute to Peggy Lee’ show that toured throughout NZ, and playing support for Al Jarreau and George Benson – not to mention performing at the Monterey Jazz Festival in California with the RFBB.
Erna loves to sing the blues and works regularly with a Whanganui blues band called “Blues Buffet” – and now and then teams up with Wellington vocalist Julie Lamb under the moniker of “Two Bluesy Blondes”.
On a good day she also plays a mean harmonica.
We are SOOOO looking forward to her engagement at The Realm with her ‘A’ team of musicians:
• Oscar Laven (saxophones)
• Duncan Haynes (piano)
• Rory McCartney (bass)
• Greg Crayford (drums and host)
Join us!
Table bookings 04 974 2207 or info.therealm@nzvenueco.nz or therealm.co.nz and click on ‘book a table’
Great ambience, good company, superb kai and stellar music. What more could a jazz fan want?
Jamming and sit-ins more than welcome. Bring your horn/axe/favourite toy.
Hope to see you there
Mark your diary!
Twenty Years of Realm Jazz Variety Concert/Gig – Many Acts!
30th August 2025 from 2pm-10pm

description:
Great Sounds Great Festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St

Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.
