description:
An Evening for Palestine, Please come along to a fundraiser evening to benefit The UN's Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian (OPT) Fund. The fund supports NGO's and UN partner organisations on the frontline of the humanitarian crisis in Gaza - more information here UN Crisis Relief.
It's an opportunity to give back and to share kai, and spend time with community. We have immense privilege in Aotearoa, and cooking and sharing food is a way that feels important (to me) as a way to bring people together for a good cause, in the face of what often feels like endless global and local injustice, oppression and catastrophe.
All ticket sales from this fundraiser will go to the OPT Fund, to support the people most in need when they need it.
Included in the ticket sales are:
a three course family style meal (menu released closer to the date, vegetarian and vegan option)
tunes from some of Wellington's local musicians
discounted beverages on the bar (with sales going directly to the Fund)
Doors open 5:30, music from 6, dinner from 7.
We're currently sourcing donations from local sponsors to make the event possible. If you would like to participate, get in touch.
Please note there is a flight of stairs to Bedlam and it is unfortunantly not wheelchair accessible.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Netherfield Ball, Step into the enchanting world of Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice at Homewood, where the timeless elegance of a Regency-era ball comes to life. This evening of romance, music, and culinary delight invites you to relive the iconic moments of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr Darcy’s fateful meeting.

Guests will be greeted with crafted cocktails inspired by love potions, showcasing ingredients from some of the finest distilleries in New Zealand and the United Kingdom. As the evening unfolds, indulge in a carefully curated selection of canapés, created with fresh ingredients sourced from Homewood’s own garden, evoking the flavours and charm of the Regency period.

The grand setting of Homewood, the esteemed residence of the British High Commissioner, will transport you to a bygone era. With the glow of garden lighting, live music filling the air, and an atmosphere brimming with romance, you’ll feel as if you’ve stepped into Austen’s world. Dancing will play a central role in the evening, allowing guests to immerse themselves in the grace and grandeur of the Regency social scene.

Whether you’re an Austen devotee, a fan of Bridgerton, or simply drawn to the allure of historical elegance, this event promises to captivate your imagination and senses. Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a night filled with charm, sophistication, and timeless romance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Catfish Trifecta presents: Nutflick and Chill, Do you like taking forever to pick a movie on Netflix? We did — so we made our own.
Nutflick and Chill is what happens when classic horror gets railed by the unhinged minds of Catfish Trifecta. Expect poor jump scares, fake blood, bad accents, worse decisions, and sexual tension. It’s horny, it’s haunted, and it’s probably not approved by your priest.

Grab your popcorn. And maybe a towel.
Tickets $10
Door sales available.

description:
Greytown Through the Ages, Greytown Through the Ages
DATE: All Weekend
LOCATION: various retail shops & eateries in Greytown Main St.
AGES: All
COST: Free
Step back in time with Greytown Through the Ages, a unique, immersive event where visitors can explore the town’s rich history simply by strolling along its charming Main Street and local shops. Participating businesses throughout Greytown will display historical photographs — some dating back as far as the 1850s.

Wander into cafés, boutiques and eateries to discover black-and-white snapshots of rarely seen archival images showing what Greytown once looked like. From dusty horse-drawn streets to early main street storefronts of eras gone by, each location offers a different window into the past.

Many photographs will be matched with the current buildings so visitors can compare then and now, sparking conversations and nostalgia and soak in the legacy of one of New Zealand’s most historic towns.

www.greytownarttown.com

description:
Japanese Film Festival Upper Hutt 2025, The Embassy of Japan, in cooperation with the Japan Foundation, is very pleased to announce the return of the Japanese Film Festival to Upper Hutt!

The Japanese Film Festival is an annual event held to encourage the growth of Japanese culture and understanding in New Zealand. Each year, we try to give the people of New Zealand some insight into the culture, customs, and traditions of Japan, alongside what is popular with Japanese society today, through film.

Please refer to the details at our website.

Wellington, Whirinaki Whare Taonga: 11-12 October 2025
*Bookings required via the Japanese Film Festival 2025 website above.

Film Schedule
(11 Oct 2025)
10:30-12:30 　What Did You Eat Yesterday? (120mins), 2021, Drama, Rating: G
13:00-15:10 Hit Me Anyone One More Time (127mins), 2019, Comedy, Rating:PG
15:45-17:30 　I Am What I Am (104mins), 2022, Drama, Rating :PG(Adult themes)

(12 Oct 2025)
10:30-11:45 　ON-GAKU:Our Sound (71mins), 2020, Anime, Rating :M
12:15-13:55 The Nighthawk's First Love (100mins), 2021, Drama : M(Sex scenes)
14:30-16:20 　 Love At Least (109mins), 2018, Drama, Rating : M(Offensive language, nudity & mental
health themes)

*All films will be in Japanese with English subtitles*

description:
Jazz Festival: Free Status, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Free Status is a jazz fusion band, drawing melodic inspiration from iconic artists like Herbie Hancock and 70s jazz/funk legends with electronic flair inspired by artists like Moby.

At the heart of Free Status is Tommy David on keys, an accomplished musician/composer in the early stages of his career. He has earned recognition in numerous jazz competitions and supported legendary rock acts such as Dire Straits Legacy Band, Nazareth, Hello Sailor, and plays with popular rockabilly band, Recliner Rockers. With composition at the center of his artistry, he can't wait to share the exciting and genuine compositions he has created.

The rhythm section features Behzad Karakia (drums) and Tyler Diprose (bass), both veterans of performances with many of New Zealand's jazz greats.

On lead alto sax is James Dawes, recently selected for an international touring band on a year-long cruise. His versatility extends well beyond jazz.

On keys is Sam Voyle, whose primary instrument is tenor saxophone. Performing with Tommy since their school days, he has built a strong musical bond that has led to major appearances, including the America's Cup main stage and high-profile corporate events.

On vocals is Melody Lui-Webster, an award-winning singer and accomplished musical theatre performer and actor, with numerous professional stage and television roles.

Thank you for watching!

description:
Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026, Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026
Get ready, Kapiti – something bold, creative, and totally unforgettable is coming your way. On Saturday, 7th March 2026, the Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival makes its explosive return at the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall, bringing together the ultimate fusion of ink, art, and live entertainment for one epic day of creativity and connection. Whether you're a tattoo enthusiast, an art lover, or someone who thrives in high-energy, artistic environments, this festival is your ticket to something truly extraordinary.

This isn’t just another tattoo expo — it’s a full-blown creative takeover. Expect to see over 40 talented artists under one roof, from the regions leading tattooists to visionary painters, sculptors, illustrators, and local craftspeople. You’ll witness live tattooing, explore interactive art installations, shop handcrafted works, and dive into workshops designed to spark your imagination. Plus, with non-stop local entertainment on the main stage — from musicians to performers and DJs — the atmosphere will be electric from start to finish.

What makes this event truly special? It’s powered by the team at Kapiti Castles — the creative minds behind the popular Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo. Known for producing vibrant, community-driven experiences, Kapiti Castles has crafted this festival as a platform for creative expression, community connection, and artistic inspiration. Whether you're an artist looking to grow your brand or a visitor eager to explore the region’s creative heartbeat, this is your moment.

The Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival is more than an event — it’s a movement. It’s a chance to meet incredible artists, get inspired, celebrate culture, and maybe even walk away with some fresh ink. With something for everyone — from art collectors to curious newcomers — this is a must-attend event for 2026.

So mark your calendars for 7th March, gather your crew, and get your tickets now. The Kapiti Tattoo & Arts Festival 2026 is where creativity comes alive, and you won’t want to miss being part of it. Tickets are on sale now — don’t miss your chance to be part of Kapiti’s boldest new festival.

description:
Jewellery-making in 8 weeks - Tuesday Eve Mixed Level, This class is mixed level, allowing beginners to work alongside advanced students. It starts on Tuesday, 14 October and runs for 8 weeks till Tuesday, 2 December, 5.30pm - 8pm.
Our popular weeknight classes are the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment.

Beginners start with basic ring-making and stone-setting in copper or brass. Students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering. Then we move on to making a practice-ring set with a Cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top) in a Bezel Setting. The stone-setting process teaches you many fundamental techniques in one project! As you work through your practice-ring and setting, you can move onto working in silver and produce another ring with a cabachon stone that you really love. This way you will learn the basics as you go on your practice-ring, before taking the next step in costly silver.

Level 2 students learn to solder more competently on their own using chainmaking as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. They may create a simple stone setting or ring alongside this challenge project so they have something to hone their skills that they are familiar with, as well as taking on a new skill. Their silver project could be a pendant on a handmade chain, a charm bracelet or a more complex bezel setting - for example a teardrop or soft square stone to take on bezels with corners!

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques. They should prepare to have one or two simple projects they can work on self-directed in class: more chains or simple bezel settings are ideal - to help them strengthen their soldering skills - alongside a challenge project that might be a shelf setting (an adaptation of a bezel setting that can take faceted stones), a tube setting or a larger bezel setting for a box or brooch. Our tutors will work with you to discover your passions in the world of making, and to support your skills so you grow your understanding with each block you take. We recommend that students from level 3 and up take the occasional Technique class (for example - claw setting, enamelling, flush setting) and then bring those techniques into their projects in their block class to be supported in their practice and skill by their regular tutor.

This class fee does NOT include materials for any student.
Beginners should expect to spend at least $60 on materials for their ring making project.
All metals and stones as well as quality findings and chains are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it thriftily in future projects!

Our booking system asks for payment to be made via credit card, Afterpay or PayPal on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this ;)

description:
Martinborough Music Festival 2025, Bringing the world to Martinborough for chamber music in the heart of South Wairarapa.

Join us for four exciting concerts over three days, featuring stunning New Zealand and international artists including Natalia Lomeiko (violin), Yuri Zhislin (violin/viola), Matthias Balzat and Ashley Brown (cello), Jian Liu (piano), Wilma Smith and Donald Armstrong (violin), Simon Brew (saxophone) and Caroline Henbest (viola).

These artists will bring to life extraordinary works including Zoltán Kodály's Duo for Violin and Cello, Op. 7; JS Bach's Goldberg Variations for string trio; Shostakovich's Piano Quintet in G minor, Op. 57 and Mozart's String Quintet No. 5 in D major, K.593.

The Sunday afternoon concert will also include the world premiere of Shifting Worlds, a piano quintet by renowned New Zealand composer Louise Webster, who has special ties with South Wairarapa.

Visit martinboroughmusicfestival.co.nz for more information about artists, programmes and links to ticket sales.

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Award Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Footprints on Katmai (22 mins) Max Romey, USA. Following his grandmother's footsteps to one
of the most remote and bear-strewn beaches in Alaska, painter Max Romey discovers that an
ocean of problems is closer to home than he could have imagined. BEST FILM ON THE ENVIRONMENT
Alone Across Gola (20 mins) Jude Kriwald, UK, NZ Premiere. Stranded in Liberia’s Gola
rainforest, filmmaker Jude Kriwald faces hunger, isolation, robbery and disappearing trails. A raw
tale of one man’s solo, self-filmed journey chasing a childhood dream. With only a bike and a
tent, Jude pushes the limits of survival and self-discovery. BEST ADVENTUROUS SPORTS & LIFESTYLES
Zahir (36 mins) Julien Nadiras, Switzerland, subtitles. Katherine and Eline take on an iconic rock
route, accessing it by bike. Their all-eco ascent tests endurance, nerve, and friendship, with long
runouts and tiny holds pushing them to the edge.
Body of a Line (10 mins) Henna Taylor, subtitles, USA. A cleverly animated short film that
morphs into real life as Madaleine undertakes an intimate and creative journey to climb a difficult
rock route, with original music and poetry. BEST SHORT FILM
Trango (46 mins) Leo Hoorn, USA. After a two-year attempt, ski mountaineers ski the first
descent of the Great Trango Glacier. They navigate risk, grapple with grief, and face physical
danger as they push the limits of human experience. Unspoken trust and support within their
expedition team allows them to face the unimaginable together. GRAND PRIZE FILM


Total running time: 120 minutes + 15 minute intermission.

description:
NZ Drum & Dance Camp, NZ Drum & Dance Camp
Join us this 24th to 27th October for a West African musical immersion at our annual NZ Drum Dance Camp.

Set amidst 38 acres of native bushland just a short drive from Wellington, this weekend is a celebration of unity, rhythm, and the soul-stirring power of African drum and dance, curated for the NZ African drumming community.

We are excited to announce that Epizo Bangoura will be back to join us again in 2025!

Epizo Bangoura is a celebrated master musician from Guinea, West Africa, known for his extraordinary versatility on the Kora (African harp), Balafon (African tuned percussion), and Djembe/Duns.

Epizo will be joined by Ghanaian Master Drummer Yaw Asumadu and special guest Jimi Dale.

Camp Highlights:

♪ Djembe and Dunun Workshops: Suitable for all skill levels, from enthusiastic beginners to advanced drummers, guided by our awesome team of teachers.
♪ Traditional Dance: with the effervescent Epizo Bangoura.
♪ Group Jams and Musical Sessions: Strengthen communal bonds through captivating group jams and impromptu musical sessions.
♪ Tranquil Setting: Enjoy the native bushland environ - build mind, body and spirit whilst enhancing our weekend of music and togetherness.
♪ Catering – Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included on Saturday and Sunday, as well as breakfast Monday. Please bring a shared (pre-prepared) plate for Friday evening kai.

Featured Instructors:

Epizo Bangoura: A master of the djembe and traditional dance, Epizo brings profound knowledge and vibrant energy, embodying the essence of West African music and dance.

Yaw Asumadu: A Master Drummer from Ghana, Yaw has performed globally and taught African drumming for 25 years, collaborating with legendary artists.

Jimi Dale: A pioneer of African music in NZ, Jimi has been teaching African Drum and Dance classes since 1995 and formed the world music and dance group, Tamani. We are excited to have Jimi back again teaching us a dun dance piece.

Pricing Details:
♪ Early Bird: $450 (Reserve by Sunday 31st August 2025)
♪ Adult rate: $495
♪ Kids 9 – 14 years old: $250
♪ Kids 8 and under: $175
♪ Family Packages available on request
♪ Single Day & night $220 (includes 3 meals and full day tuition)
♪ Drum Hire: $15

Event Schedule Snapshot:
♪ Friday, 24th October: Arrive from 4pm - A warm welcome sets the stage for a weekend filled with rhythm and learning.
Bring a share plate for dinner.
♪ Saturday, 25th October: Engage in enriching drum and dance workshops. Participants will be grouped into their appropriate levels.
♪ Sunday, 26th October: Continue your musical journey with drum and dance sessions, leading to a group performance that encapsulates the weekend’s shared experiences.
♪ Monday, 27th October: Morning All in Drum & Dance ceremony, then it's time to hit the road.

FAQs
♪ Getting Ready: Bring your drum (if available), snacks for the weekend, dance-appropriate shoes, sleeping gear (pillowcase & sheet, sleeping bag/ doona), warm clothes, and an eager spirit.
♪ Beginners are warmly welcomed – our camp is a nurturing space for newcomers to discover the joy of African drumming and dance, bolstered by a supportive community.

For more information and tickets -
https://africandrumming.co.nz/tours-and-retreats/nz-drum-dance-camp/

More questions?
Contact - Tulletha at or call: 028 474 1123

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Island Bay Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.
label: Festivals

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Island Bay Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.
label: Festivals

description:
Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week Flag Raising Ceremony, Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week Flag Raising Ceremony
Papua Niugini Tok Pisin Wik - Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week
Celebrate: 7 - 13 September 2025

The 2025 theme for Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week is 'Lukautim, strongim na kirapim tokples na pasin blo tubuna - Preserve, revitalise and promote our language and culture'.

You are invited to join the formal flag raising ceremony, at the Performing Arts Centre inside Pātaka Art + Museum.

There will be morning tea and refreshments following the ceremony.

Find out more about the Pacific Language Weeks here:

https://poriruacity.govt.nz/your-council/pacific-culture-in-porirua-city/pacific-language-weeks/

description:
Puku Rangi Tea – Rapa Nui Music & Dance Tour in Marlborough, Experience the vibrant culture of Easter Island as Puku Rangi Tea tours for the first time in Marlborough to closing the Welcoming Week Celebration!
Since 2012, they have been dedicated to preserving and showcasing traditional Rapa Nui music and dance. Their vibrant performances include the Hoko warrior dance, resonating with the spirit of the Māori Haka, storytelling through Takona body painting and ancestral narratives, Kai Kai string games and the rhythmic sounds of Tahitian ukulele and drums.
Puku Rangi Tea currently performs three shows a week at the Tahatai Hotel in Hanga Roa, Rapa Nui, and has participated in various festivals throughout its history, including:
Indigenous festival 2023–2024, San Juan de la Costa, Chile.
World Gathering of Folkloric Associations 2020, Lima, Peru.
International Festival 2018–2019, Málaga, Spain.
Chapultepec Forest Festival 2018, Mexico City, Mexico.
Second Workshop on Rapa Nui Music and Dance 2018, Mexico City, Mexico.
Rapa Nui Dance and Music Show 2018, Mexico City and Morelia, Michoacán, Mexico.
First Workshop on Rapa Nui Music and Dance 2017, Mexico City, Mexico.
Rapa Nui Dance and Music Show 2017, Mexico City, Mexico.
Indigenous festival 2016–2020, San Juan de la Costa, Chile.
Cultural Market 2017, Mexico City, Mexico.
12th Pacific Arts Festival 2016, Hagåtña, Guam.
Carnaval 2016, Arica, Chile.
Summer Festival 2016, Valdivia, Chile.
Oktoberfest Chile 2015–2017, Malloco, Chile.
Gala Puro Chile 2015, Miami, United States.
The tour holds significant cultural importance due to Rapa Nui deep ancestral connections with Aotearoa, offering a unique opportunity for cultural engagement and community connection.
Their itinerary includes high-profile engagements, such as:
Music Workshop on Friday 12 at 4pm - Koha Entry - RSVP Required
Dance Workshop on Friday 12 at 6pm - Koha Entry - RSVP Required
Concert: Live music and dances on Sunday 14 Spetember. Doors open at 3:30pm, Event start at 4pm
Koha - Entry - RSVP Required (Limited Capacity)
We are also excited to feature the local guest band "Matices", who will open the concert with a vibrant performance of live Andean and Latin American music.

description:
Rathkeale Christmas Fete 2025, Welcome to the Rathkeale Christmas Fête 2025! Walk through the gates of Rathkeale College on 1st November and be welcomed by a diverse range of colourful stalls, the aroma of freshy cooked food and plenty of festive inspiration.

Now in its 22nd year, the Christmas Fête has become a must-do event on the Wairarapa spring calendar. Stallholders travel from around the North Island to sell their wares and offer Christmas shoppers loads of inspiration. From festive decorations, clothing, arts and crafts, to flowers, toys and plants – there is something for everyone.

Gourmet food is always a highlight at the Fête - think freshly made gourmet burgers, lamb & mint sausages, wraps, curry, salads, and the ever-popular berries & ice-cream - there is always a huge variety of flavours to tempt the taste buds. Devonshire Teas and home baking served in the Rathkeale Homestead rose garden is a time-honoured tradition while refreshing cold drinks can be sipped on as visitors listen to live music performed by students at various times throughout the day. The popular Christmas cake stall features again this year - but visitors are encouraged to get in early as the cakes often sell out by midday.

The beauty of this Fête is that it’s a day out for the whole family. In addition to the 120 plus stalls, there is plenty to entertain the children including facepainting and magic shows throughout the day.

Visitors can also explore the beautiful, expansive grounds of Rathkeale College including the school gardens designed by Alfred Buxton, the Greek Amphitheatre and the 3km eco-trail which weaves through large stands of native trees, including ancient kahikatea.

Eftpos is available, but we strongly recommend that visitors bring cash.

Koha/gold coin entry.
Rathkeale College is a five-minute drive north of Masterton in the Wairarapa.

description:
RAVE TO THE GRAVE - Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS Theatre and RadioActiveFM, RAVE TO THE GRAVE - Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS Theatre and RadioActiveFM
30+ DJs - 3 Stages - 1 Fundraiser

🦇 Rave to the Grave 🔊 – Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS Theatre and RadioActive.FM will transform the Kent Tce into a pumping, all-night celebration on Halloween night. With three unique dance spaces across all of BATS’ venues, ravers can choose their vibe, from blissed-out chill, to deep grooves, to high-energy bass.

🚨 Tickets are strictly limited so be quick! 🚨

🎟️ Earlybird: $49.5 (use code"EARLYBIRD")
🎟️ General Admission: $55.9
🎟️ VIP: $99.5 (Includes a free drink and snack on arrival, plus a mystery goodie bag!)
🎟️ Can't make it? You can still donate!

More than 30 RadioActive.FM DJs will be behind the decks, from all your favourite shows, including The Jewel School, Midnight Marauders, The Floor, Homebass, The Session, and more!

Both BATS and RadioActive.FM, as charitable organisations, must continually raise funds to keep their doors open and their creative voices alive, ensuring that audiences can continue to enjoy bold, independent theatre and iconic local broadcasting.

‼️ This event is R18 ‼️

description:
Karori Friendship Club, Looking for community, connection, and a good cuppa?

Come and join us at the Karori Friendship Club — a friendly weekly gathering where you can:
- Meet new people
- Share stories over morning tea
- Try your hand at a puzzle or join a chat group
- Simply enjoy time together in a relaxed space

Where: St Ninian’s Church, 208 Karori Road, Karori
When: Every Tuesday, 10am–12pm
Koha for morning tea

Although many who come are seniors, the club is open to anyone — whether you’re new to the area, a recent migrant, or just looking to make some new friends. People join us from all over Wellington, not just Karori!

Why not come along this Tuesday and see for yourself? You might leave with new friends, a full heart, and maybe even a completed puzzle.

These classes offer flexible booking, and participants can sign up week to week or purchase a term pass.
The teacher will alternate every 4 weeks.

Please see FAQ's on our website for any questions https://rnzb.org.nz/for-dancers/adult-open-classes

description:
SlavFest 2025 - Festival of Slavic and Balkan culture, food, music and dance, SlavFest 2025 - Festival of Slavic and Balkan culture, food, music and dance
Welcome to SlavFest 2025 - a FREE family friendly event to celebrate the richness of Slavic and Eastern European culture! 💪
Witamy | Ласкаво просимо | Добро пожаловать | Добродошли | Добре дошли | Vítejte | Dobrodošli | Добредојдовте | Сардэчна запрашаем

📍 Venue: Te Whaea: National School of Drama and Dance in Newtown, Wellington.
📅 6th SEP from 10 am - 6.30pm
🕙 Doors open at 10:00 AM

This year’s festival is bigger than ever! Enjoy live music from Ish, Vox Ethno, Balkany, Klezmer Rebs, Krackerjack, Cosmonauts, Wososi, and Mehana — plus traditional Polish, Ukrainian, and Bulgarian dancing.
Come and try yummy food from our Slavic and Balkan stalls (pierogi, borscht, burek, kielbasa (Polish smoked sausage), Hungarian fried bread, Blini, pirozhki), artisan crafts, kids’ workshops, and hands-on cultural fun.
Entertaiment is going to be to be for the whole day:

🎉 10:10 AM – Mihi Whakatau (Welcome Ceremony) @ PLAZA
🎶 10:30 AM – Wososi @ PLAZA

🎉 Slav Fest 2025 – Stage program in The Theatre🎉

🎻 10:55 AM – Klezmer Rebs
💃 11:45 AM – Bulgarian Dancing (Dance Performance)
🎤 12:10 PM – Mehana
💃 1:00 PM – Vinok (Dance Performance)
🎼 1:25 PM – Vox Ethno
🕺💃 2:15 PM – Orleta + Orzel (Dance Performance)
🎸 3:00 PM – Krakerjack
🎺 3:50 PM – Balkany
🌌 4:40 PM – Cosmonauts
🔥 5:30 PM – Ish
🏁 6:20 PM – Closing Ceremony

🎨 SLAV FEST - WORKSHOPS PROGRAM @ DRAMA 1 studio🎨
🎟️ Free Entry
Workshops for kids and adults. Get involved and try something fun. Creative sessions, dance, craft, cupcake decorations and movie – all celebrating Eastern European culture!

🕺 10:45 – 11:05 AM
Dance: Bulgarian Balkan (Kolo) dance Workshop with Lilia (20 min)
🎬 11:15 AM – 12:00 PM
Watch: Eastern European Animation – Beautiful, short movies
💃 12:00 – 12:30 PM
Dance Workshop: Polish Folk Dance with Orleta + Orzel (30 min)

🍰 12:45 – 1:15 PM
Make: Cup Cake Decoration Workshop for kids– Session 1
🍰 1:30 – 2:10 PM
Make: Cup Cake Decoration Workshop for kids – Session 2

🥁 2:30 – 3:00 PM
Play: Balkany Percussion Workshop (30 min)

💃 3:10 – 4:00 PM
Dance: Folkloric Alphabet: Bulgarian Kolo with Milen
Milen will take you on a journey through different regions of Bulgaria, exploring the unique styles and rhythms of traditional Kolo dances (40 min)
🎬 4:15 – 5:00 PM
Watch: Eastern European Animation – Final screening

🎨 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM @ DRAMA 1
Russian School will organize kids Craft Workshop
Create traditional crafts and explore Slavic heritage through art.


We can’t wait to dance, sing, and celebrate with you all!
📲 Bring your friends and whānau – let’s celebrate together! See you there! #wellington #festival #wellingtonfestival

description:
Slow Grind Fever [AUS] - Wellington Jazz Festival, Express from Melbourne, Australia and crossing international waters for the first time this October, Meow is excited to welcome the slowest, spookiest, smokiest and swingin-est club night Wellington has ever seen: 'Slow Grind Fever'.
For this one-night-only episode of SGF Wellington, founder Richie1250 (106.7 PBS FM) will be joined by fellow Melbourne radio alumnus Dr. Popalotacorn (RRR, 98.1FM Raglan) and Wellington's own belle of the airwaves Miss Juliet (RadioActive.FM Americana)
Slow Grind Fever was born in 2012 when Richie1250 hired a Russian Cultural Centre ballroom and threw a slow dance party for his 30th birthday, and it's been running as a regular monthly club night ever since. Richie and his friends play the slowest, sleaziest, spookiest, sweetest, swinginest old records they can find, and people dance real slow in a haze of smoke and dim red light. It's a good time.
In the last few years Richie has taken Slow Grind Fever on the road, with regular dances in Sydney, Hobart, Darwin and Alice Springs. They post up a monthly Slow Grind Fever mix in the week before the party every month, and have collaborated with Stag-O Lee Records in Germany on a series of Slow Grind Fever LPs and CDs.
Enjoy the music and if you feel so inclined, get down to Slow Grind Fever - Wellington at Meow on Friday 17th October.
Listening to the MP3 mixes is nice, but when you’re in the room all
wrapped up in smoke with the music sizzling right off the old records, through the speakers and into your brain, well, there's nothing quite like it…
http://www.slowgrindfever.com/
https://www.instagram.com/slowgrindfeverclub
label: Festivals

description:
Splendor of Silk: A Celebration of Traditional Chinese Clothing, Unveil the timeless elegance of China's sartorial heritage! Join us for an enchanting exploration of "华服" (Huáfú) - the exquisite traditional costumes that have graced Chinese culture for millennia.
Living History: Discover how imperial robes, flowing Hanfu and delicate Qipao tell stories of China's dynasties.
Dance Through Time: Enjoy traditional performances showcasing how movement and costume intertwine.
Cultural Immersion: Interactive activities that bring ancient fashion to life.
Join us for an unforgettable Traditional Chinese Costume Culture Event! Don't miss the chance to immerse yourself in the beauty of various clothes. See you there!

description:
Tartan Up The Green, Tartan Up The Green
Gather up the clan and join us here at Brewtown Upper Hutt – Tartan Up The Green is back for 2025!

Are you ready to be blown away by the power of the Pipes and Drums as Tartan Up The Green returns this October 4th for another rousing rendition of Bagpiping, Highland Drumming and Dancing!

Our mates from RNZPBA Wellington Hawkes Bay are back to curate their all-new take on traditional pipe and drum comps with some of the finest musicians in the country.

Join us on The Greenspace for our very own family friendly, FREE to attend salute to those earth-shaking instruments of war (literally) and all things Highlands and Islands!

It won’t just be Pipers and Drummers competing for glory. Brewtown is delighted to welcome some bonnie boogying in the form of Scottish Highland Dancing, as dancers from up and down the country wow the crowd with traditional dance.

A true showcase of strength and stamina, Highland Dancing is highly technical and recognised as a sport by the Sport Council of Scotland…waltzing this aint!

So, get behind these incredible young athletes and show your support at this years Tartan Up The Green!

description:
Welly Green Thinks - Spring Edition, Although architecture is a confluence of styles, cultures, amenity, and technical delivery, it is the ‘site’ which buildings are most vehemently shaped by, and yet the land they are located on often loses touch with critical pathways to solving systemic sustainability issues. Tina will discuss this proposition, her observations in practice and what decisions get prioritised, and how we can be more conscientious about land use.  

Tina Williams is a NZ registered architect and current chair of Te Kahui Whaihanga – NZ Institute of Architects Wellington Branch, and has worked on numerous residential and community projects.
Be part of the conversation that aims to shape sustainable and resilient futures for our communities.

We can’t wait to see you there!

description:
THREE JOYFUL HOUSES - AOTEAROA FESTIVAL OF ARCHITECTURE - SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER, THREE JOYFUL HOUSES by IAN ATHFIELD
SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER @ FUTUNA CHAPEL - KARORI
Three joyful houses, three families and three client stories about the commissioning, designing, building and living in homes designed by Ian Athfield.
SPENCER and DIANE LOGAN
1974 - 1978
WINDY POINT – EASTBOURNE
Photographer unknown
Spencer Logan and his wife Diane will talk about the commissioning of their first new home, its design, construction, the cleaning of thousands of bricks, and living in this unique collection of a pair of recycled brick towers with timber clad ‘saddlebags’. 
ROSS, CUSHLA and TESS JAMIESON
1974 - 1978
MAHINA BAY
Ross and Cushla have lived in their home on the Eastern hills above Mahina Bay for 48 years. They will, along with their youngest daughter, recount their experiences of working with Ian Athfield in the commissioning of the design of their home, the construction process and then living in this hillside hugging collection of building, and how this home may have influenced their living and the raising of a family of four children.
JONATHAN CUSTANCE   - THE CUSTANCE HOUSE 1981 – 1982
HAVELOCK NORTH
“The Custance House replaced an early modern home that burnt to the ground in 1981 leaving only the swimming pool unscathed.  Ray and Ann Custance, who were friends of the Athfields, sought a bold replacement.  With their son, industrial and interior designer Jonathan Custance, they prepared a four page brief for a new building….. “
Text taken from Athfield Architects by Julia Gatley 2012 AUP.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. 
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when registering for Architect tickets

description:
Jazz Festival: Alex Keatley's Sounds of the Motherland, An exclusive concert for Wellington Jazz Festival at The Undercurrent.

Double bassist, bandleader and composer Alex Keatley presents Sounds from the Motherland — a vibrant and deeply personal journey into the rich world of South African jazz. Blending the infectious grooves of Cape jazz, the joyous spirit of kwela, and the harmonic sophistication of post-bop, this project pays tribute to the music of Abdullah Ibrahim, Nduduzo Makhathini, Bheki Mseleku, and Winston Mankunku Ngozi while offering bold new compositions inspired by their legacy.

Starting this project while studying his undergraduate degree at the University of Auckland Jazz School, Alex's band consists of friends he has met during his time studying in Auckland and is excited to share with you what they have been working on for the past year. Come along and enjoy the music with us.

Featuring:

- Na'amah Cheiban
- Francesca Parussini
- Jenna Aspeling
- Will Ralph
- Iggy Palmero Epstein
- Ryan Tomov
- Finn McNeill

Join us under a canopy of trees for an unforgettable afternoon that blends flavour, sound & celebration. Set against the stunning backdrop of Martinborough’s rolling hills and vines, this curated gathering brings together our favourite makers, movers, and shakers - ready to pour, plate, and play their hearts out.

Sip iconic artisan wines, swirl small-batch gin and savour signature gourmet bites by culinary legends.

On stage we welcome the soulful stylings and powerhouse vocals of Hollie Smith, the retro glam and infectious energy of The Beat Girls, and the genre-spinning magic of Sweet Mix Kids, interspersed with sets from DJ Takas. The only thing smoother than the wine is the soundtrack.

Our Saturday session promises an elevated, intimate atmosphere - where the wine flows, the beats drop, and the good vibes carry you through an afternoon of dancing, right into sunset.

With invited friends: Martinborough Vineyard, Te Kairanga, Escarpment, Ata Rangi, Schubert, Palliser Estate, Halite Wines, Lighthouse Gin, Mt Difficulty, Vavasour, Martinborough Brewery, Antipodes Water, The Crab Shack, Wharekauhau Estate, Shed 5, SOUL Bar & Bistro and Martin Bosley's Oyster Saloon.

Elevate your festival experience with VIP hosting at The Runholder Cottage. Indulge in premium and library wines poured by the winemakers themselves, impeccably paired with gourmet food offerings from Auckland Viaduct’s iconic SOUL Bar & Bistro. As a VIP guest, you’ll enjoy all-inclusive food and beverage with menu service for any onsite vendor, exclusive access to the dedicated VIP area with priority stage sightlines and premium hosting amenities for your comfort and convenience.

Take advantage of easy transportation options with return bus add-ons from Wellington, Masterton, Carterton, Greytown & Featherston ($30-$60), and free shuttles to and from Martinborough Square, so you can sip responsibly.

description:
From Sad Blokes to Well Men: Changing the focus in male suicide prevention - Wellington (FSB2025/01), From anxious boys through to lonely old men: Tracking male suicide across the lifespan.
Are traditional notions of masculinity meeting the needs of men in 2025? How the changes in men’s roles and identity contribute to suicide in men.
A vision for men’s wellbeing: An holistic approach to conceptualising men’s wellbeing and key mental wellbeing messages for men.

IT'S TIME FOR A SERIOUS RETHINK IN HOW WE PREVENT MALE SUICIDE AND TO TAKE SUICIDE IN MEN OUT OF THE TOO HARD BASKET
Hear a comprehensive critique of why the suicide rate in men continues to rise despite numerous prevention initiatives, the reasons why we need to focus more on men and what are proven effective strategies for preventing male suicide.
BE PART OF THE SOLUTION
DURING THE MONTH OF MOVEMBER TAKE THE OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE  IN A WORKSHOP WITH INTERNATIONALLY RESPECTED AND AWARD WINNING MALE SUICIDE PREVENTION SPECIALIST BARRY TAYLOR
It matters that men are able to optimise their wellbeing.  Well men contribute to well whānau, communities, workplaces, economy and society
Drawing on his lived experience and his extensive experience in engaging, assessing and supporting suicidal men of different cultures, age groups, genders and sexualities, he offers practical and time proven approaches to both preventing male suicide, engaging with a suicidal man and effective initiatives to optimise men's wellbeing.
"Helping men and boys to transition from sad blokes to well men must be our focus"
Topics covered:
Overview of suicide in men
The Suicidal Moment - Men's thoughts, emotions and behaviour in the "suicidal moment”
Masculinity for the 21st Century - Are traditional notions of masculinity meeting the needs of men in 2024?  How the changes in men’s roles and identity contribute to suicide in men.
Intergenerational suicide among men and its impact of whānau and hapū
From anxious boys through to lonely old men: Tracking male suicide across the lifespan
A vision for men’s wellbeing: An holistic approach to conceptualising men’s wellbeing and key mental wellbeing messages for men.
Tāne Ora: An Online Masterclass in creating a movement of wellbeing for men by men
Participants would benefit from also registering for this online workshop series which takes a deep dive into the determinants of wellbeing men and what is required to shift very ingrained understandings in men about being a man.  How do we move from a program approach to mens wellbeing to a movement of change that engages men in conversations of the heart and the walrua. Click here for more information and to register
Previous participants’ feedback
"The best and most informative workshop I have attended in 27 years of mental health nursing”  Community Mental Health Nurse
"This workshop should be compulsory for anyone working with men”  Male Family Violence Worker
"It was as if Barry was talking about every young man I see at school”  School Counsellor
"I have much better understanding about depressed and suicidal men. Going away with lots of ideas of how work with the men in my community”  Rural Community Support Worker
"Thanks for being so inclusive of older men. They are so often forgotten”. Aged Care Worker
"The incorporation of Te Ao Māori into the training was excellent and made it relevant to the men I work with” Kaiwhakatere
"Most helpful workshop I have been to in regards to suicide”  Mental Health Recovery Programme Facilitator
"Appreciated how inclusive the presenter was of different cultures and his analysis of how culture influences what it means to be a man”  Refugee Health Worker
An opportunity for a day of learning with award winning suicidologist, Barry Taylor

Barry has worked in mental wellbeing promotion and suicide prevention / postvention for 36 years at the local, national and international levels.
His extensive experience includes sitting on state and national government advisory committees; designing, implementing and evaluating suicide prevention programs; writing suicide prevention guidelines, training packages and community resources; providing technical advice to and evaluating  community based and national mental wellbeing and suicide prevention programmes.
He has led multiple ‘firsts’ in the context of suicide prevention and postvention both in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas. In recognition of his outstanding contribution to mental wellbeing and suicide prevention, he was awarded in 2016 the NSW Mental Health Commissioner's Community Champion Award. He currently sits one of the Health and Disability Ethics Committees.
As a health sociologist, Barry offers an unique insight into the phenomenon of male suicide in the Aotearoa-New Zealand context, the role of gender construction and the critical social and cultural determinants that have influenced men's distress and impaired wellbeing. Insights that very few others trainers or training programs in this country provide. He has had an interest on the impact of social exclusion, alienation and discrimination on mens's wellbeing and advocates for a human rights based, systems change and person-centred approach to wellbeing.The workshop is enriched by the learnings from Barry's own lived experience of depression and suicidality and his pathway to recovery.
After a number of years overseas, Barry is living back in New Zealand and is passionate about building the knowledge base, competence and capability within our country to effectively respond to the unacceptably high rate of male suicide in this country.

WORKSHOP PLACES ARE LIMITED. REGISTER EARLY TO AVOID DISAPPOINTMENT

Cancellation and Refund Policy
Workshops can fill quickly. If you are no longer able to attend the workshop please cancel your registration as soon as possible. The following refund policy is strictly adhered to.

description:
XCOMMUNICATE, XCOMMUNICATE
The formidable powerhouse duo COMMUNICATE return to Wellington in November with their clubnight, XCOMMUNICATE, for one night only.

Known for their long sets that incorporate decades of sound, Cyril Orson and Heylady have been punishing dance floors across Aotearoa since they joined forces 3 years ago. Off the back of a monstrous summer, which saw them play 19 shows up and down the country, the pair have spent most of 2025 in the studio finessing their own brand of audio alchemy and preparing to release their label, also named XCOMMUNICATE.

Usually XCOMMUNICATE is a 6 hour journey though decades and sonic realms, however as Heylady is still recovering from a mighty dose of burnout they’ve roped in a couple of their good friends, who happen to be some of Wellington’s finest, to join them as they lay down four hours of four to the floor.

Halo is a mainstay on Wellington dancefloors and it was a no brainer asking her to be on this lineup. A DJ since 2000, she has played festivals across the country and never fails to rock her slot. Her set at Taniwha’s Den last summer was a big highlight and one of the best of the festival. Halo’s ability to drive forward thinking sound and her clever construction of sets are just two reasons you need to be on her floor.

DJ Coda is the godfather of techno in New Zealand. With a career that spans decades, he isn’t just a DJ but a dedicated promoter and one of the trustees of NZ’s longest running student radio station, Radio Active. Part of the COMMUNICATE family from the get go (and a longtime collaborator of Heylady’s), DJ Coda is a master of his craft and never fails to deliver. Armed with knowledge , taste and a hefty love of Detroit, DJ Coda is the man when it comes to rocking the dance floor.
First release tickets are on sale now, grab yours before they are gone and come and dance the evening away with four of the best. We recommend arrive early so you don’t miss out on any of the sets, they are all going to be killer.

IMPORTANT INFO:
Our event is a safe space for all. If you or someone you know is feeling unsafe or harassed, please approach one of the DJs or bar staff. If you are behaving badly and impacting others ability to have a good time safely, you will be removed. Please act with respect and care for your fellow attendees at all times, no means no and this goes for conversations as well as more intimate requests.

description:
Poetry Slam: Regional Heat #1, This PIM event is a Poetry Slam! The first of three regional heats leading to the regional finals at the National Library on October 11th.
This Poetry In Motion Slam is the first heat for the 2025 Wellington Poetry Slam Champs. The top three scoring poets from this event will gain a spot in the regional finals!
Poets who want to sign up for the slam, please drop an email to:
travis.cottreau@gmail.com
subject: slam heat #1
What is a slam?
A Poetry Slam is a competitive poetry event where poets compete for points. Five random audience members are tasked with being the judges and they score each poem out of 10 to one decimal place.
The number of poets involved and number of rounds can change event-to-event, but there are some universal rules – no props, no costumes, poems must be three minutes or less, poets must read original work, and no punching down or hate speech.
Price on the door is $5
The top four poets from each heat will go through to the Wellington Poetry Slam Champs at the National Library of New Zealand on October 11th.
Other heats:
Sunday the 21st Sept
Thursday the 2nd October
Finals: Saturday, 11th October.

description:
Dear Gentlemen (Colombia), Dear Gentlemen (Colombia)
Director: Patricia Castañeda -

Genre: Drama

About this Event

Dear Gentlemen brings to light the little-known sufraggist movement in Colombia. Set in 1954, the film follows Esmeralda Arboleda, a fiercely intelligent leader who sparks a revolution in a society deeply rooted in patriarchal traditions - a revolution that culminates in a fierce and decisve debate. A women group embarks on a historic struggle to bring the issue of women's right to vote before the National Constituent Assembly. With bold marches, radio appearances, and a brilliant media strategy that puts them on the front page, they achieve their goal, but the real challenge begins during the debate, where they face fierce opposition. Esmeralda Arboleda must endure personal attacks from the assembly members, and just as she is about to speak, she receives a heartbreaking call: her son has suffered a serious accident. She is torn between her duty as a mother and her commitment to the cause, with an unfavorable outcome. Although all seems to be lost, her perseverance leads to a historic victory when women's suffrage is finally approved, marking a turning point in Colombia's history.

description:
Get Animated! Stop-motion Animation Workshop, Get Animated! Stop-motion Animation Workshop
Ever wanted to try your hand at stop-motion animation and bring inanimate objects to life? Now you can!

Join animator Steffen Kreft and storyteller and poet William Connor for a practical, hands-on workshop that will inspire and enable you to make your own magical stop-motion worlds and movies at home.

Supported by Wairarapa Library Service.

You’ll need to download an app on your smartphone, bring a desk-lamp, a snack, your fully charged smart-phone and charger, a steady hand and an open mind. All other materials provided.

Here's the (free) app to download on your smartphone:
i-Phone:
https://apps.apple.com/nz/app/stop-motion-studio/id441651297
Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cateater.stopmotionstudio&pli=1

Ages 12 and up welcome – no prior experience required.
Places are limited to 16, so get animated!

Workshop 1-4pm, then a break, and at 5.30pm, we'll screen everyone's work.

Registration is required.
To register your interest, please email <events.waiword>.

About the tutors:

WILLIAM CONNOR
William Connor studied German, English literature, and Theatre at Victoria University in Welling-ton, where he completed his Master’s in creative writing in 2016. He lives between Berlin and Greytown, and works as a teacher, translator, editor, writer, and puppeteer. He has published numerous poems and short stories in several anthologies and journals, has written and per-formed in a number of plays that have toured New Zealand and Germany, and is the writer and cocreator of the intercultural comedy web-series Lifeswap, which explores and celebrates the differences between the German and New Zealand cultures.

STEFFEN KREFT
Steffen Kreft is an animation film director, illustrator, marionette maker and puppeteer. He was born in Münster, Germany and is currently living in Greytown in the Wairarapa.
When he first moved to New Zealand in 2007, he did his Masters in design at Massey University and co-founded the animation company National Park Studios in 2010. He taught design, animation and puppet making at Massey University and The Learning Connexion. In 2012, he directed and organised the Greytown Arts Festival and directed and made marionettes for the award winning adult puppet show “The Kitchen at the End of the World”. In 2014, Steffen and his partner William moved to Berlin for a few years where they started the popular animated web series Lifeswap about the cultural differences between New Zealand and Germany.
Now, he spends his time making short films for organisations like the French/German TV channel Arte, several New Zealand ministries, German museums and start-up companies or creates giant puppets and mesmerising marionette shows for festivals. He is also building a beautiful tiny house on wheels – apparently his most creatively challenging as well as satisfying project yet.
He has a passion for making things with his hands and while his projects are so varied, he can be very proud of the attention to detail that is obvious in all of his work.

</events.waiword>

description:
Tangihanga, Created and performed by Kristyl Neho

Tangihanga is a solo drama-comedy centred around Jess - a devoted daughter whose father, Karanipa, has passed away. As Jess’ whānau gathers at the marae to mourn, tensions rise, secrets are revealed, and long-held family dynamics begin to unravel. Neho masterfully embodies over 30 characters, capturing the complexity of grief, cultural identity, and the strength of whānau. This bold, emotionally charged, and often hilarious performance speaks to the heart of Aotearoa.

“A graceful celebration of the power of theatre to create and tell a story.” - Tanya Piejus, Regional News

Audience care: Contains themes of grief and loss. Recommended for audiences aged 9+.

description:
Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton in concert, Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton in concert
DATE: Saturday Sept 27
TIME: 7pm
LOCATION: The Offering – 65 Main St, Greytown
AGES:
COST: $25 pp at the door or booking link below

Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton are two of New Zealand’s best-known folk musicians. They bring their deep musical connection to festivals across New Zealand, playing their favourite songs and tunes collected over years of playing together at festivals, stages and late into the night at kitchen tables. Based in Wellington, Bob is one of NZ’s best-known folk songwriters and a favourite with Greytown audiences. His songs have been covered by artists in NZ, Australia, the UK and the USA. New Zealand Musician magazine compared his songwriting to Bruce Springsteen and Mark Knopfler; the Dominion Post likened him to Jackson Brown, James Taylor, Luka Bloom and Dougie Ma¬cLean. A guitarist, he is known for his distinctive open-tuned acoustic fingerstyle and electric guitar playing. He has toured widely in NZ, Australia, Canada, Ireland, the UK and the USA. His latest album, released in June 2024, is Lost Stars, an extended release on CD and download featuring new recordings and rarities, with Emily on violin and piano.

From Whangarei, Emily is a virtuoso violinist inspired by the Scottish tradition and the modern trad movement. Classically trained, she is infinitely adaptable with her gorgeous stylings and fiery tune playing, making her the perfect foil for Bob’s lyrical songs.

Don’t miss a chance to see these two consummate musicians share their foot-stomping collection of banging tunes, favourite songs and stolen moments from the last 20 years.

Book your tickets here:
https://greytownarttown.com/bob-mcneill-and-emily-roughton-in-concert/

description:
Film Talks At Aratoi Presents the Bride of Frankenstein (1935), Film Talks at Aratoi presents The Bride of Frankenstein (1935)
Halloween Film Night 2025

Get ready for a night of cinematic chills and festive frights! Since 2022, Film Talks’ Halloween Film Night has brought Wairarapa audiences together to celebrate classic horror in a fun, immersive atmosphere.

This year, join us on Halloween night for James Whale’s masterpiece, The Bride of Frankenstein (1935). Widely regarded as one of the greatest horror films ever made, it combines unforgettable imagery, Gothic atmosphere, and a surprising touch of dark humour.

Doors open at 6:45 pm, and the movie begins at 7 pm at Aratoi, 12 Bruce Street, Masterton. Running time: 75 minutes.

Costumes encouraged! Spot prizes will be awarded for the best dressed, adding to the spirit of the night. Bring friends, family, or come on your own and join a community of film lovers for playful scares, shared laughs, and a celebration of classic cinema.

Reserve Your Seats. Koha welcome — suggested $5. Your contribution helps keep Film Talks alive and accessible for our community.

Presented by Film Talks, and Aratoi, in association with the Wellington Heritage Festival.

Step into the shadows this Halloween and celebrate the 90th anniversary of one of cinema’s most haunting Gothic classics!

description:
Film fundraiser for Gaza - Where Olive Trees Weep, Feeling heartbroken about what's currently happening in Palestine? Want to learn more, watch a good film and donate money directly to those in Gaza?
Pay what you can for the ticket, all of the ticket price will be donated. Ticket includes the movie and a cup of tea. 
Baking available on the night for a small cost. 
Optional discussion after the film. 
Where are the proceeds going? All film ticket money and donations made via Humanatix or bank account prior to the film screening or raised on the night will be donated through ‘Emily Writes’ connection to mutual aid funds directly in Gaza to provide water tankers and tents.
Film info: https://whereolivetreesweep.com/
Film synopsis: "Where Olive Trees Weep offers a searing window into the struggles and resilience of the Palestinian people under Israeli occupation. It explores themes of loss, trauma, and the quest for justice.
We follow, among others, Palestinian journalist and therapist Ashira Darwish, grassroots activist Ahed Tamimi, and Israeli journalist Amira Hass. We also witness Dr. Gabor Maté offer trauma-healing work to a group of women who were tortured in Israeli prisons.
Ancient landscapes bear deep scars, having witnessed the brutal reality of ancestral land confiscation, expulsions, imprisonment, home demolitions, water deprivation, and denial of basic human rights. Yet, through the veil of oppression, we catch a glimpse of resilience—deep roots that have carried the Palestinian people through decades of darkness and shattered lives.
This emotional journey bares the humanity of the oppressed while grappling with the question: what makes the oppressor so ruthlessly blind to its own cruelty?"
label: Film & Media

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Film screening: GAGA
Join us for a special screening of the 2022 Taiwanese comedy-drama film GAGA, featuring a Q&A with the award-winning Director, Laha Mebow

About this Event

Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.

Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.


Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

description:
Next Gen Cook Off, The Next Gen Cook Off returns for its fifth year, and things are heating up at Everybody Eats.
Every Monday in August, four of Wellington’s freshest young chefs will go head-to-head in a high-energy kitchen takeover, serving up epic three-course dinners using rescued food.

Each chef will be given the same protein, generously provided by Meat Direct, but everything else is a surprise—ingredients are revealed that morning, based on what’s come in. Menus are created on the spot, and dishes are served to a buzzing, hungry crowd. It’s fast-paced, creative chaos with serious culinary skills on display. Guests get a front-row seat to the action, while supporting a truly game-changing enterprise.

4 August — Jessie Gibberd, Loretta
Originally from rural Waikato, Jessie Gibberd made the move to Wellington to study, but it was the buzz of hospitality that captured her heart. Swapping textbooks for tongs, she left her degree behind to dive headfirst into the kitchen. Now a chef de partie at Loretta, Jessie brings a grounded, fresh perspective to one of the city’s most beloved eateries.

11 August — Felipe Molina, El Matador
Hailing from Chile, Felipe Molina is a professional chef with over 15 years of experience in kitchens around the world. Having worked in several countries and world-class restaurants, Felipe brings a global sensibility to his craft. With a passion for seafood, meats, and bold, expressive flavours, his cooking is shaped by travel and tradition, blending international influence with creativity on every plate.

18 August — Zane Gupwell, Graze
Zane Gupwell began his hospitality journey at just 15, washing dishes at a local café in Mount Eden. From there, he headed to Queenstown, learning from a wide range of chefs and kitchen styles before challenging himself with a move to Wellington. Since then, he’s worked at some of the city’s top restaurants and now brings his thoughtful, evolving style to Graze Wine Bar.

25 August — Lulu Temmuyin, Mr Go’s
Lulu Temmuyin is a chef who loves pushing boundaries, even when they’re unexpected. Lactose intolerant but obsessed with cheese, and not a fan of lamb but winner of a lamb cooking competition, Lulu is all about surprises. At Mr Go’s, she brings bold, sustainable flavour to the forefront, blending personality with punch in every dish.

Everybody Eats runs on a pay-what-you-can model, transforming food waste into gourmet meals and bringing the community together over good kai. The Next Gen Cook Off celebrates and champions this mission, proving that rescued food can be next-level delicious.

The Next Gen Cook Off is proudly supported by The Gas Hub.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career, Flying a tattered flag for New Zealand film: Rudall Hayward’s 60-year career
In this month’s Friends of the Turnbull event, author and lecturer Annabel Cooper will talk about researching New Zealand filmmaker Rudall Hayward, best known for his silent films but also his later feature films ‘Rewi’s Last Stand’ and ‘To Love a Māori’.

Join us at the Library or online. Register if you’d like to join this talk and we'll send you the link to use on the day:

Rediscovering Rudall Hayward
Join us for a fascinating talk by historian and author Annabel Cooper as she delves into the life and legacy of Rudall Hayward — a trailblazer of New Zealand filmmaking.

Although not widely known today, Rudall’s career spanned from the early 1900s to the 1970s. He made four feature-length films during New Zealand’s silent film era, later navigating the financial challenges of accessing new sound equipment to make documentaries, educational films, and two more feature films — Rewi’s Last Stand (1940) and the first New Zealand film to be shot in colour, To Love a Māori (1972).

Drawing on research for her biography of Rudall Hayward and his family, Annabel Cooper will explore his enduring contributions to cinema, his collaborative work with his wives Hilda and Ramai, and the cultural legacy he left behind.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Associate Professor Annabel Cooper taught at the University of Otago for 30 years, and published on a number of New Zealand topics including gender history and film. Her last book, Filming the Colonial Past: The New Zealand Wars on Screen, is the subject of an exhibition, He Riri Awatea: Filming the New Zealand Wars, curated with Ariana Tikao for the New Zealand Portrait Gallery and now showing at Canterbury Museum.

The Sameer Project is an on-the-ground aid organisation organised by Palestinians in the diaspora, which crowdfunds in order to provide tents, medical care and direct cash aid to those most affected in Gaza. They can be found on Instagram at @thesameerproject.
More information:
Jenin Jenin includes testimony from Jenin residents after the Israeli army’s Defensive Shield operation, during which the city and camp were the scenes of fierce fighting. The operation ended with Jenin flattened and scores of Palestinians killed. Palestinians as well as numerous human rights groups accused Israel of committing war crimes in the April 2002 attack on the refugee camp. The sad question forces itself on the spectator: What will become of a country, a people when its children are confronted with war and violence from a very early age?

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Linda Linda Linda - Fundraiser for Burmese Punks!, The Freedom Shop are hosting another movie night and we would love to see you there.
LINDA LINDA LINDA (Nobuhiro Yamashita, Japan, 2005)

Fundraiser for Burmese punks - Koha entry.

Since the military overthrow of a semi-democratic government in 2021, Burma has been immersed in a civil war, three million people have been displaced, many now living as refugees in surrounding countries. Over half of the country has been liberated by opposition armed groups, but the regime hangs on, using air strikes, forced conscription and brutality to control the main cities and areas of economic value. Amongst the opposition is the punk movement that has led protests, organised Food not Bombs groups, food gardens, social centres and other projects, both inside and outside the country, all run on the smell of an oily rag. Your dollar goes further when it’s in the hands of punks.

We are screening Linda Linda Linda – a low-key, cheerful but by no means saccharine, 2005 Japanese film that actually gets punk. It has the same plot as every other rock movie, except this one is believable. Four grumpy teenagers are empowered through a willingness to accept outsiders, music and friendship.

Burmese food from 6pm, a short talk about the situation at 7pm followed by the film.

French Film Screening - Chien de la Casse, 🎬 Join us for a screening of Chien de la casse (Junkyard Dog) - a gritty and quietly powerful French drama exploring friendship, masculinity, and emotional repression in a small town in France.
The plot 👉 In a sleepy village in the South of France, Dog and Mirales have been inseparable since childhood. Their bond is strong but also marked by teasing and power games - until a new arrival, Elsa, disrupts the dynamic. As Dog starts to drift toward this budding romance, Mirales is left grappling with jealousy, vulnerability, and the fear of being left behind.
The trailer 👉 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCv83D3CQOY
Chien de la casse is a nuanced and touching debut feature by Jean-Baptiste Durand - a subtle portrait of male friendship, emotional fragility, and the unspoken tensions of rural life.
This film is rated R13 – Restricted to persons 13 years and over (Violence, offensive language, drug use & sex scenes).
📅 Friday, 05 September 2025 - 6pm
📍 Alliance Française, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎥 French VO with English Subtitles

description:
Mother Tongue: A Sri Lankan food story • WLG screening, Motivated by things that are very tasty, Bhagya and Carl travel to the motherland of Sri Lanka to document forest gardens, coconut mills, rice paddies and Aachi’s house. After a couple years bringing Lankan flavours to the people of Ōtepoti - and armed with the cultural knowledge of diaspora kids - they want to know: Who grew this and why is it so delicious?
Follow us on IG: @media_syndicate
A true labour of love, this film was created to honour the people who put so much work into the food we eat. To this end, proceeds will be donated to our friends at The Movement for Land and Agricultural Reform (MONLAR) so that they can continue in their work for a cooperative, ecological and just food system.
MONLAR's mission is to "cooperate towards building a peoples movement by capacity building and mobilizing of small farmers and marginalized communities, who have become victims of the globalization structures, to protect natural resources and human rights and to lobby for change and implement alternative policies that are favorable and sustainable."
Running time: 42 minutes + QnA with filmmaker Bhagya Herath
label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: DJ Ahmet, Ahmet stumbles upon a forest rave at the edge of his local village, where he finds the escape he’s been desperately seeking in Georgi M. Unkovski’s loveable debut, the first ever Macedonian film to be awarded at Sundance.

Still reeling from the death of their mother and wife, Ahmet’s family is broken. His father, struggling to come to terms with being sole provider and caretaker for the family, pulls Ahmet from school so he can care for their flock of sheep; meanwhile, his younger brother has become non-verbal since their mother’s death. Music is both medicine and matchmaker for young Ahmet, who escapes his grief and the grim mundanity of life under his oppressive father by blasting beats from the world’s jankiest stereo system to impress local girl Aya, back from Germany to be betrothed to an older man.

In this modern-day Romeo and Juliet, the Yuruk mountain village of Kodzalia takes the place of Verona, while the Montagues and Capulets make way for an eclectic support cast, with a technophobic imam, a souped-up tractor and a fluorescent pink sheep all taking the stage. If music be the food of love, then DJ Ahmet is a feast of thumping electro and dance-floor anthems that spur on the teenage protagonist as he fumbles through the throes of his first romance. A jubilant first feature and a real charmer. — Matt Bloomfield
label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: Deaf, A woman navigates the experience of motherhood as a deaf person in a hearing world in Eva Libertad’s crowd-pleasing, feel-good drama which collected the Panaroma Audience Award at Berlin this year.

Based on the award-winning short of the same name, Spanish filmmaker Eva Libertad’s debut follows couple Ángela and Héctor as they make the transition into parenthood. Ángela is deaf. Héctor is not. When she tells them she’s pregnant, her own parents can’t hide their shock – loving but concerned that their daughter will be unable to tackle the task of motherhood. Will the baby be born deaf? Uncertainty abounds as the due date draws closer, and it’s not just Ángela’s parents who are beginning to have doubts.

The foundations for the film’s narrative derive from the personal experiences of first-time actor Miriam Garlo, Libertad’s own sister, as she began to contemplate motherhood as a deaf woman. When surrounded by her other deaf friends, Ángela is comfortable, alive, vibrant within a community that supports her. Around the local mums in the park, or her husband’s friends, isolation sets in with a painful immediacy that anyone who has ever struggled to understand the language in a foreign country will know all too well. A poignant story bound by the chemistry of its leads, deafness is woven into the film as a lived experience, not a defining label. — Matt Bloomfield
label: Film & Media
