description:
WCC "Tequila and Salsa night!", Hello again bartenders from all walks of life! Brush up on your Tequila knowledge and your Salsa recipes because the next Wellington Cocktail Competition is just around the corner!
As to the theme for this WCC, it is “Tequila and Salsa food pairing” The hero spirit this time around will be a surprise tequila on the night, but I can tell you it will be a reposado. The catch is, you have to pair it with a salsa that you make yourself. There are no limits on the style of cocktail you want this time around, so get creative!
If you would like to participate, get in touch with me or Dan ASAp as we were running low on time to organize this time around.
Minimum 30ml of Tequila must be used in the drink and as always must be the hero spirit of the night.
You will be making two drinks for the judges to try and 5 minutes to make two servings of your cocktail and serve your salsa.
The judges may also be coerced with bribes and favours during your presentation.
The event will be on 28th of September and the competition will start at 6pm.
If you have any questions about the competition, please ask either me or Dan.
The main aim of this cocktail competition is to help those who may not have entered comps before, gain a bit of confidence and experience, or for people who haven’t entered a comp in a while, to shake off those cobwebs.
It also a chance to meet new people and introduce newcomers to the Wellington bar scene. Most of all the idea is to have fun!
Each competitor will have 5 minutes to make and present two servings of their drink.
All Tequila and corn chips for your salsa will be provided, but you will have to source your own ingredients including citrus and sugar syrup. Glassware and ice will be provided, you are more than welcome to bring specialty equipment and ingredients, however you will be marked on how easy your drink is to replicate.
The competition will be judged by a panel of 3 judges. While knowing your stuff is important, brand knowledge is not the key here. This comp is to engage bartenders in a fun comp environment, so drink and personality are just as important.
Competitors will be first come first serve, so message either me or Dan if you want to be entered, there are 10 spots for the night and there will be prizes for the winner.
There will be drink deals on the night, and make sure you bring your friends, workmates, parents ect ect to cheer you on and heckle the other competitors…
See you all there!

description:
Boost Your Business: Take the Stress Out of Digital Marketing, Take the Stress Out of Digital Marketing
Calling all Pasifika entrepreneurs, small business owners, and innovators in the Wellington region.

Join us for a free, hands-on workshop led by Katie Brown. We’ll break down digital marketing and social media into clear, actionable tools you can use immediately. You’ll do this in a friendly and open environment, where you can ask questions, share ideas, and learn from others. Plus, enjoy refreshments and kai (catered by Amilagis) to keep you energised.

By the end of the workshop, you’ll leave with real, usable tools. This is perfect for anyone in Wellington wanting to build confidence online, make social media easier, and drive forward your business idea.

Attending these workshops gives you the chance to join the WLG NZ RPBN programme, where Katie’s full course supports your next steps in growing your digital presence. Spaces are limited, book your spot today and step into your digital strength!

**Doors open at 5.30pm, session begins at 6pm**

About the Speaker:
Katie Brown (Ngāti Whātua, Ngāti Raukawa) brings over 15+ years’ experience in social media, digital strategy, and communications. She’s the founder of Social Good and has held key roles in government and corporate spheres, including setting up ACC’s social media strategy and leading Aotearoa’s all-of-government digital communications response during COVID-19. Katie is also a certified Meta (Facebook) Community Trainer and regularly delivers workshops across Aotearoa, helping organisations to tell stronger digital stories.

description:
COFFEE & CLAY Hand build your own ceramic butter dish, Join us for a relaxed, hands-on workshop where you'll create your very own ceramic butter dish in a working pottery studio. Over two inspiring hours, you'll learn the basics of hand-building with clay, guided step-by-step by a ceramic artist.
Enjoy fresh coffee and a home-baked morning tea as you get creative with shaping, decorating, and embellishing your piece. You'll finish by choosing your preferred glaze colours, and we'll take care of the firing process. Your finished butter dish will be ready to collect approximately four weeks later.
This small group workshop is perfect for absolute beginners—no experience needed. Come solo and meet like-minded creatives, or bring a friend for a fun and mindful morning.
You’ll be amazed at how calming it is to get out of your head and into your hands!

description:
Writing Off The Map: Anna Jackson and Rachel O'Neill | Writers on Mondays, Nina Mingya Powles calls Anna Jackson's Terrier, Worrier 'a remarkable and playful book on language, anxiety, poetry, and the strangeness of being a person'. Somewhere between a diary and a collection of poetic essays, it takes Jackson's work into previously uncharted territory.
Equally off the charts is film-maker, writer, and artist Rachel O'Neill's Symphony of Queer Errands, a delightfully riotous musical fantasia and an irreverent ode to queer joy.
Chris Price will pilot the conversation between these adventurous voyagers in unknown seas.

Writers on Mondays is presented by the International Institute of Modern Letters and Te Papa Tongarewa. The 2025 series will run from 12.15—1.15 pm each Monday from 7 July to 29 September at Te Papa Tongarewa and Circa Theatre, with two special evening sessions at Meow. Admission is free and all are welcome. The series is supported by the Letteri family.

description:
Peter Hook and The Light, Bassist Peter Hook has intimate knowledge of the music of bands Joy Division and New Order. He’s one of the founding members of both British new wave bands. In July 2026, he is bringing his band The Light to The Opera House in Wellington. Together they will perform New Order’s album ‘Get Ready’ in full to celebrate its 25th anniversary. To make the concert even better, they will also perform a selection of greatest hits from Joy Division’s and New Order’s back catalogue. Get ready to enjoy songs like Disorder, Shadowplay, Transmission, Love Will Tear Us Apart, Blue Monday, and True Faith. 
The dark and ethereal sound of Joy Division and New Order ushered in the post-punk era and continue to be influential in the rock music scene. Peter Hook and The Light are careful to meticulously recreate their music in a live setting. Audiences are in for a show where treasured songs are played with the passion and energy they deserve.

description:
HineHau Breathwork for Women, Join Shannon Rose for this unique three-hour breathwork workshop for all wāhine.

Through story, breath, and reflection, you’ll learn and experience the power of your breath as a wāhine: to cleanse, to create, and to consciously live in alignment with who you are.

Shannon has been immersed in the practice of breath since 2017 and is recognised as one of the pioneers of breathwork in Aotearoa. She is the founder of HineHau, a breathwork training kaupapa supporting wāhine to step into leadership and facilitation through the breath.

In this workshop, you’ll be safely guided on a journey of remembrance, reconnection, and reclamation. Expect to come away feeling grounded, rejuvenated, and more at home in your body.

What’s Included
*Karakia to open and close our space
*Purākau — Māori creation stories on the whakapapa of the breath
*Kōrero — how intentional breathing helps to align your mauri, wairua and mana
*Working with the nervous system to support manifestation and creativity
*BreathWav™ Journey — a 70-minute circular connected breath practice for release, alignment, and deep connection
*Journaling & Reflection to integrate what arises.

What to Bring
Water bottle, a journal + pen and an eye mask. Mats, blankets & supportive props provided.

Who This is For
This workshop is open to wāhine of all cultures who are ready to experience the healing power of Te Hā — the sacred breath.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
A Century Celebration!, A Century Celebration!
In 1926, at a meeting at the Accounts Chambers in Johnston Street, Wellington, Mrs JW Bell (and her husband) offered to lease three sections of her land for the purposes of establishing a tennis and bowling club in Titahi Bay.

Well Mrs Bell, thanks to your kind offer, we are still here 100 years later and don’t we have some stories and memories to share of those years gone by!

Over the course of Wellington Anniversary weekend (16-18 January 2026), we invite current and former members of the Titahi Bay Tennis Club to come and join us in celebrating this incredible milestone!

In coming months, we will update this post with more information about events planned for the weekend. In the meantime, please put this in your diary, share with friends, family, or perhaps use it as an opportunity to reach out to a former interclub team mate you haven’t seen or heard from in a while and tell them you’ll see them there!

We hope you can join us for what should be a great occasion!



(article : https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19270114.2.141)

description:
Costuming Austen's Characters, Costuming Austen's Characters
Join us for a talk about dressing Jane Austen's characters for the stage

About this Event

Costuming Austen's Characters - Reschedule of May Event (slightly later start)
Following on from our panel discussion with the writers and directors of local Austen productions we welcome costumier Meredith Dooley who worked on dressing the actors for all those productions.
Meredith Dooley is a Wellington born and bred actor, director and costumier. She completed a BA in Theatre and Film at Victoria University of Wellington in the early 1990s, and then trained in acting and directing in London. In 2018-19 she gained a Diploma in Costume Construction at Toi Whakaari New Zealand Drama School and spent the next two Covid-affected years working on theatre, film and television productions such as Wellington Paranormal, Mr Corman, WOW, and Wellington Opera's Don Giovanni.
Meredith has returned to the office and over the last few years has created costumes for Stagecraft's Pride & Prejudice and Persuasion, and KAT Theatre's Sense and Sensibility, amongst others. Early in 2024 she dipped her toes back into professional theatre, working with cabaret star Meow Meow during the NZ Festival of the Arts.

Afternoon tea provided

description:

✨ Erskine Chapel Open Day & Craft Market ✨
📅 Sunday, 2 November 2025 | 10:00am – 3:00pm
📍 Erskine Chapel, 31 Avon Street, Island Bay, Wellington

Nestled high on the hillside in Island Bay, Erskine Chapel is a breathtaking and iconic landmark, with sweeping views across the hills and ocean, and a gothic charm that has captured hearts for generations.

Now in its third year, this much loved annual event returns as part of Heritage Month, celebrating the beauty, history, and cultural significance of one of Wellington’s most treasured buildings.

Foxtail Events and The Wellington Company are once again partnering to open the chapel’s doors for the community, inviting everyone to experience this remarkable space brought back to life.

Join us for a special Community Open Day and Craft Market, where you can:

* Explore a curated market of local artisans and makers
* Discover the chapel’s rich history and stunning architecture
* Enjoy live music, freshly brewed coffee, and delicious baked goods

Whether you're drawn by the history, the creativity, or the peaceful atmosphere, this is a day to celebrate local talent and honour the legacy of a true Wellington landmark.

🗓️ Mark your calendar and don’t miss this enchanting day at Erskine Chapel. A place of stories, memories, and timeless beauty, reawakened for a new generation to enjoy.

description:
NZIFF: DJ Ahmet, Ahmet stumbles upon a forest rave at the edge of his local village, where he finds the escape he’s been desperately seeking in Georgi M. Unkovski’s loveable debut, the first ever Macedonian film to be awarded at Sundance.

Still reeling from the death of their mother and wife, Ahmet’s family is broken. His father, struggling to come to terms with being sole provider and caretaker for the family, pulls Ahmet from school so he can care for their flock of sheep; meanwhile, his younger brother has become non-verbal since their mother’s death. Music is both medicine and matchmaker for young Ahmet, who escapes his grief and the grim mundanity of life under his oppressive father by blasting beats from the world’s jankiest stereo system to impress local girl Aya, back from Germany to be betrothed to an older man.

In this modern-day Romeo and Juliet, the Yuruk mountain village of Kodzalia takes the place of Verona, while the Montagues and Capulets make way for an eclectic support cast, with a technophobic imam, a souped-up tractor and a fluorescent pink sheep all taking the stage. If music be the food of love, then DJ Ahmet is a feast of thumping electro and dance-floor anthems that spur on the teenage protagonist as he fumbles through the throes of his first romance. A jubilant first feature and a real charmer. — Matt Bloomfield
label: Film & Media

Looking to meet new friends to hang out with, or maybe find love in a comfortable, respectful environment? Join us for a speed dating event designed specifically for autistic adults in Wellington!

This inclusive and sensory-considerate evening is all about meaningful conversations and low-pressure socializing. Whether you’re looking for friendship, romance, or just a fun evening out, this is your chance to connect in a space designed with your needs in mind.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

Accessibility and Comfort:
We’re committed to making this event as accessible and welcoming as possible. Sensory-friendly spaces, quiet zones, and fidget-friendly items will be available. There will also be conversation prompts on the table. Let us know any additional accommodations you may need when registering.

All genders and sexualities are welcome to come and mingle and meet others for friendship but the speed dating part of this evening works best for heterosexual people.

description:
Hutt Japan Day 2025, Hutt Japan Day 2025
Hutt Japan Day is back!
Join us for a vibrant celebration of Japanese culture at the Hutt Japan Day festival, held at the Lower Hutt Town Hall, Dowse Square & Dowse Art Gallery on Sunday, 9 November.

Celebrating 30 Years of Friendship
This year's event is extra special, marking 30 years of partnership with Minoh City, our sister city in Osaka, Japan. The festival is organised by the Hutt Minoh House Friendship Trust, with support from the Hutt City Council and the Embassy of Japan.

What’s on offer?
• Be captivated by an array of Japanese performances and demonstrations
• Engage in hands-on activities and workshops
• Immerse yourself in the exhilarating rhythms of taiko drumming
• Indulge in delectable Japanese cuisine from one of our food vendors/stalls
• Explore our market area for unique Japanese treasures

Get Involved!
To participate in this special celebration as a performer, artist, cultural group, demonstration, market or food vendor, please visit our website for more details and registration forms: https://www.huttminoh.org.nz/participate-in-hutt-japan-day-2025

Save the Date - Sunday, 9 November 2025
Lower Hutt Town Hall, Dowse Square & The Dowse Art Museum

We look forward to celebrating the richness of Japanese culture with you!

description:
Brazilian Zouk - Abertura & Soltinho Variations, Come and join us for Improvers Zouk Block E (5 weeks).
We have some great new content for you this year and will be building on foundational movements.
The complete Improvers course consists of 6 different Blocks (A-F).
Each block focuses on a different aspect and technique of Brazilian Zouk and so they can be completed independently of each other.
Our recommendation is to complete all 6 Blocks before progressing onto the Brazilian Zouk Deep Dive classes.
In Improvers Block E you will get an Variations on Abertura and Soltinho as well as some exercises on Personal body movement technique.
===Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week Block cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students
- Ad hoc cost per class is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students
Online payments can be made to Adam Polaczuk
Acct: 03-0531-0559348-25
Details: Your name and ZoukImpE
===Location:
Classes are in Footnote dance studio, 60 Dixon Street
===Housekeeping:
- You should have completed the 4 beginner Class blocks before joining Improvers classes
- Drop in or new students, please get in contact before the start of class to let us know you are interested so we can assess your level and organise a private class if necessary to catch you up. If you just show up on the night, you are welcome to watch the class but will not be able to join in (this is to respect the learning of our regular students as the classes are progressive)

description:
Brazilian Zouk Dance Classes - Beginners Block B, Connect with other like minded people that have a love of dance.
Brazilian Zouk was developed in Rio de Janeiro in the mid 90s, and is now becoming more and more popular
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfhRHnEAbak
..............
This is stunning to watch and even more fun to dance! It is based on the original Lambada dance but adapted to more modern music with a slow-quick-quick beat. It can be danced to a wide variety of music including R&B, Rock and Pop.
In this block of 5 classes you will discover the fundamental techniques, movements and sequences of Brazilian Zouk to get you up and running on the dance floor.
This includes:
Week 1: Passo basico
Week 2: Lateral
Week 3: Io-Io
Week 4: Bonus
Week 5: Combination
They are designed so you can start this block as a complete newbie, or you can continue on as an existing student from the last block.
There are 4 blocks of classes (A, B, C, D) in the complete Fundamentals course. Once these are done, you can progress to the Improvers classes.
Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week term cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students.
- Ad hoc cost is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students
Online payments can be made to Adam Polaczuk
Acct: 03-0531-0559348-25

description:
Not ya nanas market, Not ya nanas market
*Strictly R18*
Get ready to immerse yourself in a world where art and craft meet the dark and mysterious. This market is not for the faint of heart! Here's what you can expect:
1. Creepy-Cute Delights: Explore a wide range of art and craft creations that blend the creepy and cute aesthetics. From adorable monsters to spooky dolls, you'll find something to tickle your fancy.
2. Witchy Wonders: Dive into the world of witchcraft and magic. Discover spellbinding artwork, mystical jewelry, and enchanting potions. Embrace your inner witch or warlock!
3. Kinky Curiosities: For those who enjoy a touch of kink, we have a selection of unique and provocative art and crafts, and kink wear. Explore the boundaries of sensuality and embrace your desires in a safe and inclusive environment.
4. Sexy Sensations: Indulge in the world of sensuality and erotic art. Discover captivating paintings, sculptures, and photography that celebrate the beauty of the human form. Embrace your sexuality with pride!
5. LGBTQIA+ Friendly: This market is a safe space for all members of the LGBTQIA+ community. Celebrate diversity and inclusivity as you explore the wide range of art and craft offerings.
6. Alternative Art and Craft: Step outside the mainstream and explore the alternative side of creativity. From gothic to steampunk, from punk to cyberpunk, you'll find a variety of unique and unconventional art and craft pieces.
Don't miss out on this extraordinary event! Mark your calendars and invite your friends. Get ready to be amazed, inspired, and maybe even a little bit spooked. See you at the Creepy-Cute, Witchy, Kinky, Sexy, LGBTQIA+ Friendly Alternative Art and Craft Market!
$5 cash only door entry
It definitely will NOT be your nana's market! See less

description:
Make Some Noise - choral music that matters, After a successful performance of Mozart’s classic Requiem in D Minor in May, Supertonic is back with a programme of contemporary choral music that matters. 
On the evening of Saturday 8 November, Supertonic will present Make Some Noise at the Lower Hutt Town Hall. This is the first time the choir has performed in the Hutt Valley, and they hope to see some new faces in the audience as they bring this programme of  meaningful music from around the world to the stage.  
Make Some Noise highlights issues of social justice, including indigenous, women’s and civil rights and climate action. The programme is rich and varied, from Katerina Gimon’s arrangement of AURORA’s Apple Tree, a Norwegian pop song addressing the urgency of the global climate crisis, to Robert T. Gibson’s arrangement of the gospel standard This Little Light of Mine. Oliassa by Malika Tirolien utilises an invented language to invoke a call from the ancestors, while Alex Vollant titles their piece Auass meaning “child” in the Innu language to honour the generation of elders who survived the Residential Schools in Canada. The impact of sexual harassment and assault on women is highlighted in MILCK’s I Can’t Keep Quiet  and Lillia Ruocco and Emmanuelle Ader’s Canzone rò curtiell’. Closer to home, Make Some Noise features a set of waiata in teo reo Māori to highlight the importance of indigenous voices in Aotearoa New Zealand, including Ngoi Pēwhairangi’s Whakarongo. This waiata-ā-ringa incorporates Ngoi Pēwhairangi’s beliefs and methodology on teaching te reo Māori.   
Led by co-Musical Director Virginie Pacheco, Supertonic offers Make Some Noise as an invitation to concert-goers to consider the causes that are important to them. In connecting with audiences through the striking and impactful works of the composers featured in this programme - by turns harmonious, raucous, gut-wrenching, resolute - the choir hopes to inspire those listening to make some noise in their own lives. 
Supertonic was formed in 2014 in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, and strives to  push the boundaries of what choral music can be. The choir has performed concerts that cover the entire musical spectrum, from major classical works including Vaughan Williams' Mass in G Minor, Vivaldi's Gloria and Faure's Requiem to pop and rock spectaculars celebrating hits of the 70s, 80s and 90s from the likes of Fleetwood Mac, David Bowie, Elton John, Queen, and Celine Dion. The choir has performed alongside The Royal New Zealand Airforce Band, joined Brett McKenzie, the NZSO and The Muppets for the Jim Henson Retrospectacle,  shared the stage with Mama Kin Spender at Coastella, and performed in national civic commemorations, street festivals and at community events.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Together in Dialogue: Te Tiriti o Waitangi and Pacific Partnerships, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Pacific style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and effective insights. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from different communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Together in Dialogue?
In Together in Dialogue, you will share meaningful conversations around Te Tiriti o Waitangi and the role and responsibilities of Pasifika as allies. By engaging in deep talanoa, you will explore cultural, historical, and contemporary implications of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and how Pasifika people can strengthen this unique relationship and promote cultural awareness.
This is a 3.5 hour in-person learning experience. The day will begin with a Pōwhiri, to welcome you into the space.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Resilient Waters: NZ–German Conference, Strengthening Urban Water Systems Against Extreme Weather – German Insights for Aotearoa

New Zealand’s water infrastructure is under growing pressure from climate change, ageing systems, and extreme weather events. Ensuring safe drinking water, reliable wastewater management, and resilient infrastructure requires fresh thinking and innovative solutions.
The Resilient Waters Conference, hosted by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC), will bring together German innovators and New Zealand stakeholders for a high-level forum dedicated to future-proofing New Zealand’s water systems.
At this conference, a delegation of German companies will present cutting-edge technologies and intelligent system solutions designed to improve water resilience in the face of climate change. The programme will feature expert presentations, sector-specific insights, and networking opportunities with a professional audience from water utilities, engineering firms, city councils, and decision-making bodies.
Following the conference, the programme for the delegation will continue with B2B meetings, expert roundtables, and site visits in Wellington, Hawke’s Bay, and Auckland from 17–21 November 2025. These tailored sessions will connect German companies directly with New Zealand stakeholders to exchange knowledge, explore collaboration, and identify concrete opportunities for partnership.
 This initiative is organised by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC) in collaboration with German partner AHP International and funded by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWE).

description:
Perfect Days, Come along to our free Japanese Film night, co-organised with the Japan Foundation, Sydney!

Synopsis
Hirayama seems utterly content with his simple life as a cleaner of toilets in Tokyo. Outside of his very structured everyday routine he enjoys his passion for music and for books. And he loves trees and takes photos of them. A series of unexpected encounters gradually reveal more of his past. A deeply moving and poetic reflection on finding beauty in the everyday world around us.
Director: Wim Wenders / Classification: M / Year: 2023 / Genre: Drama
Language: Japanese with English subtitles

Copyright:© 2023 Master Mind Ltd.

A short Japan Video Topics DVD will be shown from 5:15pm before the start of the film at 5:30pm. Free admission is based on a first-come, first-served basis, with a full theatre capacity of 40 people. No food is permitted in the theatre

The Kava Experience, Bula Vinaka and Welcome to Kava Culture, New Zealand’s newest destination for authentic Fijian Kava!

At Kava Culture, we offer a premium, traditionally brewed kava experience designed for wellness-focused individuals seeking natural relaxation. We pride ourselves on sourcing our kava directly from small Pacific Island farms, ensuring unparalleled quality and authenticity.
Immerse yourself in the rich traditions of the Pacific as you enjoy our exquisite kava in our calm, serene location at Kaitahi, beautifully illuminated by ambient lights. This is more than just a drink; it's an opportunity to connect with others, promote genuine stress relief, and celebrate ancient island culture with modern comfort.
Join us for a night filled with community, connection, and tranquility. Let Kava Culture transport you – no passport required!
Choose your journey:

* Full Experience: $50 (3 hours)
We can’t wait to welcome you!

description:
YT | WELLINGTON | MEOW, YT | WELLINGTON | MEOW
UK’s breakout rap sensation YT hits Australia & New Zealand this October.

Sign up for presale and get first access to tickets 👉🏻 https://go.astralpeople.com/YT-PS

YT has carved out a lane entirely his own — a sound built on electrifying jerk beats, autotuned hooks that stick in your head, and a razor-sharp lyrical style that’s as witty as it is unapologetic.
From his cult SoundCloud tape #SWAGRENAISSANCE to his viral hit “Black and Tan” with Lancey Foux, he’s established a distinctive British sound that’s turning heads worldwide.

In just two years, he’s gone from Oxford student to millions of streams and headline shows across Europe. Tracks like Prada or Celine and MVP have only fuelled the fire, and his latest tape OI! proves why he’s one of the most exciting voices in rap right now.

This October, YT lands in Auckland, Wellington, Melbourne, Sydney and Perth for his debut shows in Australia & New Zealand.

Expect raw energy, chaos, and the sound of rap’s next wave coming alive on stage.

2025 is already moving at full speed — and YT is only just getting started.

👑 Gather your knights, twits, and lumberjacks for:

🕺 The Ministry of Silly Walks Competition

🩸 The Black Knight’s Limb Toss (just a flesh wound)

🎩 The Upper-Class Twit of the Year Race

🐴 The Two-Person Coconut Horse Race

🌲 The Lumberjack Song Karaoke (he’s okay!)

🧠 The Monty Python Quiz (bring your brain, or a dead parrot)

🏆 Prizes to be won, dignity to be lost.

But that’s not all! Beware of French guards at the gate, pop into the Argument Tent (“This isn’t an argument!”), and expect confusion, silliness, and possibly a Spanish Inquisition (though nobody expects that).

Plus: Market stalls and Monty Python–themed drinks at the bar.

Plus Steve Poulton live music from 4.30pm.

So grab your coconuts and gallop to The Bond Store for a day you won’t forget (no matter how hard you try).

Kindly stuff your pockets with good old-fashioned cash (none of that funny monopoly money) to hurl generously at the ‘Golf is Good’ charity in exchange for your entry into the day’s utterly ridiculous games

description:
Tip Track Marathon: Cloud 9, Tip Track Marathon: Cloud 9
START TIMES:
7am - Marathon
9am - Half Marathon

Website: tiptrackmarathon.co.nz
Rego: https://tip-track-marathon.lilregie.com/booking/attendees/new

COURSE DETAILS:
Tip Track Marathon (TTM) –
Tip Track Marathon is an out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back, out-and-back type course that has proven popular with participants. Each of the six laps is slightly over 7km, with around 400m in elevation (2500m in total). Try not to trip on a loose rock while taking in the aromatic smells emanating from the tip. Ignore the gale-force northerly. It makes for a challenging marathon but you can find comfort in the other runners suffering too.
Recommended donation: $40

Half Marathon -
For those that hate themselves but not as much as the marathoners. Same course as above but three laps instead of six,
Recommended donation: $25

Tip Track Marathon (TTM) is a low-key, no frills trail running race that takes place at the Tip Track in Wellington each year - all in the name of charity. TTM is all about hard hills, high-fives, and doing something stupid for the sake of it. There are no prizes. Your workmates will not understand why you did this. It’s not even that fun.

This is a race for those that want a little more from life than the ordinary. Those that question the monotony of their daytime jobs and wonder, "isn't there meant to be more to life than this?" Enter TTM... I mean, you won't find any answers here but those are the people that tend to be attracted to it.

DONATIONS:
All entry fees charged go to our charities for 2025:
Youthline Wellington
Social Supermarket

There is a recommended donation amount for each race of $40 (TTM) or $25 (Half). These are recommended only. If you are not in a position to donate, then give whatever you can, if you earn a bit more then feel free to pop in a bit more.
Previous years we have raised:

2024 - $5,500 for the Social Supermarket and OMF
2023 - $5,125 for the Social Supermarket
2022 - $3,600 split between Trailblazers and Wellington Women's Refuge
2021 - $3,770 split between Trailblazers and Wellington Women's Refuge
2020 - $3,376 split between Challenge 2000 and Wellington Women's Refuge


The day is a celebration of the Wellington running community. It is a social, unofficial event. Come along for a run, to support, and meet some new friends along the way.

description:
Experience Heidi: A.I Medical Scribe for All Clinicians - Wellington, Experience Heidi: A.I Medical Scribe for All Clinicians - Wellington
For practices,clinics & care teams ready to adopt Heidi—the AI scribe for all clinicians. Join us in Wellington. Hosted by Hendrix Health.

About this Event



Experience the Future of Clinical Documentation with Heidi & Hendrix
This event is perfect for practices and clinics looking to bring —the AI medical scribe for all clinicians—into their organisation. Heidi can be used by doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physios, psychologists, vetenarians and more, supporting everything from patient consults and shift handovers to practice meetings and MDMs.
Built with robust data privacy and compliance in mind, Heidi scales to fit how your clinic operates, so you can spend less time on paperwork and more time on patient care. We’ll also discuss safe AI adoption in healthcare, including how Heidi respects data sovereignty in Aotearoa. This session is designed to be straightforward and practical—no hype, just a real look at how AI can transform your everyday workflow.

About Heidi is an AI-powered medical scribe designed to ease the documentation load on clinicians. Already supporting over a million patient interactions every week, Heidi transcribes and processes clinical conversations in real time—helping generate notes, letters, and assessments so clinicians can spend more time with patients and less on paperwork.
Built by a team of doctors and backed by leading global investors, Heidi has become a trusted partner for practices and clinics around the world. The technology is developed to meet international standards including HIPAA, GDPR, NHS and the Australian Privacy Principles, with enterprise-grade certifications like SOC2 and ISO27001.
Heidi never stores session recordings and does not sell or share clinical data. It's designed with clinician wellbeing, patient care, and data safety at its core. Learn more at heidihealth.com.

About
Hendrix Health, Heidi’s official partner in Aotearoa New Zealand , is dedicated to transforming healthcare through life-long learning and human-centred technology. Since September 2024, the Hendrix team have visited over 120 GP clinics, 10 hauora Māori, and 6 Pasifika providers to understand the real challenges on the ground. By working closely with local communities, Hendrix Health ensures that revolutionary innovations like Heidi are culturally responsive and truly effective—already changing the lives of 1000's of healthcare professionals across the country.


Agenda


🕑: 05:00 PM - 06:00 PM
Networking on Arrival (Whakawhanaungatanga)
Info: Arrive, grab a drink, some kai, and connect with fellow attendees. This is your chance to meet new faces, catch up with colleagues, and set a welcoming tone for the evening.


🕑: 06:00 PM - 06:10 PM
Opening Karakia & Whakatauki
Info: We’ll open with a brief karakia (blessing) to acknowledge our gathering, focus our intentions, and bring everyone together under a shared purpose. A short whakatauki will be shared, reminding us why we’re here: to improve healthcare for all in Aotearoa.



🕑: 06:10 PM - 06:15 PM
Current Pressues in your Work
Info: A quick reflection on everyday challenges—like documentation fatigue, paperwork overload, and time inefficiencies—that impact both workflow and patient care.



🕑: 06:15 PM - 06:30 PM
Heidi Demo
Info: We’ll show how Heidi fits into your clinical workflow, covering:


- Who is Heidi? Background and purpose.


- AI Scribing Basics: Four steps (Transcribe, Customise, Output, Review).


- Live Demo: A clinician–patient consultation, including informed consent and template use.


- SOAP Formatting & Note Review: How Heidi helps structure and refine notes.


- Ask Heidi Anything: See how to generate a patient letter or other documents directly from the consultation.


🕑: 06:30 PM - 06:40 PM
Principles of Safe AI Use in Healthcare/Data Handling
Info: Explore data privacy, sovereignty, and compliance in Aotearoa, plus best practices for responsibly adopting AI in clinical settings.


🕑: 06:40 PM - 06:45 PM
Karakia Whakamutunga
Info: We’ll close the formal session with a karakia, acknowledging the time shared and the insights gained.


🕑: 06:45 PM - 08:00 PM
Networking
Info: Continue conversations, ask further questions, and connect with the team. Wrap up the evening with new insights and meaningful connections.
label: Health & Wellness

Picnic tables are situated underneath the majestic Redwood Tree for you to sit and enjoy a coffee and something to eat while listening to live music. Plus you get to take home quality, delicious produce grown seasonally within the Wairarapa region. It makes for a great morning's outing.

Enjoy breakfast, brunch or lunch and pick up your dinner items with locally produced coffee, eggs, meat, berries, bread, jam, fruit, olive oil, pastries, pies, pickles, slices, cakes, soup, vegetables and more. Shop for plants, seedlings, seaweed, artisan goods including wood turning, Māori weaving, children’s and baby clothes, aprons, peg aprons, tea towels, knitted and crochet toys and hand dyed knitting wools.
Sign up for our regular Wairarapa Farmers' Market newsletter here https://mailchi.mp/d99e1ad65a18/newsletter-sign-up or join us on Facebook to get updates on all the Market goodness! Dogs are welcome to the market and a dog bowl can be provided. See you on Saturday!

description:
Altared States | Electronic Soundscapes in a Divine Place, Wellington’s iconic Old St Paul’s will play host to a transcendent new series in August, partnering with the Pyramid Club to present Altared States, a unique electronic music experience.
Set beneath the exquisite stained-glass windows of one of Te Whanganui-a-Tara’s most exquisite landmarks, this series promises an immersive sonic experience that invites audiences to explore sound in a deeply personal and transformative way.
Altared States is inspired by Brian Sweeney’s New York-founded Ambient Church, an initiative dedicated to collaborating with artists to create transformative audio performances in architecturally significant spaces. This series will immerse attendees in soundscapes that transcend the ordinary, offering a chance to disconnect for a moment from the modern world.
Each of the evenings will bring a different electronic vibe, conjured by some of Wellington’s most innovative artists. The series lineup includes:
August 1: Ludus
August 8: Stephen Gallagher with David Long and Jules Desmond
August 15: Oghum
August 22: Dream Chambers
Set within the chancel at the altar of the venue, each artist will perform a 60-minute immersive sound experience that redefines ritual in a contemporary light.
Tickets are available from Wednesday 18 June, with limited capacity of 50 for each show of this intimate series.
About the Artists
Ludus
is the captivating musical venture curated by Emma Bernard. Her creative inspiration spans across the worlds of electronic music, audio engineering, sound design, and the written word. Bernard’s artistic journey explores the deep connection between soundscapes and the natural world, with a focus on evoking emotional responses to the environments we inhabit. She is also co-founder of the Pōneke-based collective Tonic.
Stephen Gallagher
is an Emmy award-winning composer and music editor who has worked on an extensive range of projects, from global blockbusters to television and contemporary dance. Most recently, he completed the score for The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim, directed by Kenji Kamiyama. Gallagher’s work spans collaborations with Peter Jackson, Brian Eno, Ed Sheeran, Nick Cave, and many more.
David Long
is a composer, performer, founding member of The Mutton Birds, and member of easy listening noise band, Teeth. His career has spanned over 40 years and seen him work on numerous projects to commercial and critical acclaim. In his own words he likes to “mash shit up”, creating orchestral scores that utilise “not only classical instruments but all sorts of things”.
Jules Desmond
is an experimental musician from Wellington who has played in bands including Letterbox Lambs, 1/3 Octave Band, Bachelor of Architecture and Black Boned Angel.
Oghum
is the interstellar duo of Nell Thomas (Orchestra of Spheres, Cookie Brooklyn and the Crumbs) and Jonny Marks (All Seeing Hand, Mean Bones), performing on Synthi AKS, theremin and other assorted items. Oghum blends electronic sounds from times past with an array of acoustic and found sounds, using nuanced improvisation to create detailed and tangible sonic environments, invoking memory and transporting the listener through narrow gaps into wide open otherworldly spaces.
Jess Chambers
is a composer, musician, and educator currently based in Aotearoa New Zealand, and working under the moniker Dream Chambers. From her beginnings as a folk singer to her current explorations in electronic music, she experiments with sound as a practice of attention: to a room, an outer world, an inner feeling. It’s in that space of beholding where transformation and connection occur, and Chambers is a master alchemist, likening that stretch of attention in music to growing a garden: “There’s a lot of searching, reaching and eventual blossoming in my music – it feels like coming up from underground, like a tulip bulb.”
The Pyramid Club, located on Taranaki Street, is an artist-run space dedicated to experimental music and sonic arts, providing a home for innovative sound exploration.

description:
End of Year Party Time with The Closet, Save the Date: Saturday, December 13!

The rumours are true… after much soul-searching (and to give our neighbours a breather!) The Closet is taking a year off from Kiwiburn. BUT ~ don’t worry the closet doors aren’t closing just yet… we're throwing an end of year party for you all to keep the fruity vibes alive!
We're bringing the pre-burn heat early this year with an epic night at our fabulous friends Champagnaria bar Otto, and we want your beautifully creative minds to help create the party…
Theme TBD >>>>
We want YOU to dream up the wildest, weirdest, most wonderful party themes you can think of. Send us your ideas & the top picks will go to a public vote.
Winner scores two FREE tickets + a bottle of bubbles to pop at the party!
The Lineup so far is already looking epic:
• Seraph – delivering her signature melodic uplifting magic
• Tori – back with the booty-shaking, baddy bass we all crave
• More DJs to be announced soon!
While we won’t be fundraising for the Burn this time, we are raising funds to secure long-term storage for our fabulous clothes & infrastructure… So The Closet can return next year bigger, better, and even more fabulous.
Stay tuned. Start dreaming. Get ready to party like its the end of 2025!

description:
C.W Stoneking - Pāuatahanui - The Morgans Clubhouse, C.W Stoneking - Pāuatahanui - The Morgans Clubhouse
After an unforgettable run of shows across Aotearoa in January, acclaimed troubadour,
C.W. Stoneking makes his much-anticipated return this spring.

Presale 10am (NZST), Friday 15th August
General on sale 10am (NZST), Monday 18th August
Tickets from Banished Music
Register for presale at banishedmusic.com/subscribe

With his unmistakable swagger, Stoneking moves effortlessly between the red dust of Alice Springs and the deep grooves of the American South. Drawing on a heady blend of vintage blues, New Orleans jazz, gospel, calypso, country and western kitsch, he conjures a sound that is both timeless and thrillingly original.
Audiences can expect zombie shuffles, gospel stompers, and tropical torch songs – all delivered with wit, charm, and musical brilliance. Rich in character, darkly funny, and steeped in storytelling, Stoneking’s music may evoke a bygone era, but his performances crackle with electricity.

description:
Auckland Kristallnacht Commemorative Concert 2025, The Holocaust Centre of New Zealand must confirm all tickets generated by the Humanitix ticketing system. Once you register, you'll receive an acknowledgement from Humanitix, followed by a second email directly from the Holocaust Centre of New Zealand.
2025 Annual Kristallnacht Commemorative Concert
Escape & Exile – East & West
Join the Holocaust Centre of New Zealand for a poignant evening of remembrance and reflection. The Te Kōkī Trio, featuring Inbal Megiddo (cello), Martin Riseley (violin), and Jian Liu (piano), will be joined by Professor Kim Cunio, Head of Te Kōkī / New Zealand School of Music, in a powerful performance commemorating Kristallnacht.
 This concert commemorates Kristallnacht, or “The Night of Broken Glass,” the horrific pogroms of 9–10 November 1938, across Germany, Austria, and the Sudetenland. This state-sponsored violence saw the murder of an estimated 91 Jews, the arrest of 30,000, and the destruction of hundreds of synagogues and Jewish businesses. Kristallnacht is widely regarded as a pivotal moment, marking the escalation of Nazi persecution and often described as the beginning of the Holocaust.
 The Nazis sought to silence the music and art of all those they deemed "untermenschen," including six million Jews and other victimised groups. This concert stands as a powerful act of defiance and remembrance, allowing us to hear the voices of those who were murdered, forced into hiding, or exiled. It celebrates their artistic brilliance and ensures their memory lives on.
 This year's theme is "Escape and Exile: East and West." In the tradition of paying musical tribute to all victims, we will honour the music of Jewish composers from across the globe—from the Netherlands and Nazi-occupied Germany in the West, all the way to Iraq and Shanghai in the East.
 The programme will feature pieces that honour:
Erna Weiss Falk, a talented Jewish opera singer from Cologne, whose promising career was cut short by anti-Jewish laws. She and her family ultimately escaped to the Netherlands.
Brigitte Schiffer, a young composer who completed her doctorate in Berlin before fleeing the Nazis to Egypt, where she became the director of the Higher Music Education Institute for women.
The Al Kuwaiti brothers, Jewish pioneers of modern Iraqi music, survived the Farhud, a devastating pogrom inspired by Nazi ideology that targeted Baghdad's Jewish population on June 1-2, 1941, coinciding with the Jewish holiday of Shavuot. Despite their legacy resonating across the Middle East through radio, their contributions were erased from Iraqi history.
Ferdinand Adler, a Hungarian Jewish violinist who miraculously escaped from the Dachau concentration camp, to Shanghai.
 Join us for this important event as we mourn the lives lost and celebrate the resilience of the human spirit. We look forward to welcoming you.
 Details:
Wellington: Sunday, 9 November 2025
Auckland: Monday, 10 November 2025
Doors Open: 6:00 PM
Concert Begins: 6:45 PM
Location: To Be Announced
 Please RSVP by Monday, 3 November 2025, to let us know if you can join us.

description:
Bob McNeill and Emily Roughton, Bob McNeill and Emily Roughton
Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton are two of New Zealand's best-known folk musicians. They bring their deep musical connection to festivals across New Zealand, playing their favourite songs and tunes collected over years of playing together at festivals, stages and late into the night at kitchen tables.
Based in Wellington, Bob is one of NZ's best known folk songwriters. His songs have been covered by artists in NZ, Australia, the UK and USA. New Zealand Musician magazine compared his songwriting to Bruce Springsteen and Mark Knopfler; the Dominion Post likened him to Jackson Brown, James Taylor, Luka Bloom and Dougie Ma­cLean. A guitarist, he is known for both his open-tuned acoustic fingerstyle style and electric guitar playing. He has toured widely in NZ, Australia, Canada, Ireland, the UK and USA. His latest album, released in June 2024, is Lost Stars, an extended release on CD and download featuring new recordings and rarities, with Emily on violin and piano.
From Whangarei, Emily is a virtuoso violinist inspired by the Scottish tradition and the modern trad movement. Classically trained, she is infinitely adaptable with her gorgeous stylings and fiery tune playing and the perfect foil for Bob's lyrical songs.
Don't miss a chance to see these two consummate musicians share their footstomping collection of banging tunes, favourite songs and stolen moments from the last 20 years.
Tickets $25 from Eventfinda or book by text to 02102361951

description:
Burgin, Kerr & Norman, The Undercurrent presents Burgin, Kerr & Norman

A swampy melting pot of country, folk, americana and blues, they combine a mutual love of story-telling and rhythmic grooves with narratives about the human experience. Original material from each member, with a wide range of instrumentation including piano, acoustic and Weissenborn guitars, accordion, bodhran, and percussion.

Irishman Andrew Kerr (ex. Jacky Tar) and Alan Norman (The Warratahs, The Rag Poets) formed a trio with Paddy Burgin (The Wooden Box Band, The Zimmermans). Paddy, a world-renowned luthier who featured on Andrew and Alan’s critically acclaimed 2023 release ‘For the Record’ described as …

“…..one of the year’s best albums in Americana/folk ….a thoughtful, passionate, and
musically rich collection that holds up under repeated listens….”
- Anne Hollister ⁦(www.theindiesource.com⁩)

“I’m struck by the smoothness of the production, the delicate precision of the
arrangements…what a great set of songs. What wonderful playing..”
- Simon Sweetman.

Listen here - ⁦https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V0XnzDhE-vE⁩
⁦https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FRHOXgbYuu0⁩

Saturday 27th September
Doors 7pm/ Gig 7:30pm
$20
Tickets available on the door and online

Wine, beer & soft drinks, tea & coffee, and of course...books available for purchase!

See you there!

description:
CMNZ Series: Takács Quartet (Wellington), Celebrating their 50th anniversary in 2025, the Takács Quartet are among the world’s top tier chamber ensembles.
PROGRAMME
* Joseph Haydn | String Quartet in G minor, Op. 74, No. 3 “The Rider”
* Nokuthula Ngwenyama | Flow
* Ludwig van Beethoven | String Quartet No. 9 in C major, Op. 59 No. 3
ARTISTS
Edward Dusinberre, Violin
Harumi Rhodes, Violin
Richard O’Neill, Viola
András Fejér, Cello
Lauded for their recordings of Joseph Haydn’s String Quartets, the Takács Quartet will open their programme with Op. 74, No. 3, known as The Rider – a reference to the galloping licks in the finale, and will finish with Ludwig van Beethoven’s glorious No. 9, Op. 59 No. 3, Razumovsky.
Between these two tōtara of the string quartet repertoire, the Takács Quartet will present a new work - Flow by American solo violist and composer, Nokuthula Ngwenyama, that seeks to express the creation of the universe as it expanded out from a primeval atom 13.7 billion years ago.
Come in and out of silence
Tone swirling in the balance.
Nothing, then everything
Waving into space.
Then light
And after a longer while
Air.
And now sixteen strings manually animated
Vibrating through time.
Nokuthula Ngwenyama

Celebrate your kids' Daddy with a professional, painless, and fun photo session that will leave everyone smiling. Don't miss out on this annual tradition—add another timeless portrait to your collection this Father's Day!

description:
Jack Hooker - Live Music Wednesdays, Jack Hooker is an acoustic guitarist and electronic musician, known for his immersive electronic music and intricate fingerstyle guitar. His output spans solo guitar, the groups The Shocking and Stunning and Ambient Ousìa, and many international collaborations across Indonesia, the Philippines, Greece and beyond. He will be performing a set of original acoustic guitar works. Expect expansive steel-string soundscapes with intricate fingerpicking, tapping techniques, and open tunings.

As always, entry is free and $15 pizza specials will be available!
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Choral Connections Concert, NZCF presents Choral Connections, a concert featuring two of New Zealand’s finest youth choirs – the acclaimed New Zealand Secondary Students' Choir, directed by Sue Densem, and the Aotearoa Academy Choir, directed by Rowan Johnston and Elise Bradley.
Set in the soaring acoustics of Wellington’s Cathedral of St Paul, this public concert forms the centrepiece of NZCF’s Choral Connect convention – a bi-annual professional development conference that brings together choral directors from around the country.
At the end of the concert, conference delegates with join with the two youth choirs to form a massed choir of over 150 voices to sing under the direction of international choral clinician Dr Pearl Shankuan.
New Zealand Secondary Students' Choir
Aotearoa's national choir for secondary school students, NZSSC gathers during school holidays to rehearse and perform across the motu. Each two-year cycle culminates in an international tour: in July 2024, the choir travelled to China, where they took part in the Shanghai Oriental Art Centre Chorus Exchange, the Chorus and Conducting Art Conference in Hangzhou, and the China International Chorus Festival in Beijing.
NZSSC is directed by Sue Densem, alongside Assistant Conductor and Accompanist Brent Stewart and Assistant Conductor and Vocal Consultant Ben Madden.
Aotearoa New Zealand Academy Choir
The Academy Choir was established as a pipeline for talented singers from across Aotearoa who are aspiring to join NZSSC or the NZ Youth Choir. In 2024, the Academy Choir received a Gold Diploma at the World Choir Games in Auckland.
The Aotearoa Academy Choir is co-directed by Elise Bradley and Rowan Johnston.
Dr Pearl Shangkuan is a highly sought-after conductor, lecturer and clinician who has led performances and workshops on six continents. She is the National President-elect of the American Choral Directors Association (ACDA), the chorus director of the Grand Rapids Symphony and Professor Emerita of Music at Calvin University in Grand Rapids, Michigan. She has conducted several times at Carnegie Hall and other major concert halls in the US. Her guest conducting engagements regularly take her to Europe, Asia, and across North America.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Monteverdi Vespers, Join us for our major project of the year! This will be the first time this groundbreaking work has been performed in Wellington for over a decade.

Juxtaposing Renaissance melodies and polyphony with the rich virtuosity and colour of Baroque instruments, intimate vocal solos with a choir and orchestra of unprecedented grandeur, and dazzling opulence with striking emotional and spiritual depth, this will be an unmissable performance


We are thrilled to be joined by an incredible orchestra of top musicians from the NZSO and leading international artists! Come hear the striking tones of cornetti, dulcian, archlutes, Baroque recorders and more!


N.B. There will be a pre-concert talk at 7pm.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Papermaking using native plants, Papermaking using native plants
Discover the hidden beauty of native plant fibre and learn how to make your own harakeke paper from scratch.

Following an introduction to basic papermaking techniques, participants will hone their skills through several projects including sheets of paper, cards, letter writing stationery and more.

In addition to the practical skills, the workshop will cover technical aspects of preparing your own pulp using simple household appliances and commonly found plants.

Finished harakeke paper typically has a light straw colour and its own unique texture and feel. The paper is suitable for a wide range of uses.

description:
Cushion Concert with The Lighthouse Trio, IAS Cushion Concerts presents local bands in the intimate environment of historic Inverlochy House. Join us as The Light House Trio explores some new interpretations of familiar melodies and unheard compositions! The trio will play original arrangements of favourite tunes as well as come brand new original songs. Expect mysterious ballads, soulful blues, and exhilarating bop.

The Lighthouse Trio is made up of three of Wellington's busiest players; Alex Trask, Jeremy Grant, and Elijah Mulheron. Alex is a highly regarded alto saxophonist who is seen all around town leading bands and playing for some of the leading musical organisations, including the RNZAF band and formerly the Rodger Fox Big Band. Elijah is the busiest bassist in town and often appears with Wellington legends such as Callum Allardice and John Rae. Jeremy is an extremely captivating guitarist and the creative force behind the arrangements you will hear.

The trio is celebrating the release of their debut EP with a tour of their own backyard, playing for the first time in Pito-one and Raumati, and finishing with a gig in central Wellington. Come along for an evening of fresh music presented in a relaxed setting, we hope to see you there!

https://www.facebook.com/share/1CAASvj8fd/

Free entry for tamariki and no worries if cushion's aren't your thing - we have chairs!

Ngā mihi nui to our friends at Wellington City Council for sponsoring our 2025 Cushion Concert series. This helps ensure artists are paid a living wage for their performance. Seventy five percent of all ticket proceeds go directly to the artists.

description:
Daniel Champagne (Australia) LIVE at Martinborough Town Hall (7pm Show), Show #1
Second show announced by popular demand!
The young virtuoso recently described as “the finest guitar player of this generation” has spent the past few years selling out shows all over the globe and will be bringing his dynamite live act back to New Zealand in 2025 for a series of intimate regional concerts!
Seated show
Family friendly  
Cheaper $15 tickets for under 18s because live music is for everyone!
BYO (non alcoholic) drinks and nibbles 
October 19, 2025 @ Martinborough Town Hall
Doors open from 6:30pm / show starts at 7:00pm (8:10pm finish) 
Tickets are VERY limited. DON'T miss out!
WHAT THE PRESS SAY..
“The word Prodigy seems to entirely fall short of this soft-spoken young man’s skills, he coaxes sounds and melodies out of his instrument that literally drop jaws.”
The Calgary Herald, CANADA

“Today I saw the future of Folk – Festival goers flocking in the thousands towards the main stage to witness a young musical phenomenon from Australia dish out an absolute show-stopper.” The Firefly Column, USA

“Daniel Champagne is a crossroads. Fusing the strong traditions of Blues, Folk and other roots art with pop showmanship and admirable lyrical ability. I firmly believe that he will become an ambassador for roots music in a time where it desperately needs representation.” The Indie Blender, CANADA

“reinventing roots guitar” Rhythms Magazine, AUSTRALIA“Watching Daniel Champagne perform is a once in a lifetime experience. He is a true prodigy that plays like no one else could possibly play unless they spent at least two lifetimes studying the art.” BW Review, NEW ZEALAND

“Daniel Champagne exudes a natural ease on stage, as he sings poignant lyrics and beautifully crafted melodies that invariably whisk the heart up with grand romanticism. Coupled with an exhilarating guitar talent that transcends mere acoustic playing to replicate a whole band, Champagne is just magical” Themusic.com.au, AUSTRALIA

"You feel as if he just invented the instrument yesterday and was discovering its possibilities afresh” Ted Gioia (American jazz critic and music historian)
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Airhorn Calms Down, Hi [said in a whisper], how are you, are you ready for Airhorn?
PLEASE READ. SHOW WARNING!
This is truly going to be a different Airhorn. Last month was intense, and we love intensity, but felt the need to bring it down. The focus for this month is calm. Chill. Relaxation. This is truly going to be the most gentle Airhorn you have seen.
There will be no flashing lights or threat of epilepsy. There will not be loud noises or gross out humour. There will not be airhorns! This is not a bit. We are sincerely concerned that folks are going to come to think this is a goof and expect the usual madcap, abrasive chaos of our comedy show.
There will be no abrasion. There will be no chaos. We are wanting to do the most experimental show we can do, which in our case is a low-key, cozy, warm-hearted hour of quiet reflection and gentle comedy.This is going to be a soft show for everyone who needs a minute to just breathe. You will laugh, but not enough to hurt your side or upset your neighbor. It will be a laugh held in the liminal space between a deep breath and a long sigh.
For folks in which this amount of calm is too stressful, we will also have a Stimulation Booth (provided by Wattie's) available at any time to provide the classic Airhorn jolt they need.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Folk Bitch Trio – Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Folk Bitch Trio – Te Whanganui-a-Tara
Folk Bitch Trio - 'Now Would Be A Good Time' Album Tour
with special guest Georgia Knight

Now Would Be A Good Time, the debut album by Folk Bitch Trio, tells vivid, visceral stories. Their music sounds familiar, and it’s built on a foundation of the music they’ve loved throughout their lives–gnarled Americana, classic rock, piquant, clear-eyed balladry. But the songs are modern, youthful, singing acutely through dissociative daydreams and galling breakups, sexual fantasies and media overload, all the petty resentments and minor humiliations of being in your early twenties in the 2020s.

Heide Peverelle (they/them), Jeanie Pilkington (she/her) and Gracie Sinclair (she/her) have known each other since high school, and first started singing together five years ago. Peverelle recalls sending Pilkington a heartbroken—in their words “bad”—song they had written called “Edie”; Pilkington remembers the song differently. “I felt so inspired that my teenage peer had written something so honest and original,” she recalls. It wasn’t long before she messaged Peverelle and Sinclair, asking if they’d be interested in starting a “folk bitch trio.” As soon as they started singing together, their connection deepened, and “the chemistry of being inspired by each other was evident from the get-go,” says Sinclair.

Listening to Folk Bitch Trio, it’s clear that this is a band of three distinct points of view, with contrasting and complementary backgrounds and visions. Pilkington grew up with two musician parents and brings formative memories of watching them perform, of listening to Gillian Welch and Lucinda Williams, and of her own imagined path as a career musician. Peverelle spends their spare time making art and furniture; those hobbies, as well as their love of pop music old and new, articulate a love for the tactile, the home-grown and the hand-made. Sinclair is the self-proclaimed jester of the group, but her taste skews dark, gothic, baroque and dramatic, expressed as a love of opera and ballet as well as musicians as wide-ranging as Patti Smith, Nirvana and Tchaikovsky.

Folk music has a bad habit of being presented as a deathly serious concern. It’s the music you cry to, it’s overly sacred, it’s solemnly considered by critic-historians. But Folk Bitch Trio have a shared sense of humour that is embedded deep in their music and that sets it alight, safe from the self-serious traps of the genre. Now Would Be A Good Time is funny and darkly ironic in the manner of writers like Mary Gaitskill or Otessa Moshfegh. On “Gods A Different Sword” they crack that “My body keeps the score/But if you tell me that you need it/I can get up off my floor,” a nod to the clichéd, over-referenced millennial self-help book, as they wryly sing about sex within earshot of housemates, and wring sexual innuendo from physics terminology.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
The Enchanted Ale Quarter, Enter the magical realm of The Enchanted Ale Quarter, a fairytale-inspired pop-up tavern where whimsy, wonder and craft beer collide.

Step into a storybook setting, with twinkling lights, woodland decor, and forest-fantasy touches around every corner. Feast on gnome and fairy-themed comfort food like the solstice salad, loaded forest fries, sirens & ships fish & chips, and a decadent dark forest brownie, all paired with enchanted brews and mythical tipples.

Cosy, curious, and otherworldly, The Enchanted Ale Quarter brings a little magic to Wellington’s winter nights. Dust off your wings and join us for a pint, some sustenance or a potion, no quest required.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Funky Fridays Vol.7 - Not My Sister, Libbi K, Ben-Jammin, Funky Fridays Vol.7 - Not My Sister, Libbi K, Ben-Jammin
We're back for another night of house techno disco bass & more at Moon with Funky Fridays Vol. 7!
Created to revive and celebrate the underground electronic scene Funky Friday is more than just a night out—it’s a space for music lovers dancers and creatives to connect through rhythm and energy. Each edition features a rotating lineup of talented DJs both local and international ensuring a fresh and unique experience every time.
Come with an open mind and leave with tired feet.
This edition features legends Libby K Ben-Jammin & our host Not My Sister!
$10 presales available now via UTR or $15 on the door.
Times:
9-10 Not My Sister
10-11.30 Libby K
11.30-1 Ben Jammin
1-2 Not My Sister
-------------------------------------------------------
NOT MY SISTER
Not My Sister is a house music DJ born and raised in a little town in the north of Italy. Now based in Wellington she started this project in 2024 and recently she has been lighting up dance floors across New Zealand you may have already come across her sets at Twisted Frequency Kiwiburn Earthbeat Cuba Dupa Arkadien and other events across the country. Influenced by funk and disco with a special focus on vocals and anything groovy Not My Sister brings high energy and uplifting sets. Constantly developing as an artist she always brings fun and passion to the dance floors. Expect a delightful fusion of melodic basslines blending soulful tech garage and deep house sounds.

Unlock the Power of AI: Save 10 Hours a Week in Your Business, Join us for this free event with Matt Browning and Stephen Johnson from Incredible Software, designed to transform the way you work using artificial intelligence.

description:
ROADKILL: The Uber-cool Musical - TAHI Festival: CANCELLED, Hey everyone- we have a little change of plans!
Unfortunately, ROADKILL: The Uber-Cool Musical won’t be happening this time around, but we’re already cooking up something even better for the future. All ticket holders will receive a full refund and we can’t wait to welcome you to our next big adventure.
Thank you for your excitement and your support.

CANCELLED-


ROADKILL The Uber-Cool Musical takes you on a wildly immersive journey through love, life and rock ’n’ roll — all from the back seat of a van. This intimate one-man musical combines humour, heart and unforgettable tunes for an experience like no other.
Strap in for the rollercoaster ride of your life as we take a regular mundane occurrence of driving in an Uber and blow wide open the private life, memories and miss happenings of our hero, and driver, Terry.

Carpool karaoke meets intense love story meets wild murder mystery.

Much more than a musical, its an experience, its a journey and an attraction!

In the space of a usual cabaret show and with the help of the passengers in the van, you will witness and be part of, childhood dreams, births, deaths and marriages, high drama, dark comedy, all sung live with a kickass, original, meatloaf-esque rock soundtrack. Surprises and magic ensues as we push the van, and Terry, to the limits of what is possible.

This will be an intimate, sensory overload, in a van. A full grand musical with all the bells and whistles.

With only 9 seats available each ride, grab your mates and have a private experience in the fast lane!
The hottest ticket in town- be sure to experience the ride of your life!

The show is in the style of a musical crossed with karaoke songs you have never heard before...

The van will be stationary and parked for this initial season.

Winner of BEST IN FRINGE and EMERGING ARTIST OF THE YEAR at the Dunedin Fringe and Winner of MOST INNOVATIVE at the NZ Fringe awards this year!

description:
Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents: John Rae, Award-winning composer and musician John Rae invites you to an enchanting evening of Celtic-inspired music that promises to get your feet tapping and your ears thumping. This large ensemble draws on both new and traditional melodies, reimagined in a style that reflects Rae’s cultural roots and personal musical journey. Experience a vibrant celebration of Celtic heritage through engaging rhythms and rich harmonies that showcase the versatility and depth of contemporary Celtic music.

John has recorded over 30 albums as a leader and side man including two BBC Jazz Albums of the Year (2003 and 2004). He has performed with the Scottish National Jazz Orchestra, was the first ever Jazz Composer in Residence at Victoria University, has written music for the NZSO/Wellington Jazz Orchestra and RNZAF Concert Band, and has toured internationally with his eclectic chamber ensemble "The Troubles".

The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15 from Humanitix.com, door sales $20.

Thanks to Creative New Zealand for their generous support.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Scaling Sustainably with Brianne West, founder of Ethique and Incrediballs, Part of the Pegasus Startup World Cup and Sustainable Spring Series
 Globally recognised environmentalist and entrepreneur, Brianne West, redefined industry norms with her bold vision and innovation, transforming a kitchen experiment in Christchurch into a global beauty revolution.
Ethique was the world’s first zero-waste beauty brand and named in Time Magazine’s Best inventions of 2020. It expanded rapidly, saving millions of plastic bottles from landfill in over 20 countries.
Brianne has won many awards including being an Obama Foundation Leader (AsiaPac), Exporter of the Year (American Chamber of Commerce), and NZ EY Young Entrepreneur of the Year, and was a finalist in the 2024 Kiwibank New Zealand Innovator of the year award.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her incredible journey on scaling, and later exiting a purpose driven, sustainable business. Learn about her current venture, Incrediballs which is set to disrupt the beverage industry, and gain practical insights on how to enter new markets while remaining true to your values.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her remarkable journey of scaling - and ultimately exiting, a purpose-driven, sustainable business. She’ll introduce her latest venture, Incrediballs, poised to disrupt the beverage industry, while offering practical insights on breaking into new markets without compromising your values.
Brianne West is a judge for the Pegasus Startup World Cup held on 9 October 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti. Learn more and book a ticket to the Pegasus Startup World Cup here.
Snacks provided, if you would like to order a coffee, please arrive earlier to avoid noise.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Jazz Orchestra Composer Series Presents Callum Allardice, The eleventh concert in our series of Aotearoa jazz composers features award winning composer and performer Callum Allardice, with a new suite of music for rhythm section and strings; Ode to Sadness.

A collection of songs, old and new, presented alongside some of the works that inspired them. From intimate improvisations and poignant melodies to soaring strings, the music moves through moments of reverence, reflection, and quiet triumph. Sometimes solemn, sometimes radiant, but always beautiful, Ode To Sadness is a celebration of the beauty found in sorrow.

Callum is an award-winning composer and guitarist based in New Zealand. He is a three-time recipient of the APRA Best Jazz Composition award for his works ‘Sons of Thunder’ (2016), ‘Deep Thought’ (2017), and ‘Chungin’ (2019). In 2020 he and his group The Jac, received the Recorded Music NZ Best Jazz Artist award for their album ‘A Gathering’, and in 2022 he was the inaugural Te Kōkī - New Zealand School of Music jazz composer-in-residence.

The Jazz Orchestra Composer Series showcases original music for large jazz ensemble by New Zealand composers. Concerts take place every 1st and 3rd Friday of the month, from May to October, from 7pm. Tickets are $15, door sales $20.

Thanks to Creative New Zealand for their generous support.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
1st Joint SETAC AU & ACTRA Conference, We are excited to invite you to join us in Te Whanganui-ā-Tara Wellington, Aotearoa New Zealand from 25-28 August 2025 to experience the first ever joint Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry Australasia (SETAC AU) and the Australasian College of Toxicology & Risk Assessment (ACTRA) conference.
The theme of this year’s conference is:
“Building a lasting legacy: Our choice, their future”
What legacy will our work leave for future generations?
Rooted in an understanding of the impacts of chemicals and emerging challenges, this conference will explore how diverse knowledge systems, collaborations, and innovative educational and engagement strategies can secure a better outlook for generations to come.
Scientists, knowledge keepers, practitioners, and end-users from diverse fields will share their research, insights, and strategies, fostering collaboration for improved environmental outcomes.
Hosted by The Environmental Protection Authority Te Mana Rauhī Taiao
https://www.epa.govt.nz/

description:
King Missile (Dog Fly Religion): John S Hall & Dogbowl (Wellington), Powertool Records Presents ....
King Missile / Dog Fly Religion
John S. Hall and Dogbowl
John S. Hall and Dogbowl are the co-founders of King Missile (Dog Fly Religion) the original incarnation of a group that, in various forms, was a college radio staple in the late 80’s and early 90’s.
In its various forms, King Missile released a string of songs that were resoundingly embraced by American college radio, including “Take Stuff From Work,” “Wuss,” “Sensitive Artist,” “Jesus Was Way Cool,” “Cheesecake Truck,” “Martin Scorsese,” and the hugely popular “Detachable Penis.”
John S. Hall and Dogbowl perform together, and also have separate acts that can be added to the bill: John as a poet/spoken word artist and Dogbowl and a singer/songwriter, whose many albums were released on Shimmy Disc and other labels.
Links

description:
Paraparaumu drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan, Council manages over 130 parks and reserves on your behalf – from playgrounds, sports grounds, and esplanades to scenic and native reserves.
We’re drafting an omnibus Reserve Management Plan to set out objectives, polices and rules that guide their use, management, protection and development and want your help. Tell us what you value about your favourite parks and reserves, what might impact their use, protection and enjoyment, and what ideas do you have for their future.
There's lots of ways to have your say - online, on paper and in person.
Come and chat to our Open Space Planning team
Thursday 28 August, 4pm–7pm, Coastlands Shopping Centre
Saturday 30 August, 9am–1pm, Maclean Park, skatepark
Saturday 6 September, 9am–1pm, Waikanae Park, old skatepark
Sunday 14 September, 9am–1pm, Ōtaki Centennial Park
Further information and ways to provide feedback can be found at haveyoursay.kapiticoast.govt.nz/RMP

description:
LVDF tickets, “Virtuosos” (The Guardian)
International jazz supergroup LVDF bring their genre-bending, globally informed sound to New Zealand for an exclusive appearance at the Wellington Jazz Festival.
All acclaimed bandleaders in their own right, LVDF is a cross-cultural quartet featuring Myele Manzanza (NZ/UK) on drums, Alex Hitchcock (USA/UK) on saxophone, Michelangelo Scandroglio (ITALY) on double bass and special guest Daniel Hayles (NZ) on piano and synths (stepping in for Maria Chiara Argirò). Their fresh sound fuses jazz with electronic textures, global rhythms and raw improvisation.
With Wellington-raised Myele Manzanza returning from London for this special hometown performance, LVDF will perform his groundbreaking Festival commission Music for a Multi-Polar World. This bold new work explores shifting global narratives through sound and draws on events from Brexit to the conflicts in Gaza, Sudan and Congo. Manzanza reflects “I’ve noticed how much the geopolitical shifts have unsettled and angered me, as well as shifting and widening my views on the world, and giving me some things to be hopeful for amidst change.” The work channels both the uncertainty and hope of a rapidly changing world.
The set will also feature tracks from LVDF’s upcoming self-titled EP - a bold and electric statement from a group as diverse in experience as it is unified in vision.
Only in Wellington - don’t miss the debut of one of modern jazz’s most exciting new ensembles, live at Meow Nui.
Commissioned by Wellington Jazz Festival
This LVDF performance is supported by Help Musicians UK, Embassy of Italy, Wellington & Comites Nuova Zelanda
label: Music & Concerts

description:
