description:
FRUIT LOOP FESTIVAL, Fruit Loop Festival
Marlborough’s freshest music festival!
About the Festival
Fruit Loop Festival is Marlborough’s juiciest new summer gig! A full-blown celebration of music and dance, kicking off under the sun and well into the night. Think open-air energy - blending Marlborough's summer magic with a full-scale music festival. An insane line-up of DJs and live performers with production to match! From the first drop to the final track, it's where the beat hits harder and the drinks taste sweeter.
Fresh, wild, fierce - Fruit Loop is the party Marlborough has been waiting for.
The Line-Up
DICK JOHNSON: The heart of NZ’s electronic scene, Dick Johnson is a true house music heavyweight. With remixes for global icons like Fatboy Slim and Claude VonStroke, plus Kiwi favourites L.A.B and Tiki Taane, he’s spent over two decades electrifying dancefloors worldwide. A relentless force behind the decks - and music director for Synthony - Dick brings the fire every time.
SIN: Co-host of George FM Drive, Sin is plugged into the pulse of the dance scene and has quickly become a revered authority on all things electronica. She’s torn up stages at Rhythm & Vines, Homegrown, Hidden Valley, and international festivals from Fiji to the UK. With supports for legends like Fatboy Slim, Groove Armada, and Netsky, Sin brings high-energy house, techno, and ravey curveballs to every set.
KITA MEAN: Kita Mean is New Zealand’s award-winning drag superstar, known for her infectious charm, razor-sharp wit, and high-camp aesthetic. With a career spanning 15+ years across stages and screens worldwide, she’s wowed audiences from Aotearoa and Australia to London, Canada, the USA, and beyond. Winner of the very first RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and co-owner of the iconic Caluzzi Cabaret, Kita continues to dazzle with colourful looks, flawless mug, and hilarious timing. Quirky, kooky, kitsch, and quick - Kita Mean isn’t just a queen, she’s an experience.
PETE GREEN: Originally from the UK, Pete is part of the vinyl-digging collective Rare Specimens. His love for deep, worldly electronic sounds brings low-end warmth and an infectious energy to the dancefloor. Along the way, he’s supported artists such as Crazy P, Psychemagik, Audio Jack, and Christopher Tubbs, playing festivals and parties from Creamfields and Rhythm & Alps to Tempo Schmempo. Expect a set seasoned with Italo, ambient, and deep house flavours, dusted with disco, and finished with a splash of techno.
Event Details
Date: Saturday 28 March 2026
Time: 2pm - 10pm
Location: The Fancy Cow, Marlborough
R18 event - Photo identification will be required.
Return Bus Service:
Getting to and from the festival is easy with our return bus service. Pick-up points will include Redwoodtown Woolworths, Seymour Square, and Countdown Springlands. Purchase a return bus ticket when you nab your ticket.
A full timetable and bus information will be announced closer to the event.
Parking is strictly limited at the festival. Drop off recommended.
Tickets
Tickets are limited — don’t wait. Secure yours now!
Door sales may be available.
Have your ticket open and ready to be scanned at the gate.
Kaupapa
Fruit Loop is a safe, inclusive space where everyone belongs. If you can’t celebrate diversity, respect others, and bring good vibes, this festival isn’t for you.
Harassment or discrimination of any kind will not be tolerated. Anyone behaving this way will be removed.
Refunds and Cancellations
Fruit Loop Festival is a rain or shine event. The festival will proceed regardless of weather conditions, except in circumstances where safety is compromised or conditions make it impossible for the event to continue.
No refunds will be given for changes to the programme, line-up, or advertised performers.
Stay Connected
Follow us for line-up drops, updates and key event information: @fruitloopfestival on Instagram

description:
Sika Sound Journey, This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.

Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements. A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.

description:
Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington, Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington
This September Wesley Huff is joining Thinking Matters for the Truth Matters Tour in Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington and full-day Conference in Auckland.

While in Wellington, he will be doing his only Christian Leaders Lunch.

Proceedings
Doors will open 11:15 am
11:30 am - the event will begin with a short powhiri/mihi whakatau
11:50 am - Kai
12:20 pm - Wes will present his talk and do q and a
1:30 pm - Conclusion of event
About Wesley Huff
Wesley Huff was born in Multan, Pakistan, and spent a portion of his childhood in the Middle East. After being diagnosed with a rare neurological condition at the age of eleven that left him paralyzed from the waist down, Wes experienced a miraculous recovery for which the doctors themselves had no medical explanation. This experience, along with a great deal of study and soul searching in his later teen years, solidified his interest in faith and in engaging the beliefs and worldview perspectives of others. He spent his high school years in Northern Ontario and currently lives in Toronto, Canada, with his wife and three children.

Wesley is currently the Central Canada Director for Apologetics Canada and has been a guest on a variety of public platforms, from The Joe Rogan Experience and Piers Morgan Uncensored, to Apologia Radio and Daily Dose of Wisdom. He has participated in numerous public dialogues, debates, and interfaith events on issues of belief and religion globally.

He holds a BA in sociology from York University, a Masters of Theological Studies from Tyndale University, and is currently doing a PhD in New Testament at the University of Toronto’s Wycliffe College.

description:
Harmonic Sound Journey at Space with Claudio, Harmonic Sound Journey at Space with Claudio
We invite you to a special evening of Sacred Harmonic Sound with multi-instrumentalist Claudio Escutia. This immersive sound journey offers a deeply restorative experience that invites you to settle into stillness, reconnect with the heart, and explore a sense of inner spaciousness through vibration and tone.
Claudio skilfully layers the sounds of gongs, crystal and Tibetan singing bowls, Native American flutes, and other traditional instruments, enhanced through high-quality audio equipment so the sound can be both heard and felt throughout your body.
Harmonic sound and vibration offer the nervous system a chance to truly rest. In this state of relaxation, the thinking mind softens, and we find connection to citta — the heart-mind. From this place, silence arises naturally through the vehicle of sound.
This experience is open to everyone. No previous yoga or meditation practice is needed.

What to bring:
You are welcome to bring your own yoga mat, though studio mats are also available. We will provide bolsters, blankets, and eye pillows for your comfort.

Booking is essential — spaces are limited and this event often fills quickly.

About Claudio
Claudio is a multi-instrumentalist musician originally from Mexico City and now based in Wellington. Born into a family of musicians, he began playing music at a young age and later studied classical guitar. His journey led him to Montreal, where he explored jazz, world music, and spiritual sound traditions.

Extensive travels in Asia and Europe deepened his connection with Indian music and yogic philosophy. He studied Tibetan singing bowls in Kathmandu and Varanasi, and has since worked with a wide range of instruments including the sitar, esraj, bansuri, harmonium, flutes, gongs, and voice.

Claudio’s work blends technical skill, deep presence, and a profound respect for the healing power of sound.

Learn more or listen to Claudio’s music here:
SoundCloud https://soundcloud.com/claudioescutiasounds
Instagram https://www.instagram.com/claudio_yoga_sound_healing
Facebook https://www.facebook.com/soundhealingyogamusicclaudio

description:
The Greatest Story - A Group of Wise Teachers Returning, Public Talk & Workshop

Throughout history, especially at times of crisis, great spiritual teachers have emerged to show humanity the next step forward.

According to British artist, author and esotericist Benjamin Creme, a group of such spiritual teachers is now living in the modern world. Maitreya, the World Teacher, and his group The Masters of Wisdom are here - not as religious teachers - to inspire all people to create a civilisation based on sharing, justice and peace; and for humanity to act to do the work to share and save our world.

Humanity at spiritual crossroads

Humanity is at crossroads. One path into the future leads to increasing social and economic division, environmental destruction, war and planetary peril. The other path leads to increasing social harmony, economic and environmental balance, and a golden era of peace.


Maitreya’s priorities

To help humanity in its task of global transformation, Maitreya has formulated certain priorities. They cover the essential needs of all people, every woman, man and child: an adequate supply of food; housing for all; healthcare and education as basic universal rights. Other top priorities include the restoration of the environment and the establishment of peace.

The key to achieving these goals requires a major shift of present mind-set and thinking, structures and systems – and more equitable sharing of the world’s food and resources. To realise humanity is one global family and the planet is a living being. According to Maitreya: “Without sharing, there can be no justice; without justice, there can be no peace; without peace, there can be no future.”

~ followed by short Transmission Meditation session ~

Share International New Zealand. Contact (021) 261 2749
Access - entrance from Raumati Road/ walk - drive past Te Raukura ki Kāpiti / Kāpiti Performing Arts Centre

Pastor From Gaza, St John’s is collaborating with Central Baptist to host this Pastor from Gaza, as he shares about being the Church amidst conflict.
Born and raised in Gaza, he now ministers across the Gaza and Middle East, providing pastoral support and practical aid to persecuted Christians, refugees, orphans, and widows.
This tour is not political—it is about the Body of Christ. The Pastor will share his own testimony, speak to the ongoing challenges faced by Christians in Gaza, and highlight his wider ministry in the Middle East. It is a message of hope, forgiveness, and perseverance—one that will challenge the Church in Aotearoa.
This event is to raise awareness of the spiritual and practical needs of believers in Gaza and the Middle East, as well as invite us to give in support of his ministry, with funds going directly to help persecuted Christians with food, shelter, and outreach.

description:
Mexican Prehispanic Experience at AWHI, Join Claudio in his Mexican project called Xochipilli´s Eye. Xochipilli (Pronounce: Zo-chee-pee-lee) is the Mexica god of music, flowers, arts, and sacred plants.
Claudio´s last trip home to Mexico was full of inspiration, reconnecting him to his ancestral roots in Mexico City. He was fortunate to meet a prehispanic musician and instrument maker who plays and crafts beautiful traditional instruments. Claudio returned to NZ with many special new instruments; and continues to be inspired and guided by the cultural wealth, wisdom, and knowledge of the ancient cultures of the Americas.
This event will be extraordinary and unique. You will learn about Mexican prehispanic cosmology and spirituality. Experience simple and powerful rituals together with unique musical instruments used by Olmecs, Toltecs, Aztecs, and Mayans. The instruments include clay flutes, clay drums, medicine drums, ocarinas, wooden flutes, shells, and shakers skilfully arranged to create magical shamanic atmospheres.
We will be sharing Cacao which is an energetic traditional Mexican prehispanic drinks that help open the heart, reconnect with the earth element, ignite your fire, and get you up and moving.
What to expect:
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.
Talk about the use of music in the ancient times.
An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions.
Cacao ceremony: Claudio will offer the cacao drink as a connection with the earth, to yourself, and the moment.
Live music that invokes many emotions and imagery, from contemplative natural and mystical environments to uplifting and empowering rhythms. You are free to project and explore within and/ or express and liberate projecting outwards.
We will finish with a shamanic atmosphere relaxation and close the event with a traditional chant.
No previous experience is required.
What to bring:
Wear comfortable clothing! Bring an open heart and a mind ready to learn and receive. You are also welcome to bring a fruit and or a flower to contribute to the altar.
Date & Time: Saturday, April 13th, 6-7:30pm
Location: AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing, Level 2, 15 Johnston Street, Wellington Central
Investment: $55

description:
NZIFF: Sex, Returning from last year’s Festival to screen alongside the rest of his Sex Dreams Love trilogy, Dag Johan Haugerud’s comic drama takes a candid and refreshing look at modern gender roles.

There has hardly been any investigation on contemporary male identity and sexuality as candid, insightful and hilarious as Norwegian auteur Dag Johan Haugerud’s Sex. After winning all major laurels in Nordic cinema with his impressive fresco Beware of Children (2019), the acclaimed director and author embarkson an Oslo-set trilogy simply called Sex Dreams Love.

The first instalment opens on one of the most tantalising and unexpected preludes in recent cinema. Two chimney sweeps frankly open up to each other on a coffee break in their office: the first reveals that he dreamt of being intensely looked at by none other than David Bowie, who was inspecting him as if he was a woman; the other confesses that he recently accepted the sexual advances of a male customer who asked him to have sex with him. But both men are “straight” and married to women. Here, the deft tone of the film and Haugerud’s rules of the game are immediately set.

A fervent admirer of Eric Rohmer’s thickly scripted skirmishes of love and ethics, the Norwegian writer-director infuses irony, depth and compassion in each of his elegantly composed tableaux depicting how the two men cope with the turmoil these experiences bring to their relationships with their partners and family, but most of all with themselves. Featuring some of the brightest and funniest dialogues of 2024, Sex is a real eye-opener. — Paolo Bertolin

description:
NZIFF: DJ Ahmet, Ahmet stumbles upon a forest rave at the edge of his local village, where he finds the escape he’s been desperately seeking in Georgi M. Unkovski’s loveable debut, the first ever Macedonian film to be awarded at Sundance.

Still reeling from the death of their mother and wife, Ahmet’s family is broken. His father, struggling to come to terms with being sole provider and caretaker for the family, pulls Ahmet from school so he can care for their flock of sheep; meanwhile, his younger brother has become non-verbal since their mother’s death. Music is both medicine and matchmaker for young Ahmet, who escapes his grief and the grim mundanity of life under his oppressive father by blasting beats from the world’s jankiest stereo system to impress local girl Aya, back from Germany to be betrothed to an older man.

In this modern-day Romeo and Juliet, the Yuruk mountain village of Kodzalia takes the place of Verona, while the Montagues and Capulets make way for an eclectic support cast, with a technophobic imam, a souped-up tractor and a fluorescent pink sheep all taking the stage. If music be the food of love, then DJ Ahmet is a feast of thumping electro and dance-floor anthems that spur on the teenage protagonist as he fumbles through the throes of his first romance. A jubilant first feature and a real charmer. — Matt Bloomfield
label: Film & Media

description:
NZIFF: Deaf, A woman navigates the experience of motherhood as a deaf person in a hearing world in Eva Libertad’s crowd-pleasing, feel-good drama which collected the Panaroma Audience Award at Berlin this year.

Based on the award-winning short of the same name, Spanish filmmaker Eva Libertad’s debut follows couple Ángela and Héctor as they make the transition into parenthood. Ángela is deaf. Héctor is not. When she tells them she’s pregnant, her own parents can’t hide their shock – loving but concerned that their daughter will be unable to tackle the task of motherhood. Will the baby be born deaf? Uncertainty abounds as the due date draws closer, and it’s not just Ángela’s parents who are beginning to have doubts.

The foundations for the film’s narrative derive from the personal experiences of first-time actor Miriam Garlo, Libertad’s own sister, as she began to contemplate motherhood as a deaf woman. When surrounded by her other deaf friends, Ángela is comfortable, alive, vibrant within a community that supports her. Around the local mums in the park, or her husband’s friends, isolation sets in with a painful immediacy that anyone who has ever struggled to understand the language in a foreign country will know all too well. A poignant story bound by the chemistry of its leads, deafness is woven into the film as a lived experience, not a defining label. — Matt Bloomfield
label: Film & Media

description:
Reels for Meals: Prime Minister, September's Reels for Meals movie fundraiser is Prime Minister.
In August 2017, in the lead-up to national elections, Jacinda Ardern unexpectedly became New Zealand’s opposition party leader. She had just turned 37. Two frenetic months later, she was Prime Minister. Just before the final vote was in, she discovered she was pregnant. She would become only the second head of state in history to give birth while in office.
Ardern quickly became one of the most recognisable leaders in the world. She drew global attention from people craving a sensitive and compassionate approach to the critical issues of our time. In private, she struggled with being a mother and proving herself to a public skeptical of women’s leadership. A series of crises - the Christchurch massacre, pandemic lockdowns, and disinformation-fueled protests outside Parliament - would test that leadership and the feminine touch she brought to it. She resigned from office in January 2023, shocking her supporters and critics alike.
Going behind the scenes of her administration and her private life, Prime Minister follows Jacinda for seven years as she is catapulted to the top of New Zealand politics, becomes a feminist political icon, resigns suddenly from office and continues to champion the fight against isolationism, fear, and the distortion of truth. Intimate home footage shot by her husband and audio interviews that Jacinda did while in office give us unparalleled access. Along with in-depth contemporaneous interviews, these form the emotional backbone of the story, giving viewers an unfiltered window into her years in power.

All profits from this movie fundraiser go to the Lower Hutt Foodbank.

description:
NZIFF: Dreams (Sex Love), A teenage girl recounts her crush for her teacher through the pages of a memoir. The winner of the Golden Bear 2025 is a lucid and tender chronicle of the unforgettable experience of first love.

Originally intended as the second chapter in his trilogy and released in Norway as such, Dag Johan Haugerud’s Dreams ended up premiering internationally as the last. But it secured a fitting crown to the trilogy, by winning the Best Film at the 2025 Berlinale, thus inducting Haugerud among world class auteurs.

Dreams emanates from two of Haugerud’s passions: literature, as he first gained prominence in his homeland as writer, and the cinema of French master Éric Rohmer, distinguished by sentimental skirmishes brimful of finely written dialogues.

The film’s protagonist and narrator is Johanne, a 17-year-old student who falls for her new French teacher Johanna. Johanne manages to get close to her crush, who nonchalantly ignores how her student’s devotion is veering into affection. Yet, this chronicle of first love is told in a voice over reflecting the memoir that Johanne wrote on her experience – meaning that things may or may not have happened as she says. The memoir is also read by the girl’s mother and grandmother who muse on the girl’s literary talent and provide a layer of irony and melancholy to an unfathomably lucid and tender chronicle of the universal and unforgettable experience of first love. — Paolo Bertolin
label: Film & Media

description:
Dear Gentlemen (Colombia), Dear Gentlemen (Colombia)
Director: Patricia Castañeda -

Genre: Drama

About this Event

Dear Gentlemen brings to light the little-known sufraggist movement in Colombia. Set in 1954, the film follows Esmeralda Arboleda, a fiercely intelligent leader who sparks a revolution in a society deeply rooted in patriarchal traditions - a revolution that culminates in a fierce and decisve debate. A women group embarks on a historic struggle to bring the issue of women's right to vote before the National Constituent Assembly. With bold marches, radio appearances, and a brilliant media strategy that puts them on the front page, they achieve their goal, but the real challenge begins during the debate, where they face fierce opposition. Esmeralda Arboleda must endure personal attacks from the assembly members, and just as she is about to speak, she receives a heartbreaking call: her son has suffered a serious accident. She is torn between her duty as a mother and her commitment to the cause, with an unfavorable outcome. Although all seems to be lost, her perseverance leads to a historic victory when women's suffrage is finally approved, marking a turning point in Colombia's history.

Doors open at 6:45 pm, and the movie begins at 7 pm at Aratoi, 12 Bruce Street, Masterton. Running time: 75 minutes.

Costumes encouraged! Spot prizes will be awarded for the best dressed, adding to the spirit of the night. Bring friends, family, or come on your own and join a community of film lovers for playful scares, shared laughs, and a celebration of classic cinema.

Reserve Your Seats. Koha welcome — suggested $5. Your contribution helps keep Film Talks alive and accessible for our community.

Presented by Film Talks, and Aratoi, in association with the Wellington Heritage Festival.

Step into the shadows this Halloween and celebrate the 90th anniversary of one of cinema’s most haunting Gothic classics!

description:
NZIFF: The President’s Cake, A young girl scrambles to prepare a high-stakes birthday cake for a dictator amidst the dangers and deprivations of the Gulf War in this irresistibly scrappy Caméra d'Or-winner from Iraq.

Nine-year-old Lamia (Banin Ahmad Nayef in a spectacular debut) lives with her grandmother and beloved rooster in the impoverished but tranquil Iraqi Marshes. Despite barely being able to feed themselves due to crippling food shortages caused by international sanctions, the family is randomly selected to prepare a cake as part of the forced national spectacle observing Saddam Hussein’s birthday.

From bucolic wetlands to bustling city streets, Lamia embarks on an ingredient-hunting odyssey that mixes equal parts sweet absurdity and bitter reality. Bartering with hawkers, dodging authorities, and begging the kindness of strangers, the young girl encounters the full gamut of humanity, from good to grotesque, as she approaches her ludicrous mission with innocent determination.

Director Hasan Hadi deftly evokes humour and open heartedness against a bleak background of oppression and war. Cinematographer Tudor Vladimir Panduru summons rich texture from the gorgeous locations, beautifully backed by a flowing soundtrack of traditional strings. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

description:

The Hunger is full camp; queer tension and complexity. And beware: the encounters in this movie do not stick to heterosexual norms.

Underworld Tavern in Mt Victoria is hosting this screening in their suitably dark, macabre and industrial surrounds. Prizes will be awarded to the darkest and most vampiric ensemble. A full bar service will be available throughout.

Continuing our run of film fundraisers, The Hunger allows us queers and our allies to engage with a pillar of queer culture. These screenings are organised and hosted by the community for the community. More than just a screening, this will be a queer horror experience.

The event begins at 3pm but come early to get comfortable. The film will start at 3.30. A short comfort break will be provided. Stay for a drink to discuss and dissect.

The Hunger is rated R18. No one under the age of 18 is permitted. Its running length is 97 minutes.

Tickets are $20 waged, $13 unwaged.

- The movie will include closed captions

description:
Sing Sing Film Fundraiser - Arts in Corrections Network, Join Arts Access Aotearoa for a powerful evening of film and purpose as we screen the critically acclaimed movie Sing Sing — based on a true story of redemption, creativity and the transformative power of the arts within the prison system.
Sing Sing tells the story of incarcerated men who find hope and humanity through a prison theatre programme. It reflects the values Arts Access Aotearoa upholds: that the arts can break down walls, build confidence and create change, inside and out.
Tickets are $25 and proceeds support the Arts in Corrections Network.
Before the screening, you will hear from actor, playwright and musician Jamie McCaskill (of the Māori Sidesteps musical comedy group), and playwright and columnist Dave Armstrong. Together, they led a powerful theatre and storytelling course at Whanganui Prison, supporting and transformation behind the wire.
Come along and support us to continue this important work.
About Arts in Corrections
Arts programmes in prisons can be powerful pathways to healing and change. They help people restore their sense of identity, build resilience and develop skills that support rehabilitation and reintegration into the community. By nurturing creative potential and cultural identity these programmes foster personal transformation.
Arts Access Aotearoa leads a national network that supports Corrections staff and community educators and groups to design and deliver meaningful arts programmes in prisons and Community Corrections..

Date & Time: Thursday, 28 August 2025 – Time: 5:30 PM
Venue: Embassy of Japan, 100 Willis St, Wellington, Rating : M
Free admission
copyright:© 2023 Master Mind Ltd.
Hirayama seems utterly content with his simple life as a toilet cleaner in Tokyo.
Outside his structured daily routine, he enjoys music, books, and photographing trees he loves.
A series of unexpected encounters gradually reveal more about his past. A deeply moving and poetic film about finding beauty in the everyday world around us.
Awards & Recognition
Best Actor (YAKUSHO Koji) – Cannes Film Festival 2023
Prize of the Ecumenical Jury – Cannes Film Festival 2023
Best Film – Asia Pacific Screen Awards
Japan Academy Prize for Best Actor
Nominated for Best International Feature Film – Academy Awards
A deeply moving and poetic reflection on finding beauty in everyday life.

description:
The Challenges of Peacebuilding, In this conversation, Dr David Harland will reflect on his experience working as a mediator and negotiator in conflict zones and his role as Director of the Geneva-based Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue. The Centre was awarded the Carnegie Wateler Peace Prize in 2022 “for its track record of finding the means, including mediation, to bring parties together and end conflicts”. Its work has included involvement in Aceh and Mindanao, assisting with the disbanding of the Basque separatist group ETA, and the Black Sea Grain Initiative. David will share insights on the challenges of peacebuilding in an era of growing competition and contestation.
Dr David Harland is a former New Zealand diplomat and Executive Director of the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), a Geneva-based foundation that specialises in the mediation of armed conflict. He previously worked for the United Nations, including in Bosnia, Kosovo, Haiti and Timor Leste, and he wrote the UN Secretary-General’s landmark report on the fall of Srebrenica. David serves on the UN Secretary-General’s high-level advisory board on mediation. He has degrees from Harvard University, Tufts University, Beijing University and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington.
The event will be followed by light refreshments.

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.

description:
From Vision to Action, Wellingtonians have spoken. Thousands of voices have come together to help create A Vision for Wellington — a bold, pragmatic blueprint for our city’s future, backed by findings from independent research.
Now it’s time to hear how those who want to lead our city will respond.
We’ll begin with a short presentation of the Vision itself — celebrating the thousands of Wellingtonians who shaped it, and the bold blueprint they’ve helped create for our city’s future.
Then we’ll put the hottest issues on the table: like how to rebuild trust in leadership, how to get Wellington back in business and affordable again, and how to restore pride and energy to the heart of the city.
This is your chance to test the candidates’ ideas against a Vsion created by thousands of Wellingtonians — and to put your own questions to them as you decide your vote.
Harbourside Function Venue is located above Macs Brewery on the waterfront. Arrive from 5:00pm for a 5:30 start.
Free entry, registration essential. Spaces are limited.

description:
Public Lecture – Amnesty International Secretary General Dr Agnès Callamard, Public Lecture – Amnesty International Secretary General Dr Agnès Callamard
Global human rights leader Dr Agnès Callamard speaks on humanity, justice, and hope in action. Don’t miss this rare event.

Dr Agnès Callamard is recognised globally as a leading authority on governance, accountability, and international affairs. She has been Secretary General of Amnesty International since 2021, previously served as the UN Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial executions, and was Director of Columbia University’s Global Freedom of Expression project. Her career spans decades of leadership in defending human rights worldwide.
In this public lecture, Dr Callamard will reflect on today’s global challenges and opportunities, exploring how collective action can drive change.

Jonathon Boston ONZM, Emeritus Professor of Public Policy at the Wellington School of Business and Government, and Former Director of the Institute of Policy Studies and the Institute for Governance & Policy Studies will host the session.
This event offers a unique opportunity to engage with global human rights discourse in Aotearoa New Zealand at a time when representation, civic freedoms, and the international rules-based order are being widely debated. It also aims to inspire the next generation of change-makers to connect with both local and global struggles for justice.
Event Details
Date & Time: Tuesday 23rd October, 5:00pm doors with lecture starting at 5:30pm
Venue: Rutherford Theatre, Victoria University of Wellington
Who Should Attend? Students, faculty, civil society leaders, activists, and members of the public interested in human rights, justice, and accountability
Accessibility: The venue is wheelchair accessible
Seats Available: 150 seats open to the public (first come, first served)

description:
Government Digital Transformation in Latin America - what can we learn?, We are excited to announce the latest in our series of talks on Digital Transformation, in partnership with Silverstripe.
María Inés Baque will be joining us online from Argentina to share her expert insights and experiences on the key goals, capabilities, opportunities and challenges for government digital transformation - with a range of use cases from around Latin America.
María Inés Baque is Government Transformation Advisor for Latin America, Canada, and the Caribbean (LCC) at AWS. She served as secretary of digital government and technology innovation in Argentina from 2016 to 2019. She coordinated the Digital Agenda 2030 and led the transformational efforts in the areas of digital services, digital inclusion, open government, open data and new technologies adoption.
Global awards and recognitions she has received include Innovation Lab, Tel Aviv, 20 exceptional GovTech Leaders (2020), Women Corporate Directors 2019 and The 100 Most Influential People in Digital Government, Apolitical, 2018.
She was co-chair of the G20 Digital Economy Taskforce for Gender Inclusion in 2018 that issued the Bridging the Digital Gender Divide report.
Before government, her career was in global IT and financial services enterprises. She focused on process reengineering, startups, IT management, outsourcing and business process operations.
You may attend in person at the MBIE offices (limited to 40 people - there will be some food courtesy of Silverstripe), or you may tune in online via Microsoft Teams (the link will be at the bottom of your order confirmation email). If you choose to attend in person please arrive at 11.50am so there is time for you to sign in, pick up some food, and be seated before we begin. There will be time for questions after the presentation.

description:
HRCA 50yrs Misuse of Drugs Act: What impact? What next?, Rutherford House (by the train station)
Room RHLT2
Bunny Street
Wellington
1.30-4.30pm
Free Admission
Light refreshments afterward
The NZ Misuse of Drugs Act 1975 (MoDA) has failed to deliver. Data from the United Nations Office for Drugs and Crime indicated the demand for drugs is greater than ever, while the supply of drugs knows no bounds.
A failure acknowledged globally and one we witness first hand here in Aotearoa NZ.
Back in 2011 a comprehensive review of the MoDA conducted by New Zealand Law Commission had already concluded the MoDA “should be repealed and replaced by a new Act …administered by the Ministry of Health”.
The Harm Reduction Coalition of Aotearoa wants to see that recommendation enacted.
We are delighted to have assembled a group of respected independent thinkers in the field, with vast experience of drug policy in Aotearoa and beyond, to reflect on the impact of the MoDA and to identify the principles and values needed to underpin new drug laws.
Warren Young
Professor of Law & Former Deputy President New Zealand Law Commission
Kirsten Gibson
Chair of Harm Reduction Coalition Aotearoa and Qualitative Researcher
Fiona Hutton
Associate Professor, Institute of Criminology, Victoria University of Wellington
Adam Dorsett
40 Years Living Experience of Prohibited Drug Use, in Prison for 25 years
Julian Buchanan
Former UNODC Advisor and Criminology Professor
New Zealand has a history for world leading innovative policy reform: Woman’s Right to Vote; Decriminalisation of Sex Work; National Needle Exchange, Same Sex Marriage and most recently Drug Checking.
This half day symposium will provide clear evidence why major law reform is necessary and detail the foundations upon which Aotearoa NZ can once again lead the way with new drug laws based on evidence, research and experience.
We look forward to seeing there!
Do pass on to anyone who might be interested.

description:
China and the Media Landscape in the Pacific, Over the last decade, the People’s Republic of China has sought to deepen its ties with Pacific Island countries. Beijing’s efforts to cultivate influence in the region have included expanding economic, diplomatic, and security ties with Pacific Island nations, as well as expanding China’s footprint in the region’s media landscape. This talk will present the findings of recent research on China’s efforts to shape reporting, media coverage and narratives in the Pacific Islands and put Beijing’s efforts within the context of the region’s rapidly evolving information landscape.
 About the speakers:
Heidi Holz is a Senior Research Scientist at CNA. For close to two decades, her work has focused on PRC strategic communications, propaganda, and influence efforts. She is a graduate of Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service, where she received a master’s degree in security studies and a bachelor’s degree in Chinese and East Asian history.
Genevieve Collins is a research specialist in the China Studies program at CNA, where her research focuses on the behaviour of China’s state-run media and its reactions to US military operations and activities.
 Barbara Dreaver (Discussant) has been the Pacific Reporter for TVNZ 1 News since 2002, breaking stories uncovering social and economic issues affecting Pacific people living in New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. In 2020, she created a two-year training programme through Pacific Cooperation Broadcasting Ltd to support new Pacific journalists across the Pacific region. In the 2024 New Years Honours she was awarded an ONZM for services to investigative journalism and Pacific communities.
 About CNA: CNA is a non-profit, non-governmental research and analysis organization dedicated to providing independent and objective analyses to the U.S. government and the public. This talk will build on previous CNA research on China and the Pacific Islands media landscape which you can find at www.cna.org.

description:
Resilient Waters: NZ–German Conference, Strengthening Urban Water Systems Against Extreme Weather – German Insights for Aotearoa

New Zealand’s water infrastructure is under growing pressure from climate change, ageing systems, and extreme weather events. Ensuring safe drinking water, reliable wastewater management, and resilient infrastructure requires fresh thinking and innovative solutions.
The Resilient Waters Conference, hosted by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC), will bring together German innovators and New Zealand stakeholders for a high-level forum dedicated to future-proofing New Zealand’s water systems.
At this conference, a delegation of German companies will present cutting-edge technologies and intelligent system solutions designed to improve water resilience in the face of climate change. The programme will feature expert presentations, sector-specific insights, and networking opportunities with a professional audience from water utilities, engineering firms, city councils, and decision-making bodies.
Following the conference, the programme for the delegation will continue with B2B meetings, expert roundtables, and site visits in Wellington, Hawke’s Bay, and Auckland from 17–21 November 2025. These tailored sessions will connect German companies directly with New Zealand stakeholders to exchange knowledge, explore collaboration, and identify concrete opportunities for partnership.
 This initiative is organised by the German-New Zealand Chamber of Commerce (GNZCC) in collaboration with German partner AHP International and funded by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWE).

description:
2025 Annual South Coast Cleanup, Welcome to the 16th annual South Coast Cleanup, 10:30AM-12:00PM 13th September 2025.
As well as caring for our coasts and oceans, it’s all about community! Join us at any of our cleanup locations for a morning of litter collection and family fun.

WHEN
We kick off at 10:30am on the 13 September. We host clean up sites at 12 locations between Owhiro Bay to Breaker Bay on the Wellington South Coast. All rubbish will be gathered up around 12.15pm and taken to Lyall Bay by the playground to form one huge rubbish mountain that will be collected by the council.

Pitch in for a rubbish pile up at 12:30 at Lyall Bay playground where we will mound up our rubbish and admire our collective efforts! Then we will head to Parrotdog for a drink / kai after!

WHERE
Our fantastic friendly volunteer groups will be scattered along the coastline between Owhiro Bay and Breaker Bay. You can turn up at any of our volunteer sites:

Site 1 - Owhiro Bay hosted by Project Jonah
Site 2 - Dive Wellington hosted by Dive Wellington
Site 3 - Island Bay West hosted by Mountains to Sea and Island Bay Residents Association
Site 4 - Island Bay Snorkel Trail hosted by Friends of Taputeranga
Site 5 - Houghton Bay hosted by Houghton Valley School
Site 6 - Te Raekkaihau Point hosted by Ghost Diving
Site 7 - Lyall Bay West hosted by Underwater Club Wellington
Site 8 - Lyall Bay Central hosted by Lyall Bay Coastal Care
Site 9 - Lyall Bay East hosted by Earth Science NZ (formerly NIWA)
Site 10 - Moa Point hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 11 - Tarakena Bay hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 12 - Breaker Bay hosted by Breaker Bay Residents Association

description:
Forest & Bird: Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail, Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail

Book your place now to reserve a chair.

Between November 2023 and March 2024, Te Papa natural history curator Dr Colin Miskelly walked the length of Aotearoa New Zealand on Te Araroa Trail – counting every bird seen or heard along the way. His talk will cover some of the logistics of walking the trail, as well as a summary of the birds encountered. This included looking at what difference (if any) predator trapping had on the abundance of native birds. For a taste of what the talk will cover, see Te Araroa Trail | Te Papa’s Blog.

Colin Miskelly on Mt Crawford, Tararua Ranges:

description:
Weeding Bee 18th October, Weeding Bee 18th October
Kia Ora Koutou

Now we have finished planting we are turning our attention to the all important W**d releasing.
This is essential to keeping the seedlings we have planted this winter from being overwhelmed by grass and weeds.
Also mulching to help with moisture retention over those hot summer days (hopefully we get a summer!)
Meeting at the Nursery on Hana Udy street at 9am
Gloves, tools and sunscreen provided along with a morning tea and an update on the Reserve afterward.
Hope to see you there !



Health & Safety Notice: When working in the Reserve, please ensure your clothing and footwear are appropriate for expected weather conditions (cold, wet or hot) and the terrain (such as holes, hidden objects, blackberry, overhead branches). Trip hazards and slippery tracks are a possibility. Stay clear of waterways. Be cautious if you have allergies and carry the necessary medication. Enjoy your time in the Reserve and please avoid blocking pathways used by other users. Report any accidents, injuries or possible hazards to the H&S Coordinator (021 071 536)

description:
Climate Kōrero Pōneke - Storytellers Night # 3, Join us for Climate Kōrero #3!

After our first two sold-out events, we are thrilled to invite you to the third installment of Climate Kōrero - an evening dedicated to celebrating the inspiring mahi of individuals and organisations driving climate action in our communities.

We'll hear from four passionate speakers who will share their journeys, insights, and practical ways you can get involved. The event follows the Pecha Kucha format - each speaker presents 20 slides, with each slide shown for 20 seconds. This fast-paced visual format is a great way to share stories and keeps everyone on their toes! After each presentation, you’ll have the chance to kōrero directly with the speakers, so bring your questions and curiosity.

Why should you come along?
* Get inspired by changemakers in the climate action space
* Free kai to enjoy while you listen and connect
* Meet like-minded people and grow your climate action network
* Discover opportunities to get involved, including funding through the Climate and Sustainability Fund

Our speakers:
* Gareth Hughes – Wellbeing Economy Alliance
* Ellie Clayton – Kaicycle
* Emma Osborne & Gareth Jardine – EkeRua Rebicycle
* Orini Rokx-Taratu & Santino Morehu – Future Unity

Event details:
* 5:00–5:30pm – Arrive, grab some kai, and explore info on climate action in Pōneke
* 5:30pm – Welcome and first two speakers
* Intermission – More kai and kōrero
* Final two speakers – Then wrap-up and mingling

Whether you're new to climate action or already involved, this is a great chance to connect, learn, and be inspired.

Come and kōrero with us!

description:
Clean and Care: Green Cleaning, Discover a more sustainable way to clean and care for your home!

Join eco-lifestylist Stella Carruthers for this hands-on workshop teaching you how to clean with no chemicals. Become aware of the dangers of greenwashing and how to identify commercial products that are safe for both people and planet.

Learn how to make your own effective cleaning solutions using simple ingredients from your kitchen. Discover that cleaning green not only saves you money, it can also support sustainable action that starts right in your home.

Please bring 2 small bottles and 1 container to take away samples of products. These can be upcycled items such as hummus pottles and small soda bottles for containers.

Spaces are limited, book now to clean green this spring!

description:
Electrify Wellington: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Wellington will show you how.  
Most Wellington homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Wellington has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Wellington.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Wellington is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

description:
Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.
Why attend?
Learn about climate diplomacy in action
Engage with leaders shaping global climate responses
Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting
🗓️ Date: Tuesday, 26 August 2025
🕔 Time: 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM
📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington
🎟️ RSVP Required – Limited Spaces
Networking Reception: From 6:30 pm with canapes and drinks kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.
FOR ANY DIETARY:
Please email us at ishant.ghulyani@unanz.org.nz
Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.

description:
Electrify the Hutt Expo 2025, The Electrify the Hutt Expo is charging into Lower Hutt with a mission to spark inspiration and supercharge your lifestyle with the power of clean electricity. As energy bills climb and climate concerns grow, this high-energy event will show you how to take control—cut costs, slash emissions, and embrace a smarter, more sustainable way of living.
Discover the incredible potential of generating your own local power through solar panels, micro wind turbines, and more. With dynamic demos, interactive exhibits, and expert talks, you'll learn how easy and empowering it is to electrify your home, reduce your reliance on fossil fuels, and enjoy the long-term benefits of clean energy.
But that’s just the beginning. The expo goes beyond saving money and helping the planet—it’s about building stronger, more resilient communities. By embracing local energy generation, we can protect ourselves from rising energy costs, power outages, and climate extremes. It’s about creating homes and neighbourhoods that are not just efficient, but future-proof.
So whether you're a curious homeowner, a savvy business owner, or just someone who wants to be part of something positive, Electrify the Hutt is your place to plug in. Come connect with experts, explore cutting-edge tech, and join a growing movement to electrify our lives and build a cleaner, brighter Hutt Valley for everyone.
Add the date to your calendar now!

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Friends AGM with guest speakers, Join the Friends of Wellington Botanic Garden for our Annual General Meeting and a pair of inspiring botanical presentations. You don’t have to be a member to attend — everyone’s invited!
Programme
Each presentation is 30 minutes, with time for questions.
Paul Bell-Butler
Botanist and PhD candidate, Paul is delving into the hidden world of leafy liverworts (family Lophocoleaceae). His research combines modern molecular techniques with traditional botany to reveal how these overlooked plants shape ecosystems and influence seed germination.
Clare Shearman
Plant Collection Team Manager at Wellington Botanic Garden, Clare brings a career spanning historic English estates to iconic New Zealand gardens. Fresh from the prestigious Longwood Gardens Fellows program in the USA, she shares insights into garden design, conservation, and how public gardens nurture wellbeing and connection.
Come along to hear their stories, celebrate our beautiful gardens, and meet fellow plant enthusiasts.
Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
For more info about the Friends: https://friendsofthewellingtonbotanic.wordpress.com/
label: Conservation & Environment
